1. C
ontent .  The information contained in this handbook is for use at  the MAJCSC.  The
planning information and ORBATS are not  authoritative and are notional.  They should not
be used for operational planning.
2. C
opyright .  This handbook contains United Kingdom Crown copyright material and
the intellectual property rights for this material belong exclusively to the United Kingdom
Ministry of Defence.   It also contains information on the Kuwait Armed Forces and the
intellectual property rights for this information belong exclusively to the Kuwait Ministry ofDefence.  No material or information contained in this handbook should be reproduced,stored in a retrieval system or transmitted in any form outside the Mubarak Al -Abdullah Joint
Command and Staff College except when authorised by College Headquarters.
3. Ob
jective .  The objective of the Staff Officer’s Handbook is to provide a source of
useful and easily accessible military  information for use by students during exercises at the
Mubarak Al -Abdullah Joint Command and Staff Course.
4. S
ecurity.  This handbook is issued to students and Directing Staff by the United
Kingdom and Kuwait Governments for defence purposes only.  The information presentedmust be accorded the same degree of security protection as that accorded by the UnitedKingdom and Kuwait Governments.  This information may only be disclosed within defenceorganisations.  Any person finding this handbook should hand it in to a Kuwaiti Armed Forcesunit for its safe return to the Mubarak Al -Abdullah Joint Command and Staff College.
5. A
mendment .  The accuracy of the information contained in this handbook is the
responsibility of the Course Development Team and Directing Staff subject matter experts .
It is as up to date and accurate as research and access to information allows.  DirectingStaff and students are encouraged to bring any inaccuracies and inconsistencies to theattention of the Directing Staff Sponsors so that amendments may be made, either for thebenefit of  the current or future Courses.

umbering.  The Staff Officer’s Handbook has the following numbering system:

1.1. National Security :  Kuwait’s national security originates both from national 
sovereignty, articulated and explained in Kuwait’s Constitution, and national interests. The 
first duty of the Amir of Kuwait and his Government is to maintain the freedom and integrity 
of the State and human security of the population, within the principles of Islam.  The Amir’s oath of office states:  
 “I swear by Almighty God to respect the Constitution and the laws of the State, to defend the 
liberties, interests, and properties of the people, and to safeguard the independence and 
territorial integrity of the Country”
1. 
Kuwait’s national security includes the safety of the state and protecting it from external and 
internal threats.  External threats may include invasion, attack or blockade.  Internal threats 
may include terrorism, subversion, civil disorder, criminality, insurgency, sabotage and espionage.  Other threats include instability caused by financial crisis, climatic events, cyber 
or other forms of attack on critical national infrastructure and the possibility of pandemic disease affecting the population.  
1.2. National Interest :  It is not the role of the Armed Forces to define national interest, 
that is the responsibility of the Amir and Kuwait Government.  Kuwait’s national interest will seek to secure a range of broader interests – political, economic and social – that contribut e 
to the nation’s strength and prosperity and human security.  Such interests are interconnected and mutually supporting.  Without security and the ability of the Kuwaiti people to live their lives freely, the foundations of prosperity would be undermined. 
1.3. Government  Policy :  Kuwait’s chosen political outcomes, endstate and objectives 
are articulated in the Government’s national policy.  Policy articulates a choice leading to a 
course of action proposed or adopted by the government.  The Amir, Prime Minister, Cabinet 
and National Assembly are responsible for the Kuwait’s national policy. The government’s political intentions are articulated as a national strategic vision, aim or endstate, supported 
by strategic objectives.  Policy will be reviewed and renewed periodically as needed.  
1.4. Kuwait Government ’s (National) Strategy:  National strategy defines, secures and 
advances the nation’s long- term, enduring core interests and aims over time. Generally, 
aims are based on security and prosperity.  National strategy coordinates the instruments of 
Kuwait’s national power (Diplomatic - Information – Military – Economic) in pursuit of national 
policy aims and objectives to secure Kuwait’s interests.  Formulating and executing national strategy is changeable and repeating circular activity.  Unexpected events and crises may 
also radically change national strategy, requiring the military to operate outside of previous planning assumptions and Defence policy .  Kuwait will use a mixture of hard and soft power 
to influence other nations and secure their own aims. The balance of how they project their hard and soft power reflects the overall attitude of the nation. Descriptions of soft and hard

complemented by diplomacy and information, to effectively influence actors or to
directly change the course of events. Actors use hard power to attract, deter and
compel.

Continuum of C ompetition (AJP- 01) 
1.10.  The continuum of competition is a model depicting how attitudes and behaviours 
shape international relations. The continuum depicts four types of relationships between states/groups of people: cooperation, rivalry, confrontation and armed conflict. The 
boundaries between cooperation, rivalry and confrontation, and the threshold between 
confrontation and armed conflict, are complex and dynamic; the progression between each 
is neither linear nor easily defined. Interstate relations are typically sectoral: two  or more 
states may cooperate in one sector and be in confrontation in another. The continuum is 
described and illustrated in Figure 1. 3 below .

• Rivalry . Rivals exist in a state of peace but have conflicting aims or 
contradictions. The actors compete with an attitude or behaviour in accordance with 
the rules -based international order (RBIO). The RBIO is a shared commitment by all 
countries to conduct their activities in accordance with agreed rules that evolve over time through multinationally agreed processes. Rivalry is not necessar ily negative, it 
is the normal state in international relations, and when it exists within the RBIO 
framework it can be beneficial to all parties and the international system.  
• 
Confrontation. Confrontation occurs when differences have not been 
reconciled and adversaries oppose each other with hostile intent or behaviour 
such that a state of crisis develops. Adversaries use hostile behaviour or 
attitudes, including posturing, threats and perhaps  violence, as a competitive tool 
to resolve the contradictions in their favour. There is no defined threshold that separates confrontation from armed conflict because many actors intentionally try 
to obscure or confuse exactly where this thr eshold lies. 
 
• Armed conflict . Armed conflict occurs when escalation cannot be prevented 
or contained, leading to one party resorting to military force to compel their enemy to 
resolve the contradiction in their favour. Armed conflict is a special kind of 
competition because it is not  enduring; its role is to set the conditions for other forms 
of competition. Since armed conflict includes acts of nationally directed military 
violence, it invariably has an exponential effect on human emotions, uncertainty and 
friction. Mor eover, armed conflict is an extreme trial of physical and moral strengths, 
and tests both institutional and individual resources of endurance and resilience.  
War & Warfare  
1.11.  War.  War is a state of armed conflict between different countries, or different groups 
within a country.  ( States seldom officially declare war in the modern era) . 
1.12.  Warfare .  Warfare is the conduct of war.  It is “the how” of waging war.  Warfare 
continues to change, evolve and be transformed by society, diplomacy, politics, and 
technology.

3. Operational Level. The 
operational level is defined by its role, which is to link and resource tactical -level activities to 
strategic objectives. It is the essential gearing between the strategic and the tactical levels, 
where campaigns and major joint operations are planned, and actions are integrated and 
sequenced to achieve strategic objectives.   Capabilities that are required by multiple tactical 
commands are often controlled at the operational level to enable them to be allocated when 
required.  
3.4. Tactical Level .  The tactical level of operations is the level at which activities, battles 
and engagements are planned and executed to accomplish military objectives assigned to 
tactical formations and units. The tactical level uses the echelons of command to further 
integrate, prioriti se and coordinate their activity. This activity creates a range of effects that 
together contribute to successful operations . 
3.5. Relationship between the levels of operations.  The relationship between what is 
tactical  level, operational l evel and strategic level  is both fluid and contextual.  Tactical level 
gains and losses may have far greater strategic  level effects than that which is immediately 
obvious.  There is however a difference of focus between command at different levels.  In 
practice, even this apparently clear difference does not stop intervention by strategic level 
political and military leaders seeking to influence tactical level activity and giving lower -level 
commanders very specific direction on what to do, as well as how to do it.  This might be when there is a clear political necessity to intervene at a certain time, in a certain place or in a certain way .

• Peacetime Military Engagement .  The peacetime military engagement theme 
encompasses those military activities that are intended to shape the peacetime 
environment to encourage local or regional stability  in the medium to long- term.  
Persistent engagement creates relationships and develops mutual understanding, influence and interoperability through: building partners' capacity; defence diplomacy; 
outreach; multinational training exercises; and other cooperative security activities. 
Humanitarian relief activities are the results of complex emergencies involving natural or 
human- made disasters or other endemic conditions, such as disease, hunger or p rivation .  
Peacetime Military Engagement is sometimes called Defence Engagement.  
• Peace Support .  This theme takes place in the rivalry zone of the continuum of 
competition.  The theme seeks to preserve peace or intervene early within a potential 
conflict to maintain stability, prosperity and the rule of law. Activities guided by this theme 
contribute to the comprehensive approach on a range of civilian tasks to redress the 
contradictions of a conflict, including: maintaining public order and security; security 
sector reform; disarmament, demobilization and reintegration; transitional justice; 
infrastructure reconstruction; and national reconciliation. The theme implies both soft and 
hard power actions. Soft power and hard power’s attraction comes through 
developmental actions aimed at enhancing a government's willingness and ability to c are 
for its people. Hard power’s coercive actions apply a cost or a denial -of-benefits to those 
who try and stretch the boundary of the peace settlement or the RBIO. This theme 
predominantly consists of peacekeeping and peacebuilding activities.  
• Security .  The security campaign theme applies within the confrontation zone of the 
continuum of competition, with the five principles of deterrence being implicit in the 
theme’s nature.   The security theme implies that the state  detects, deters and, if required, 
responds to strategic competition’s operating techniques, especially threshold shifting. This may be contesting sub- threshold activity or conducting peace enforcement pre - or 
post-warfighting operations . These are  operating environment s where Armed Forces are 
used to re -establish stability and prosperity, underpinned by the rule of law.  Security is 
not absolute, commanders are likely to support the activities of other actors in protecting, 
strengthening and restoring civil society, governance, rule of law and the economy. 
Examples include counter -insurgency (COIN) operations, contribute to stabilization and 
reconstruction operations, or a mixture of both.  
• Warfighting.  Warfighting occurs above the threshold of armed conflict  of the 
continuum of competition .  Warfighting takes place when the conflict has reached a point 
that the only way to change behaviour, attitude or resolve a contradiction is primarily 
through armed force.  Activity will be usually a series of  high-intensity engagements 
through one or more domains with effects created in all dimensions against a significant form of armed aggression perpetrated between one or more states, or a well -organiz ed 
and resourced non -state actor.  It is likely the enemy will combine unconventional and 
sub-threshold methods with their combat operations as part of an overall strategy.  As a 
result, the wider effects of armed conflict may be less bounded by traditional distinctions, 
such as the home base and theatre of operations. This theme will predominantly consist 
of combat and major crisis response operations.

must always consider the contribution each military element; agency, government 
department and Multi -National (MN) partner might play during an operation and work out 
how they will integrate each into the relevant area of their HQ.  The manner in which this is

alliance  approach’ ) can consist of  Combined, Joint, Interagency, Inter -Governmental & Multi -
National (CJIIM) actors working alongside each other.  A comprehensive approach aims to 
build closer links and liaisons with relevant organizations and actors, on a regular basis, 
while respecting the decision- making autonomy of each organization.  NATO sees its 
contribution to the  comprehensive approach  as having:  
• Shared Outcomes . To achieve shared outcomes all participants involved i n

risis resolution should think about the outcomes required to deliver a favourabl e

ituation.

ialogue and C ooperation.  Dialogue and cooperation requires all parties t o

istinctive Cultures of Different Agencies .  The joint force needs t o
ac
knowledge the distinctive cultures of different agencies it will be partnered with.

December 2000 was primarily about the GCC making the transition from co- operating on 
matters of defence to a position of collective self -defence.  Accordingly, member states 
agreed that external aggression against any member would be regarded as aggression against them all; that any threat facing one state would be regarded as a threat to all, and 
would necessitate various measures, including the use of military force, being taken to aid 
the victim of aggression.  The agreement also provided for the development of  a GCC 
Defence Council  and the Peninsula Shield Force , and for the enhancing of military 
cooperation by arranging joint military exercises, agreeing on defence policies, and augmenting the countries’ collective defence capacity by strengthening the local arms industry.   In addition, it was agreed that all collaborative activities would fall under the 
direction and supervision of the GCC’s Supreme Council  through its Defence Council’s 
High Military Committee, whose meetings are coordinated by the Assistant  Secretary  
General for Military Affairs.

hierarchically into formations, units and subunits and categorised by function, type and

8.5. Land Unit Hierarchy.  A typical hierarchy flows down from Army Group to Army , 
Corps , Division , Brigade, Unit and Sub-Unit. Formations and units are designed to be 
modular and scalable, so that elements can be easily added or taken away, and they can be 
expanded or contracted. The greatest capacity for this lies in corps and divisions.  
8.6. Functional groupings : Land forces are categorised functionally as either combat, 
combat support or combat service support force elements  
• Combat : force elements are those that engage the enemy directly. They manoeuvre 
and fight, typically employing direct fire weapons, to gain ground, find and defeat the 
enemy, or acquire information. They include armoured, reconnaissance, infantry, and 
attack and reconnaissance aviation units.   
• Combat Support  force elements provide operational assistance;  including fire and 
manoeuvre support to Combat force elements. They are: helicopters, artillery, 
combat engineers, intelligence, communications, command support and information 
ops specialists.   
• Combat Service S upport  is the organisational support provided to the whole force, 
primarily in the fields of administration, logistic , health service support , equipment 
support  & infrastructure . 
8.7. Force type .  Complementary to functional categorisation, land forces are also 
classified by their force type or specialist capability , commonly described in NATO as:  
•  Heavy - armoured vehicles that maximise firepower and protection, a compromise is 
made with operational and tactical mobility.  
• Medium  - equipped with armoured vehicles that are optimised for long range 
manoeuvre but still have some valuable protection and firepower . 
• Light  - dismounted light forces have limited firepower and intrinsic protection. Yet 
they can theoretically go anywhere that human beings can go –  into mountains, 
forests, marshes, buildings, caves or subterranean structures  
• ISR Forces; Air Manoeuvre Forces; Amphibious ; Mountain

organisation during operations increases flexibility.

action.  The components of this are:  
a. Shock action .   Shock action is the sudden, concentrated application of
violence on an enemy from an unexpected direction. It is the combined effect of
surprise, mobility and firepower concentrated in time and space. By attacking i n
s
trength at a weak spot at an unexpected moment and from an unexpected direction,
an armoured force can destroy large numbers of the enemy. Shock action c an
par
alyse the enemy, helping to seize the initiative. Shock action can be particularly
effective if it can be achieved at night or at a place that the enemy thinks is secure.Like surprise, the effects of shock action may be transient and local. It shoul
d be
ex
ploited vigorously.
b. Aggressive mobile action to destroy enemy armour .   Arguably the primary
component, tanks are there to kill enemy tanks.  The tank’s mobility, survivability,durability and flexibility combined with the firepower to destroy enemy armouraccurately whilst on the move, gives it the leading role in the des truction of enemy
armoured fighting vehicles and strong points during the advance and withdrawal.Above this level it should be noted that increasingly armour is being supplemented by
attack helicopters. Tanks provide the mobile element of the anti -armour plan i
n
def
ence and should be concentrated and used offensively in the support of the
positional element.
c. Close combat in conjunction with infantry.   The presence of main battl e
t
anks adds momentum, reduces casualties, significantly enhances direct precisi on
f
irepower as well as boosts friendly force morale. When considering the COE, armour
can be task organised in a more flexible manner and in smaller groupings (minimum
of a pair of tanks) to meet the specific mission/environmental requirements.
d. Surveillance, target acquisition & reconnaissance (STAR) . The sighti ng
s
ystems on armoured vehicles provide a protected, constant and all- weather STAR

b. Tank Employment Guidance: When employ ing armoured units, commanders  
must ensure that they use tanks aggressiv ely to exploit their full potential, particularly  
firepower and mobility.  The s hattering effect of armour against an enemy is  
maximised when tanks are c oncentrated, and therefore armour generally should be  
used in the greatest numbers possible (COE dependent), and employed on  
consecutive rather than concurrent tasks. Even in defens ive operations, the tank will  
be us ed offens ively to defeat an attacker. In offensiv e combined arms operations, it  
will normally be armour that takes the lead in the break-i n and exploitation of initial  
success handing over to infantry as necessary.  Due to these characteristics, tank 
organisations are the primary manoeuvre or strike arm.  Further planning factors  
include:
c. Real estate.   In an offensiv e role, tanks need sufficient manoeuvre space in  
order to use their mobility to best effect, which enhances surprise and protection.  In a 
defensive posture, dispersal assists survivability; the rule of thumb being 1 squadron / 
company = 1 km².
d. Signature (size, weight, noise, dust and thermal).   The presence of tanks is  
hard to conceal.  Effort, imagination, s pace, cover and skilful driving are required to  
minimise the chanc es of detection by  the enemy . The size, noise levels and  
presence, however, can be used to intimidate an adversary as a s how of strength or  
as part of a dec eption plan.
e. Close quarter fighting.   Armour is excellent at creating entry points, breaching 
obstac les, des troying s trong points, carrying combat supplies, protecting infantry , 
providing a communications platform, and providing devastating direct fire. However, 
at close quarters, armour has blind spots and can be vulnerable to dismounted 
advers aries. In close country (such as forests) or built-u p urban areas, armour is 
particularly v ulnerable due to high angle threats and restrictions to mobility, which 
result in channelling and restricted arcs.  To counter the constraints of fighting in 
urban or close country armour can be used to great effect if grouped as a minimum in 
pairs and combined with infantry.
f. Obstacles.   Natural and artificial obstacles can restrict armour’s mobility and if  
deliberately canalised, armour can become vulnerable and a tempting target to an  
advers ary’s  anti-t ank, air and aviation weaponry.  However, they may often be able to  
overcome obstacles with the use of an attached bulldozer blade, engineer bridges  
and the protection of infantry.
g. Ground holding capability.  Tank s can deny ground by  the application of fire,  
but they cannot, by themselves , hold ground agains t a determined dismounted  
enemy . This requires the intimate support of infantry.
h. Sustainment.   The logistic demands of fuel, oil, spares, and general  
maintenance for tanks are considerable. For example, the fuel used by  a British  
Challenger 2 squadron (18 tanks) operating across country for 1 day is 12,600 litres,  
requiring 3 x  fuel tankers.  In addition, whilst equipment is capable of operating 24  
hours per day, crews  are not. Sensible use of notice to move times is  essential to  
permit adequate crew rest, time for maintenance and battle procedure. Additional

9.1. Air Power .  Air power is defined as: the ability to use air capabilities  in and from the 
air, to influence the behaviour of actors and the course of events .  Air power is truly global in 
nature as it theoretically enables access to any point on Earth, be it over land or sea using 
its enduring attributes of height , speed and reach .  Air power offers policy makers an agile, 
timely and focussed capability that can be highly effective in resolving or averting a 
developing crisis.  The use of air power can also potentially negate the requirement to 
deploy a larger force over a broader timescale by land or sea.   
9.2. Space Power .  Space power is defined as: exerting influence in, from, or through, 
space. Like air power, the attributes of space power are related to the ability to exploit the 
vertical dimension.  The vast majority of military operations could not be sustained without  
space capabilities.  Operations  are dependent on space, principally for communications, 
meteorological, positioning, navigation and timing (PNT) functions, as well as for intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR).  
9.3. The Air Component .  The Air Component Headquarters (AC HQ) normally has an 
embedded Joint Air Operations Centre (JAOC), which may be static, or deployable 
depending on the nature and scale of joint air operations.  In a coalition setting this is becomes a Combined Air operations Centre (CAOC). The AC HQ and JAOC may be sea or 
land- based and even transition between locations should the situation dictate; for example, 
during the build- up and draw down phases of a joint campaign, or when his command & 
control ( C2) or command & control system ( C2S) capability is threatened. The 
responsibilities of the Air Component Commander (ACC) are assigned by the Joint Task 
Force Commander and usually include:  
•Developing a Joint Air Operations Plan (JAOP).
•Recommending apportionment of joint air assets to the JTFC.
•Allocating and tasking joint air assets based on the JTFC’s air apportionmentdecision.
•Overseeing, guiding, integrating and adjusting the execution of Joint Air operations incoordination with the JTFC and affected Component Commanders.
•Evaluating the results of Joint Air operations and forwarding assessments to the
JTFC to support the overall assessment effort.
•Providing and receiving appropriate liaison officers (LOs).
•Performing the duties of the airspace control authority (ACA).
•Performing the duties of the air defence commander (ADC).
•Functioning as a supported or supporting commander.
•The ACC may also be nominated as the Space Coordinating Authority (SCA).
9.4. Airspace Control Authority (ACA) .  The ACA has the overall responsibility for 
establishing and operating an appropriate airspace control system through an Airspace 
Control Plan (ACP). The ACP is developed in consultation with the JFC, the other 
components, and the HN where appropriate, in order to integrate, coordinate or deconflict all 
airspace user requirements.

10.5.  Structure .  The  principal formation for maritime forces is the Maritime Task Force.  
Each Task Force is assigned a commander  who may either report directly to the Maritime 
Component Commander (MCC)  or may be dually appointed as the MCC in which case he 
will report directly to the Commander of the Joint Task Force (CJTF) .  The Commander (of 
the) Task Force (CTF) may further subdivide the Task Force into Task Groups  and Task 
Units to exercise command and control at the tactical level.  Each of these sub- formations 
will be assigned a commander: a CTG will command a Task Group and a CTU will 
command a Task Unit.  These sub- formations  may be organise d based on capabilities, 
tasks , geography, or a combination of all three.   Each sub- formation will comprise a number 
of Task Elements (individual ships or submarines).  The 4 levels of maritime command are:  
• Task Force (TF)  – the ships and submarines that collectively comprise a 
discrete, usually multi -capability, maritime force with forces assigned to 
fulfil specific missions  and tasks  as part of the force generation process .  
• Task  Group (TG)  – the ships and / or submarines that comprise a task or 
capability -oriented formation within a Task Force.  
• Task Unit (TU)  – the ships and / or submarines allocated a specific task or 
role from within a Task Group.  
• Task Element (TE)  – individual ships or submarines allocated to a Task 
Force.  
 
 
10.6.  The Maritime Task Force.  Figure 10.2 shows a representative Maritime Task 
Force (TF 333).  TF 333 comprises 4 Task Groups:  an Amphibious Group to project power 
ashore and a Carrier Group  to deliver Carrier Strike in  both the counter -sea and counter -land

prepare the landing ground for the Amphibious Group and to clear choke points of mines.

Control .  This is not the only way in which a task force can be put together and it assumes 
that CJTF has delegated Operational Control (OPCON) of the individual platforms to the

10.7.  Escorts and Logistic Shipping .  Within TF 333, t he escorts are included as a 
single Task Unit within the Carrier Group to  provide both Above Water and Anti -submarine

the Escorts TU to provide cover for the Advance Force and to the Amphibious Group, in

would be ‘detached’ from the Logistic Shipping TU and ‘attached’ to support these

10.13.  Task Force.  Because, by definition, a maritime Task Force is an organisation 
created for a particular operation, it will be assigned a unique number for that  operation. 
United Kingdom, United States and NATO -led coalitions tend to use a 3-figure number such

10.14.  Task Group.  Within a particular Task Force, its Task Groups will be sequentially  
numbered taking the number of the parent formation and separating the sub- formations  by a 
decimal point.   The Task Groups in Task Force 333 will therefore be  numbered 333.1 
onwards.  
10.15.  Task Units .  Task Units will take the number of the parent Task Group, say  Task 
Group 333.1, and follow a similar process. Within Task Group 333.1, the Task Units will be 
numbered 333.1.1, 333.1.2 etc.  
10.16.  Task Elements.  Each Task Element will have its own unique number assigned 
following a similar process so that the ships within Task Unit 333.1.1 will be sequentially 
numbered 333.1.1.1, 333.1.1.2 and so on. Once a ship or  submarine has been assigned a 
number as a Task Element with a Task Force,  this number will not change regardless of 
subsequent tasking.  
10.17.  Levels of Command.  Not every ship will be assigned to a Task Unit or even to a 
Task  Group.  In the Task Force 333 example, the submarines are part of Task Group 333.4 
but are not assigned to a Task Unit.

Commander and not the MCC.  Organic helicopters in the escorts remain under the tasking 
authority of the MCC through his subordinate commanders.  In reality, only a proportion of the carrier -borne aircraft would be assigned to the joint air planning process; the remainder 
remaining under the OPCON of the MCC.

11.1.  The Logistic Component ( LogC ).  A LogC  provides the focal point for logistic 
support and optimum means of controlling logistic assets spread across components.  While 
component logistics are focused forward  to deployed units , the LogC  not only looks forward 
to provide logistic support to them , but also looks back to monitor the logistic activities of the 
strategic base.  A LogC  is likely to be deployed when the scale or complexity of the 
operation exceeds the capacity of JTFHQ J1/J4 staff.  The LogC  undertakes the more 
practical aspects of operational and tactical logistics, allowing JTFHQ J1/J4 staff to 
concentrate on critical campaign logistic factors.  
11.2.  Role .  The LogC  delivers coherent support to the JTF by taking responsibility for 
activities of benefit to 2 or more components, coordination between components and the 
appropriate use of their logistic resources.  The LogC  will be responsible for the RSOM 
element of Reception, Staging, Onward Movement and Integration (RSOI).  It will assist in 
the integration process , but this is a J3- led activity.  The LogC  will sustain the RSOI 
operation.   It controls the theatre end of the coupling bridge and ensures that stocks arrive in 
theatre and are distributed in accordance with the JTFC’s priorities.  A LogC  is not 
responsible for the detailed management of component logistics but does exercise a 
coordinating function to ensure that the JTFC’s priorities are met.  A LogC  may be allocated 
a specified Area of Operations, for which it has force protection and other responsibilities.   If 
this is not the case, close liaison with the headquarters performing this function is necessary. 
The specific LogC  responsibilities are to:  
•Command all logistic assets assigned to the LogC  in the JOA.  It contributes to the
JTFHQ estimate process and liaises with coalition partners, deployed contractors
and the host nation.
•Coordinate in- theatre logistic support, in accordance with the JTFC’s priorities,
through activation and maintenance of robust lines of communication.  Components
retain command of their integral logistic assets, unless otherwise directed by theJTFC. However, to maximise efficiency, the LogC  is normally given coordinati
ng
aut
hority.

Operating Picture.

1.9. NATO produce similar but slightly different version of the UK P rinciples of War.  
These are called the Principles of Joint and Multinational Operations.  They  are equivalent to, 
and closely aligned with, the UK  principles of war , however , there are some variances due to 
different emphases.  
The 12 Principles of Joint and Multinational Operations (AJP -01 Para 3.69)  
Unity of Effort.  Unity of effort emphasizes the requirement to ensure all means are 
directed to a common goal. Military forces achieve this principally through unity of 
command. As part of a comprehensive approach, unity of effort binds all the parts of the 
coalition together whilst retaining the benefit of diverse perspectives and approaches. It 
enables the integration and convergence of effects horizontally, across the Alliance and 
partners, and vertically, through the strategic, operational and tactical levels of operations. 
To achieve such unity of effort, it is essential to plan, communicate and coordinate at all 
levels and with all actors  involved in NATO activities and operations. It will require a 
flexible approach towards establishing shared objectives amongst NATO, partners, 
international organizations, non -governmental organizations, private sector and other 
stakeholders, based on the principles of civil- military interaction . 
Definition of objectives . Operations must be focused towards clearly defined and 
commonly understood objectives that contribute to attaining the end state. Understanding 
is central to providing insight and foresight to define effective objectives. Objectives must 
maintain the legal and moral legitimacy of a campaign and the force. To ensure strategic 
coherence the military instrument must be used proportionately and discriminately in 
relation to other instru ments of power with an understanding that negative actions can 
have serious political and strategic effects. By correctly selecting and defining objectives, 
it focuses the force on what is achievable and decisive, thereby supporting the principles 
of unity  of effort, freedom of action, concentration and economy of effort.  
Maintenance of morale.  All forms of competition are human activity, with psychology 
being key to success and failure. Maintenance of morale provides the will to fight. High 
morale is derived from fighting power and is characterized by steadfastness, courage, 
confidence and sustained hope. Morale manifests itself as will and resolve, which will 
drive the force to successfully achieve its objectives. It requires confidence in the 
superiority of information and equipment, inspiring leadership, tight cohesion and is 
sustained by the belief that the nation supports the force. It also demands freedom of 
action, taking and retaining the initiative, and controlling the narrative.  
Initiative.  Competition involves the interplay between initiative and response. Achieving 
objectives demands dictating the course of events in a competitive situation. To hold the 
initiative is the ability to set or dictate the terms of action throughout the operation. 
Maintaining the initiative results in relentless cognitive pressure on the adversary, 
degrading their morale and decision- making. Furthermore, it forces the adversary to 
respond by trying to protect themselves; such a reactive posture is dif ficult to recover from 
and usually leads to defeat. Gaining the initiative requires relentless determination to succeed and an ability to impose one’s will on the adversary, to do the unexpected and 
achieve surprise and delegate the freedom of action for s ubordinates to exploit 
opportunities. Initiative is dependent on the other principles being applied in unison.

riginal MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 6 – May 2025 Freedom of action .  Freedom of action is minimizing restrictions to enable a subordinate 
to use their skill, knowledge, experience, creativity and judgement to achieve their 
objectives. Freedom of action requires a disciplined offensive spirt and it enables the 
flexibility fo r subordinate commanders to make timely decisions within the context of their 
higher commander’s intent. Rather than constantly awaiting further orders, freedom of action is a precondition for successfully maintaining and exploiting the initiative. Freedom  
of action across all levels of command allows the force to adapt quicker to a rapidly 
changing operating environment, and to deal with unforeseen problems that are inherent 
in operations. Training, mutual trust and understanding, simple plans and clear, c oncise 
orders allows commanders to delegate the maximum freedom of action in line with their subordinates’ ability and the context of the mission. 
Offensive spirit .  Offensive spirit delivers the benefits inferred by purposeful action rather 
than inaction. Offensive spirit implies an incisive approach, with a willingness to understand and accept political and military risk, to seize, maintain and exploit the 
initiative  in line with one’s freedom of action. Critically, offensive spirt does not preclude 
defensive action. Central to offensive spirt is maintenance of morale and definition of objectives.  
Concentration.  In an increasingly transparent and lethal operating environment it is ever 
more difficult to maintain security and survival. Concentration is therefore not synonymous 
with the physical massing of forces for a decisive action, but concentration of effects created from a dispersed force. Integrating and coordinating actions across the 
operational domains in concert with allies and partners will achieve mass. Through 
concentration of actions and effects, it is possible to affect a rival’s capac ity for decision -
making through imposing multiple dilemmas, gaining the initiative and achieving objectives, whilst also maximizing economy of effort. Effective concentration demands 
unity of effort, definition of objectives and the ability to sustain the mass.  
Economy of Effort .  Concentration must be delivered economically and precisely, 
targeting the right objects in the right space at the right time with the appropriate 
resources. Of all the principles, it is the most difficult to apply due to its close interdependence with t he ever -changing conditions of the operating environment. 
Precision in the definition of objectives, surprise and security prevents wasted resource 
and effort by allowing the concentration of effort to be on what is decisive  
Security.  Security limits vulnerability to hostile activities, threats and surprise. It is a 
shield that can help conserve fighting power and affords the initiative and freedom of 
action, when and where required, to achieve objectives. It requires unity of effort, 
understanding the points of influence, particularly vulnerabilities, risk management and 
resilience.  
Security contributes to preparedness but does not demand  over-committing resources to 
guard against every threat or possibility, thereby diminishing relative fighting power.  
Lack of security, or a false interpretation of the principle of security, leads directly to being surprised and loss of initiative. Commanders should anticipate the effects of being surprised and make appropriate contingency plans to safeguard their freedom of action.

riginal MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 6 – May 2025 Surprise.  Surprise, achieved through unexpected actions, achieves a cognitive effect – a 
feeling of relative confusion, or perhaps shock – that can undermine the adversary’s 
cohesion and morale. Using surprise is a significant way of seizing the initiative and may 
be a critical  pre-condition for success. It is transient and must be exploited rapidly. 
Deception is closely related to surprise and requires deliberate measures to mislead targeted decision- makers into behaving in a manner advantageous to the achievement of 
one’s objective. Surprise is also dependent on security. 
Flexibility .  A flexible force is one that has the ability to be highly responsive to changing 
circumstances. Plans and procedures should be sufficiently flexible to respond to the 
unexpected and they should empower commanders with maximum freedom of action. 
This allows the force to adapt to a situation and learn lessons more quickly than a rival, 
thereby gaining the initiative. Flexibility is enabled by a clear definition of objectives, 
freedom of action and sustainability.  
Sustainability.  Operations are demanding and often brutal and visceral, placing extreme 
physical and psychological demands on personnel and requiring the constant care of people and equipment. A force that lacks sustainability and resilience is rarely successful. 
Personnel, equipment, systems and effects must be sustained and maintained to prevent 
culmination and to maintain resilience. The ability to generate and re -generate, avoiding 
shortages and waste, maintains a commander’s flexibility and freedom of  action to

1.14.  Narrative- led Execution. Every action creates an informational effect and, via the

The Manoeuvrist  Approach (JDP 0 -01) 
1.15.  Overview .  The manoeuvrist approach is one in which shattering the enemy’s overall 
cohesion and will to fight is paramount, rather than just destroying his forces and equipment.  
It is an indirect approach which emphasises targeting the enemy’s moral component of his 
fighting power rather than the physical.  Central to the concept is the need to seize, retain and exploit the initiative.  This approach is most effective when it is used in conjunction with 
mission command.  The manoeuvrist approach aims to apply strength against identified 
vulnerabilities , to induce shock, through surprise, shock action, and destruction, leading to 
an enemy’s collapse, which is followed by friendly force exploitation.   
1.16.  Requirements.  The Manoeuvrist Approach, enabled by Mission Command, has two 
specific requirements: an attitude of mind and understanding of the enemy’s vulnerabilities.

unexpected action in time, location and operational domain.  
o Simultaneity. Simultaneity seeks to overload the decision- making of actors 
and stakeholders by confronting them with a concentration of simultaneous threats, which is achieved through the integration and synchronization of actions and effects.

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 6 – May 2025 1.22.  Mission Command Principles . The following principles provide a continuous cycle 
of unity of effort, timely and effective decision- making, and decentralized execution:  
• Unity of effort . To achieve unity of effort, it is essential to plan, communicate and 
coordinate at all levels and with all actors involved in a comprehensive approach to crisis. 
Achieving unity of effort is often complicated by the variety of international military and 
non-military actors involved, the lack of command -and-control  arrangements between 
them, and varying views of the objectives or end state. Some international organizations 
and non- governmental organizations may refuse to cooperate directly w ith military forces. 
This will require a flexible approach towards establishing processes or bodies to share 
information between the involved international organizations a  
• Timely and effective decision -making. Successful command requires timely and 
effective decision- making at all levels. Mission command empowers subordinate 
commanders, who are best placed to make decisions, the authority to do so. Timely 
decisions allow the Alliance’s forces to gain and maintain the initiative .  Developing an 
intuitive understanding of when to decide is as integral a component of the art of 
command as knowing from where to command. The essential elements to any decision-
making process are detailed in Allied Joint Publication (AJP) -3, Allied Joint  Doctrine for 
the Conduct of Operations.  
• Decentralized execution. Decentralized execution enables subordinates the 
freedom of action to act independently, which enables agility in changing situations and 
the ability to exploit opportunities in accordance with their overall objective. C ommanders 
must delegate the maximum freedom of action in line with their subordinates’ ability. This 
is affected by a commander's style of command. Where control measures are 
established, these have a role in reducing the complementary need for direct comm and 
style. If control measures are  ambiguous, weak or absent, more direct command is 
inevitably required. These control measures only specify how a mission will be executed if 
there are political, legal or military restraints, to enable coordination and synchronization 
of actions on the objective. Decentralized execution depends upon:  
o commanders ensuring that their subordinates understand the intent, their own 
contributions and the context including the narrative within which they are to act;  
o commanders exercising minimum control over their subordinates, consistent 
with the context and nature of the mission, and the subordinates’ experience and ability, while retaining responsibility for their actions;  
o subordinates having a sound understanding of the overall plan, what objective 
they are contributing to, the effect they are to create, and why;  
o subordinates being allocated sufficient resources to carry out their missions, 
and subordinates deciding for themselves how best to act on their superior’s intent, 
including where and how to establish their main effort and what risks to take;  
o subordinates communicating their plan to the commander to ensure 
situational awareness; and 
o subordinates having the willingness to accept the trust placed in them, and 
the initiative to act within any freedom of action given.

1.25.  The Functional Framework is also known as the Tactical Framework in UK Land 
Doctrine .  The Functional Framework takes the 4 core functions of manoeuvre and provides 
a framework for a scheme of manoeuvre :

• Fix (To gain freedom of action, a commander must deny the enemy the opportunity

scope of an engagement beyond its original objective.)

employing actions. In this framework, deep and rear operations are defined by the close operational engagement space around the joint force. The geographic framework is: 
• Deep (The purpose of deep operations is to fracture the cohesion of an opponent 
and establish an advantage before conducting close operations . Examples are 
Information Activities , ISTAR, Fires, Deep manoeuvre and they will invariably require 
close coordination with all  components of a joint force. ) 
• Close (Close operations occur at short range,  their effects are immediate and 
tangible.  Close operations occur once the conditions for success have been set by

• Rear (Rear operations ensure freedom of action by protecting and sustaining a force. 
They also maintain freedom of action for uncommitted forces. Although rear 
operations include administration, logistics and protection, their effect is much wider; 
within the overall scheme of manoeuvre, they create the conditions for successful 
deep and close operations. )

JOA effectively by shattering their cohesion rather than destroying each of his components through incremental attrition.

Internal Waters  Covers all of the waters on the landward side of the baseline. The state is 
responsible for setting laws and governing their use.  
Territorial 
Seas/waters  From the baseline to a limit not exceeding 12 nautical miles. The state is 
responsible for setting laws and governing their use, subject to the right of 
vessels from other states exercising the right of innocent, or in international 
straits, transit passage.  
Contiguous Zone  A zone that may not exceed 24 nautical miles  from the base line,  in which a 
state can intervene to prevent potential offences which may otherwise occur 
inside territorial waters, or to apprehend a vessel that has committed an offence 
inside territorial waters and is attempting to escape.  
Exclusive 
Economic Zone 
(EEZ)  This area extends up to 200 nautical miles from the baseline. Within this area a 
state has sole claim over all natural resources. This includes exploiting 
resources such as oil, gas and fishing. Other states enjoy high seas freedoms in 
the EEZ, provided these activities do not impact on the coastal state’s rights and 
jurisdictions in the EEZ as set out in UNCLOS.  
Continental Shelf  The continental shelf of a coastal state comprises the seabed and subsoil of the 
submarine areas that extend beyond its territorial sea throughout the natural prolongation of its land territory to the outer edge of the continental margin, or to 
a distance of 200 nautical miles from the baseline.  
High Seas  The high seas are open to all states who may enjoy the freedom of the high seas 
subject only to the conditions described in UNCLOS/customary law.  Vessels on 
the high seas are subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of their flag states, with a 
few very important exceptions: for example, piracy is a crime of  universal 
jurisdiction.

PRINCIPLES AND APPLICATIONS OF MARITIME POWER  
2.13.  The strategic use of maritime power is made possible through the concept of sea 
control and underpinned by the principles of maritime manoeuvre and maritime power 
projection. These are supported by a number of operational approaches. (Para 3.25)  
2.14.  Sea Control .  The concept of ‘ sea control’ , is where a maritime force establishes the 
conditions to allow freedom of action in a particular part of the sea, at a particular time, to the required degree and, if necessary, deny its use to an opponent.  Sea control requires control 
of the surface and  subsurface environments (including the seabed), the air above the area in 
which sea control is required, the electromagnetic environment and potentially areas of the land where that part of the land dominates the sea. (Para 3.26)  
2.15.  Levels of Sea Control .  The level of sea control required, and indeed achievable, 
will depend upon the threat and the mission. Where sea control is not contested the force has achieved it by default and can focus on delivering maritime manoeuvre or maritime 
power projection. I f there is any risk to freedom of action, sea control is necessary; however, 
if the risk is small, the capabilities required can be correspondingly modest. Gaining the necessary level of sea control early, and retaining it, will be a major component of any maritime or expeditionary operation.  (Para 3.27)  
2.16.  Sea Control Operational Approaches .  Where sea control is necessary it can be 
achieved through one of a number of operational approaches. (from Para 3.28)  
a. Decisive Battle.  While a successful decisive battle at sea, where maritim e
f
orces classically oppose each other is exceedingly rare in the modern era, a decisiv e
engagem
ent is not.  A singular act can provide sea control.
b. Sea Denial .  Sea denial is a form of anti -access and area denial exercised w hen
one par
ty prevents an adversary from controlling a maritime area without being able to
control that area oneself. It can be a tool for a superior maritime force, either in a
secondary area of operations, or for one phase of a larger campaign. Classic means of
achieving sea denial include laying a minefield or deploying submarines to threat en
enem
y surface forces. A more recent method, particularly appropriate in littoral
operati ons, is to project land assets such as surface- to-surface missile batteries al ong
t
he coast to pose an unacceptable level of risk to maritime units.
c. Fleet -in-being .  A state deprived of maritime superiority might choose, or  be
f
orced, to adopt a strategy of fleet -in-being.  By avoiding confrontation with  a superior
enemy a state can hold back its own maritime forces but continue to threaten those of
the enemy or their ability to carry out their mission.
d. Blockade.  This allows the presence of a stronger maritime power to contai n an
adv
ersary reluctant to fight, or force a decisive battle on them.
2.17.  Maritime Manoeuvre.  Sea control and the legal framework which allows 
unrestricted access and presence no closer than 12 nautical miles from the baseline in 
peacetime is a key enabler for maritime manoeuvre.  The ability to operate, particularly in 
littoral areas, is of cru cial importance, either as the main effort or as the staging area for 
deploying and sustaining ground forces.  Therefore, as well as the central requirement to be 
capable of controlling events at sea, maritime power must also be capable of influencing 
events on land from the sea. (from Para 3.30)  
2.18.  Maritime Power Projection.  Maritime power projection is the threat, or use, of 
national power from the sea to influence events. It exploits sea control and maritime

state.  A state reassured by the presence of maritime forces is more likely to provide 
access, basing and overflight.  
c. Deter .  Maritime forces can be used to deter an aggressor by deploying into a 
region at an early stage, at relatively low political risk and, if necessary, in considerable strength.  
d. Coerce.   As maritime forces build up in theatre, they can launch discrete 
amounts of mixed land, air, or maritime power against key targets to force an 
adversary away from one course of action or to compel them to take another.  
e. Disrupt .  Prior to the main offensive, maritime forces can help to shift the 
emphasis from defensive to offensive operations by disrupting enemy activity through 
the use of amphibious raids  
f. Project .  An important role of maritime forces, particularly amphibious forces, is 
to provide manoeuvre from the sea.  Speed of manoeuvre at sea will often surprise opponents ashore.  
g. Support .  The maritime component’s capabilities, in particular its ability to 
engage in precision attack, can support friendly forces ashore or in the air.  Additionally, the sea base may be used to hold a reserve force or serve as a command 
platform.  
h. Limit .  Maritime forces can guard the maritime flanks of an operating area and 
by doing so, limit the freedom of manoeuvre of an enemy.  
i. Recover .  When it comes to withdrawal, maritime forces have the capability to 
transport large numbers of personnel and equipment out of theatre whilst protecting 
them in the process.  They may also remain in theatre to provide a strategic reserve.

3.1. This is a summary of the key ideas and doctrinal elements of JDP 0 -20 Ed 6 Land

3.2. What is Land Power?  Land power is defined as: “ the ability of land forces to exert 
decisive control and influence on actors and the course of events.” ( JDP 0 -20 Para 1. 2) 
3.3. Aspects of the Land Environment .  The land environment  is inherently complex and  
is shaped primarily by the following 3 aspects. (JDP 0 -20 from Para 2.6) 
•Physical aspects .  The land environment  is varied and complex. It includes  open
gr
assland, cultivated land, forests, mountains, deserts, jungles, rivers, swamps, urban
and littoral areas.  Each creates constraints and freedoms, placing different demands
on the people and equipment that operate within them.
•Human aspects. Within the land environment , people inhabit towns, cities and
v
illages, whilst even apparently unpopulated space often contains resources that
support humans in some way. Control over land is consequently of fundamentalpolitical, cultural and psychological importance, and has often  been regarded as
decisive in conflict.
•Information aspects.  The Land environment  is shaped by the way that populations
interact; it is the exchange of information between individuals, tribes, ethnic
 and
i
nterest groups, and countries that lie at the heart of human dynamics.  This
communication can be verbal, written or visual and it can be conducted directly
between people or through radio, television or online.  Human interaction is expandi ng
and ac
celerating as information flows in the virtual domain increase, linking individuals,
groups and societies globally, unconfined by traditional state boundaries.
Unlike the air or maritime environments , Land  is distinguished by the fact that it is where 
people predominantly live. It is in the land environment that the roots of conflict are usually 
found, since conflict on land involves those things that people tend to value most: their lives, 
values, property and resources.  
3.4. The Attribute of Land Forces.   All land forces, regular or irregular, have four inherent 
attributes.  Each attribute has advantages that can be used, but also disadvantages that have to be avoided or mitigated.  (JDP 0 -20 Para1.7 and Ch 3) . 
•Soldiers – Land forces rely on human initiative, enterprise & intelligence.
•Presence – Land  is where people predominantly live & the roots of conflict are found
•Persistence –capacity to endur e in an area for long periods of time .
•Adaptability  – the ability to conduct a wide range of military and non -military tasks.
Land power is critically dependent on the other operational domains for support. This 
dependency limits the speed and scale of deployment and the degree to which land forces are 
strategically mobile. This can be offset somewhat by persistent presence and adaptability, but this approach is costly.  
3.5. The Purpose of Land Forces. (ADP Land Ops 2 from Para 3- 01) “The core purpose 
of land forces is the defeat of opposing land forces in armed conflict ”. 
3.6. The Critical Capability of Land Forces.   (ADP Land Ops 1 from Para 3- 13) “The 
critical capability of land forces is the ability  to plan and execute combined arms manoeuvre. 
Force and land forces achieve political objectives. The application and threat of force, and the 
gaining and retention of physical objectives, affect political decision- making in ways  
consistent with those objectives.

3.10.  Combined Arms Approach.   The combined arms approach is how land forces 
orchestrate effects in land tactical operations by combining forces and capabilities, both lethal 
and non- lethal, to overmatch an opponent. It is defined as:  
“The synchronised and simultaneous application of forces and capabilities across domains to 
achieve an effect greater than if each element was used separately or sequentially ”.  
Through task organisation, it reinforces strengths  and compensates for weakness through 
complementary grouping. It also imposes  dilemmas on opponents by confronting them with 
multiple threats; forces are task  organised so that if the opponent attempts to protect against 
one threat, they become  vulnerable in another.   It includes the forces and capabilities of all 
army, joint, and multinational elements across the tactical functions.

for offensive, defensive or stability activities. Enabling activities are:

Purpose  
The purpose of exploitation  is to disorganise the enemy in depth and usually follows a successful 
attack. It is characterised by a rapid advance against lessening resistance and its effects are both 
physical and psychological.    
The purpose of a pursuit . The pursuit seeks to catch or cut off an enemy who fears envelopment 
and who is demoralised and beginning to disintegrate under pressure.

4.1. This summary is taken from JDP 0- 30 UK Air Power  3rd Ed (2022) and AP3002 Air 
Warfare 5th Ed (Sep 2023). 
4.2. What is Air Power ? The fundamental purpose of military air power is achieving 
mastery of the  air.  Air power is  defined as: “ the ability to use air capabilities in and from the 
air, to influence the behaviour of actors and the course of events .” (JDP 0 -30 Para 1. 2) 
4.3. Fundamental Characteristics of  Air Power . (JDP 0 -30 from Para 1.4) 
•Height –enables aviators to observe, and deliver, activities in the land and maritime
environments .
•Speed – enables the rapid and responsive projection of power .
•Reach – enables adversaries to be influenced, regardless of their location.
While height, speed and reach represent core air power characteristics in their own right, 
they act together synergistically to produce additional characteristics:  
•Agility – a blend of responsiveness, adaptability, flexibility and resilience using multi-
role & multi- mission capabilities .
•Ubiquity  – Height, speed and reach, combined with the agility of air  capabilities,
provide air power with ubiquity .
•Concentration - concentrate military force in time and space, when and where it is
required.
4.4. The Air Environment .  The air environment is an unforgiving one and, thus, aircraft 
are designed to meet the challenges of operating at a variety of altitudes, temperature extremes and speed ranges . 
4.5. Limitations of Air Power . (JDP 0 -30 from Para 1.10 ) 
•Impermanence.  Aircraft cannot yet stay airborne indefinitely. Although the use of
air-to-air refuelling can extend the range and endurance of aircraft.
•Limited payload . The payloads that can be carried by aircraft are limited i
n
c
omparison with ships or land vehicles .
•Fragility . Structurally, aircraft are highly stressed and built to be as light as
practicable, carrying little or no armour protection; thus, relatively low levels  of battl e
dam
age may have a catastrophic effect .
•Cost .  Many military aircraft use cutting- edge technology, which, inevitably, comes at
significant financial cost .
•Basing and overflight .  All forms of military power depend on basing, support  and
pr
otection; aircraft are no exception .
•Weather .  Poor weather may still create some difficulties, but modern technology means
that the majority of military aircraft can now operate in all light conditions, day and night,
regardless of weather conditions .
4.
6. Manned / Crewed Aircraft .  Crewed  combat aircraft are categorised according to 
their ‘generation’ which broadly reflects their capabilities. A generational shift in combat 
aircraft occurs when a technological innovation cannot be incorporated into an existing 
aircraft through upgrade. Although there are currently five broadly accepted generations, 
most NATO air forces are equipped with fourth and fifth generation aircraft.  
•Third Generation .  Third generation aircraft form the bulk of most non- western air
forces, originally entering service during the 1970s and 1980s.  These were multi -role
ai
rcraft  capable of supersonic flight and engaging targets beyond visual range.  This
generation includes the Mig- 27 Flogger and Mirage III.
•Fourth Generation .  Fourth generation aircraft are those designed to bridge the  gap
bet
ween the developments of the 1970s and those entering service after 2000.

weaponry. This generation includes the Typhoon, F -15 Eagle, Mig- 29 Fulcrum and 
Su-27 Flanker.  
• Fifth Generation .  Fifth generation aircraft combine new developments such as 
composite materials, low observable technology, advanced electronically scanned 
radars and sensor fusion to greatly improve pilot situational awareness. This

4.7. Unmanned Aircraft .  An unmanned  aircraft is an aircraft that does not carry a 
human operator and is operated remotely using varying levels of automated functions. Unmanned aircraft can be expendable or recoverable, they may carry a lethal or non- lethal 
payload.  Cruise missiles are not considered unmanned aircraft.   Due to the lack of a 
requirement to accommodate a human being, unmanned aircraft can be significantly smaller 
than manned aircraft, thus the range of sizes can be greater than that of manned a ircraft. 
Unmanned aircraft are  categorised as follows:  
• Class One (Less than 150kg) - includes three sub classifications -  Micro, Mini and

The f our fundamental air power roles are: 
• Control of the Air  (Counter Air).  
• Attack.  
• Intelligence, Surveillance & 
Reconnaissance.  
• Air Mobility . 
These four roles can be conducted in 
isolation, combined or, more usually, as

deliver each of the four air power roles is 
dependent on critical enablers: base;

CONTROL OF THE AIR - Secures our joint freedom of manoeuvre.  
4.10.  Terminology. Operationally, control of the air is achieved via 
counter -air operations; a term that is also used by NATO and the United 
States Air Force to describe the over -arching air power role.  
4.11.  Control of the Air Definition : “freedom, over a given period of 
time, to use a volume of airspace for our own purposes while, if necessary, denying or 
constraining its use by an opponent” .  (AP3002 Para  501). 
4.12.  Purpose:   Control of the air is the most important air power role because it secures  
our joint freedom of manoeuvre.  At the operational level, it assures military freedom of 
manoeuvre in the air, land or maritime domains. This allows our commanders to seize the 
initiative while denying it to an adversary.  The breakdown of control of the air is depicted in 
Figure 5.2 below.   
4.13.  Degrees of Control of the Air :  NATO recognises three  levels of control:   
• Air parity . Air parity exists where no force enjoys decisive control of the air in either 
time or space. Consequently, both friendly and adversary land, maritime and air 
forces may encounter significant interference by the opposing force.  
• Air Superiority : That degree of dominance in the air battle of one force over another, 
which permits the conduct of operations by the former, and its related maritime, land 
and air forces at a given time and place, without prohibitive interference by the 
opposing force.   
• Air Supremacy:  The degree of air superiority where the opposing air force is 
incapable of effective interference.  It is important to note that even air supremacy 
cannot guarantee that an adversary will not inflict some damage or losses, 
particularly given the extensive proliferation of small arms weapons and man-
portable air defences. This is normally the highest level of control of the air that a 
joint force can achieve. (JDP 0 -30 Para 2.3 a, b & c).

5.1. This summary is taken from JDP 0- 40 UK Space Power  1st Ed (2022)   
5.2. What is Space?  There is no agreement under international law as to the altitude at 
which airspace ends and outer space begins. From a practical perspective, outer space (the 
final frontier! !) begins  ‘above the highest altitude at which an aircraft can fly and below the 
lowest possible perigee of a satellite in orbit’.   This point is commonly known as the Kármán 
Line: a height approximately 100 kilometres above mean sea level, above which the 
atmosphere becomes too thin for an aircraft to generate conventional lift without needing to 
exceed the speed required to achieve orbit. Thus, for practical purposes, anything in orbit or 
beyond can safely be regarded as being in space.  
5.3. Space as an Operational Domain.   Space is contested by both state and non- state 
actors. It is subject to expanding commercial competition and is congested by a growing 
volume of satellites and debris. Increasing reliance on space, identified vulnerabilities and 
the perception of challenge in space necessitated it  to be considered an operational domain.  
5.4. What is Space Power ?  Space power is defined as: “exerting influence in, from, or 
through, space. ” (JDP 0 -40 Para 1. 3) 
5.5. Attributes  of the Space Domain . (JDP 0 -40 from Para 1.5) 
• Congested.   Traditionally, the use and exploration of space was only undertaken by 
the major powers. In recent times, the lowering of technological the traditional 
barriers and costs have trigger ed commercial expansion into space on an 
unparalleled scale.  
• Complex .  The blurring of the lines between civilian and military, government and 
commercial has drastically increased complexity in space.  
• Critical .  Technological advances, underpinned by increasingly widespread 
commercial or dual -use space capabilities, have imperceptibly permeated society 
and popular culture to such an extent that they are now almost indispensable, but 
they are nonetheless taken almost completely for granted.  – eg GPS.  
• Contested.  Many adversaries have space programmes themselves  and can source 
capabilities commercially or have at least identified space to be a critical vulnerability . 
5.6. Aspects of the Space Domain .  It should be stressed that the following aspects 
cannot be taken in isolation: each affects and relies on the others.   (JDP 0 -40 from Para 1.7) 
• Political Aspects : 
o Diplomatic .  To supports the growth of a commercial space sector . 
o International Negotiations . To prevent an arms race in space  
o Legal .  The international legal framework for space is the Outer Space Treaty . 
• Military Aspects.  Most  military operations could not be sustained without space 
capabilities .  Operations depend on space, principally for communications; 
meteorological; positioning, navigation and timing functions; intelligence, surveillance 
and reconnaissance; and the ability to operate remotely piloted aircraft at range.  
• Economic Aspects.   A thriving commercial space sector is valuable to Defence both 
for developing innovative projects that offer the potential of delivering decisive 
military advantage but also to reduce the costs and increase the capacity and 
availability of existing systems . 
• Social Aspects.   All modern states, depends on space services for day ‑to‑day 
societal functions such as enabling banking transactions, the effective operation of 
the national power grid and the use of smartphones. However, the public are often unaware of this, or take assured access for granted, making it difficult to 
acknowledge our reliance on freedom of access to the space environment.  
• Information Aspects.   The free flow of data and seamless functioning of networks 
are critical for space functions, both for control signals and the operation of payloads.

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 5 – Apr 2024 • Infrastructure Aspects.   Space operations are separated into three segments to aid 
understanding of the space system . 
o Space segment . The space segment comprises elements of the space 
system in outer space itself .  There are t wo basic systems: the spacecraft 
itself and the payloads it carries. This differentiation is important as the two 
can have different software, systems, ground segment elements and tasking 
chains.  
o Ground segment . The ground segment comprises terrestrial facilities that 
are used to launch, direct and control satellites as well as operate their 
payloads.  
o Link segment . The link segment connects the space and ground segments 
and comprises both the data itself and the medium used to carry it.  
• Physical Environment Aspects .  The environment encountered by a spacecraft on 
orbit can be extremely harsh, given it lacks the protection afforded terrestrial domains 
by the Earth’s atmosphere.   Three areas:  
o Orbits and orbital mechanics.  
o The space environment . Temperature, magnetic fields & vacuum.  
o Space Debris .  Tens of thousands of objects in orbit >  10cm  = impacts . 
o Space Weather .  The sun’s activity causes solar flares, coronal mass 
ejections and radiation storms.  
o Time .  Every satellite launched has a finite operational lifetime based on the 
fuel it carries and which it needs to operate its systems and manoeuvre to 
maintain the orbit parameters it is launched on . 
5.7. Characteristics of Space Power . (JDP 0 -40 from Para 1.19) 
• Perspective . As with the air domain, space capabilities exploit the vertical 
dimension, albeit to a completely different order of magnitude.  
• Access. The international rules and norms governing overflight of sovereign states by aircraft do not apply to satellites; space offers unrivalled access to any point on 
Earth, with no requirement to adhere to national boundaries.  
• 
Persistence. Typically, the orbital life expectancy of satellites is measured in years or 
even decades, so they can overcome the air power limitation of impermanence.  
• Versatility. Space assets are versatile because a single platform can carry a 
multitude of sensors and capabilities to provide services simultaneously to multiple 
users.  
5.8. Limitations of Space Power . (JDP 0 -40 from Para 1. 20) 
• Cost . While the traditional cost barriers for space systems have dramatically 
reduced, they are still expensive.  
• Vulnerability. Space systems possess vulnerabilities across all three segments.  
• Predictability . Objects in space do not fly like aircraft, rather they fall in accordance 
with the laws of orbital mechanics. Satellite orbits are therefore mostly predictable.  
• Limited responsiveness. While limited responsiveness is still valid when 
considering larger exquisite capabilities (which are few in number and take years and 
sometimes decades to build and replace), increasingly, the ease with which small, 
almost disposable satellites can be built and launched may mitigate this limitation to 
some degree.  
• Orbit congestion . While space itself is vast, the laws of orbital mechanics mean that 
certain orbits, especially geosynchronous equatorial orbit  (GEO ), are extremely 
valuable. Orbit slots in GEO are regulated by the International Telecommunication 
Union .

structured around the Defence Tasks set out in the Defence Strategy.  As a sub -set of the 
strategy, a plan is also Ways of applying Means. It is an annual plan which direct s the 
various commands  to deliver outputs to meet the overall strategy. The plan allocates 
appropriate resources to deliver these outputs through the budget process. The various 
Commands within defence write their own C ommand plans to meet the defence plan.  
7.8. Policy, Strategy, Plans Linkage. There is a clear linkage between policy, strategy,  
and plans. Policy is the highest -level direction on what is to be achieved. Policy directs 
strategy  – whatever way forward is decided upon to meet strategic objectives, these must be 
aligned to policy.  Plans  are developed by the MOD  to direct its activities and by commands  
take this direction and create their own plans . All plans  must be written to support the 
strategy . Governance is the process which ensures that outputs directed in the Defence Plan 
are achieved and remain aligned to Defence Strategy and eventually policy.

Roles of Principa l Staff Officer s & Advisors:  
2.1. Chief of Staff .  A Chief of Staff (COS) is responsible for operations, operations 
support, plans and intelligence. He coordinates work across the headquarters, with particular 
responsibility for information management. He is pivotal to the efficient running of the 
headquarters; a good COS can engender and sustain mutual trust and understanding 
between individual staff mem bers, advisers and subordinate headquarters.  
2.2. Deputy Chief of Staff .  A Deputy COS (DCOS) coordinates logistics, personnel and 
often finance. Though normally of equivalent rank, the COS is primus inter pares.  
2.3. Policy Adviser . The Policy Adviser (POLAD) advises a JTFC on the international, 
regional and local political context, as well as UK Government policy.  
2.4. Legal  Adviser .  A Legal Adviser (LEGAD) provides legal advice and is pivotal to all 
aspects of planning and execution. Targeting and rules of engagement, for instance, will 
demand his close scrutiny and input.  
 
2.5. STRATCOM - Media Adviser . A media adviser brings technical and cultural 
understanding of media processes and agendas. This shapes not only direct media 
engagement, but also wider activity, through better understanding of how events are likely to 
be reported and perceived.  
2.6. Scientific Advisers.  Scientific Advisers (SCIADs), when embedded, provide 
operational analysis support to planning, execution and assessment.  
2.7. Subject Matter Experts.  A JTFC may employ subject matter experts to advise on 
local or regional issues. They may, for example, be indigenous or foreign academics who provide guidance on culture, economy and religion.  
2.8. Interpreter or Translator Support .  Skilled and experienced interpreters or 
translators enhance a JTFHQ considerably. However, locally employed civilians, while 
readily available, may not always be impartial or reliable.

3.3. ACOS of a J - Staff Branch. The role of the Assistant Chief of Staff (ACOS) of each 
generic functional J – Branch is to serve as the principle subject matter expert advisor to the 
CJTF and assist him in the planning, direction and control of operations to achieve his 
mission.  As ACOS he leads, directs and coordinates his overall J function al branch area s of

3.4. DACOS of a J - Staff Branch.  The role of the Deputy Assistant Chief of Staff 
(DACOS) of each generic functional J – Branch is to act as the deputy to the ACOS and act 
in his place if he is absent.   He is responsible to his ACOS for leading any specified areas of 
his branch.  
Types of Cross Functional Staff Organisations  (AJP -3) 
3.5. Centre .  Centres are permanent, cross functional staff integrating organizations. A 
centre is an enduring functional organization, with supporting staff, designed to perform a 
joint function within the JTF HQ. Often, these organizations have designated locations or  
facilities. Examples of centres include the JOC and the joint personnel recovery centre. The 
JOC is the most familiar centre typically found in a joint HQ with dedicated manning and 
facilities to integrate the activities of the staff for current operations.  The JOC focuses on 
supporting the direct, monitor, assess, and plan functions for the commander.  
3.6. Group .  A group is an enduring functional organization formed to support a broad 
function within a JTF HQ.  Normally, groups within a JTF HQ include a Joint Force  Planning
