Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 6 – May 202 5 1.49.  Culmination : “The point in time and the location at which a force no longer has the 
capability to continue an operation under current conditions .”  (AAP- 06) 
1.50.  Why do Forces Culminate?  A military force will culminate for one or more of the 
following reasons:  
• Higher than anticipated attrition or activity –  ie not enough combat power remaining.  
• Inadequate logistics –  ie running out of fuel or ammunition.  
• Extended lines of communication –  slowing down the rate of logistic support.  
• Poor or inadequate intelligence leading to an unrealistic estimation of the enemy’s or 
one’s own forces relative capabilities.  
• In the offence, the attacking force reaches its culminating point when it can no longer 
sustain its offensive action and must transition to the defence or risk counterattack  and 
defeat.  
• In the defence, the defending force reaches its culminating point when it no longer has 
the capability to mount a counter offensive or defend successfully and is forced to 
disengage or withdraw or face defeat.  
1.51.  How do you Plan to Avoid Culmination?  Planners should use sequencing and 
phasing in their own planning to ensure that operations by opposing actors culminate well 
before they can achieve their objective while ensuring that their own operations achieve their 
objectives well before any culmination.           
1.52.  Operational Pause : “A temporary and deliberate cessation of certain activities 
during the course of an operation to avoid reaching the culminating point and to be able to 
regenerate the combat power required to proceed with the next stage of the operation.”   
                                                                                                                       (AAP6 Definition)  
1.53.  How do I use a ‘Operational Pause’ in my Plan?  Although a pause tends to 
reduce tempo, at least in the short term, it can also provide greater effectiveness and 
improved tempo later on. Indeed, implicit in the term ‘pause’ is the ability to re- activate the 
operation in order to regain the initiative and re- establish momentum.  An operational pause 
can apply to all component activity  or to just one line of operation or one component of the 
force , for example to concentrate effort on another.   
1.54.  Pause - Don’t Culminate!   A planned operational pause is preferable to premature 
culmination.  Nevertheless, operational -level planners need to ensure an integrated 
approach to the operational design in order to minimise the requirement for operational 
pauses in the operation. (A JP-5 Para 3.17)  
1.55.  Sequencing and Phases (AJP -5 para 3.18)  The primary aim in sequencing and 
phasing an operation or campaign is to maintain its continuity and tempo and to avoid 
unnecessary operational pauses.  
1.56.  Sequencing: “Sequencing is the arrangement, simultaneously or sequentially, of 
actions designed to create effects to establish DCs within a campaign or operation in an 
order that is most likely to produce the desired operational outcomes.”  
(COPD Para 4.27.j.(1))

1.57.  Why do we Sequence in Planning?  The planning team  should determine the best 
arrangement of actions and effects to achieve objectives. This arrangement will often be a 
combination of simultaneous  and sequential  actions. However, it may not be possible to 
achieve the objectives in a single engagement or even a major operation. As such, the operations design normally provides for the sequencing of actions and the phasing of operations. Although simultaneous action on multiple lines of operation may be ideal, 
resource availability usually forces the commander to prioritize  and sequence the actions; 
consequently, a commander may choose to sequence the actions in order to reduce risks to 
an acceptable level. This process assists in thinking through the entire operation logically in 
terms of available forces, resources and time, and helps to determine different operational phases.  
1.58.  Phases: “A clearly defined stage of an operation or campaign during which the main 
forces and capabilities employed set conditions for a common purpose.”  (COPD Glossary of 
Terms)

riginal MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 16 – May 2025 1.61.  Synchronization, synergy and leverage .  The planning team  “considers how to 
best synchronize actions in order to generate the greatest effect with a given expenditure of 
resources or a desired effect with the least expenditure”. ( AJP- 5 para  3.18.b) 
1.62.  Synchronisation. Synchronization is the arrangement of actions and their effects in 
time, space and purpose. The planning team  will therefore make integrated use of all 
capabilities available to them  to achieve their objective. The primary benefit from 
synchronized actions is the ability to produce synergy using different resources and gain 
leverage through creating effects and their exploitation throughout the operations area.  
1.
63. Synergy.  Synergy is the ultimate aim of all synchronization efforts. Synergy is the 
cumulative outcome or result of discrete acts; it is greater than the sum of the individual parts acting independently. Synergy should be the result of effective synchronization. In  
practice, it means integration and synchronization of actions aimed to achieve the objective.  
1.64.  Leverage.  Leverage is achieved when the resulting impact of an action is more than 
proportionate to the effort applied. Leverage can be achieved by focusing the joint force’s  
strengths, against another actor’s weaknesses and  utilizing also other instruments of power 
in a comprehensive approach. 
1.65.  What’s the Difference between Sequence & Synchronise in Planning?  
Sequencing is the logical arrangement of effects and activities based on their 
interdependencies.  Synchronisation applies time , space and resource considerations to 
sequences and thus establishes their feasibility.

1.67.  Simultaneity and depth . The planning team determines the extent to which joint 
forces can conduct simultaneous actions  to create Effects & DCs throughout the depth of the 
operations area.  
• This is largely a function of the availability of military resources and their operational 
reach. The intent should always be to achieve synergy by combining the effects of simultaneous actions to overwhelm the adversary’s ability to respond effectively with so 
many actions occurring at one time and to conceal the direction of main effort as long as 
possible . (AJP-5 para 3.18.c ) 
1.68.  Tempo .  Tempo is the rate or rhythm of activity relative to the adversary’s, within 
tactical actions and between major operations.  
• Tempo incorporates the capacity of a joint force to make the transition from one 
operational posture to another to gain and maintain the initiative. The ability to dictate the 
operational tempo provides freedom of action and is key to bringing an adversary  to its 
culmination point while preventing the premature culmination of one’s own operation.   
(AJP- 5 para 3.18. d) 
1.69.   Branches and Sequels - Contingency Options Planning .  An essential step in the 
operations design process in operational -level planning is to anticipate eventualities that may 
occur during the course of an operation and determine alternative LoOs and sequences of  
action, while still achieving the objective.  
• For every action there is a range of possible outcomes that may or may not create the 
desired effects or the expected changes of conditions.  
• Outcomes that are more favourable than expected may present opportunities that can be 
exploited.

2.7. (T) Task.  – Something that must be completed.  Tasks can be objectives, effects, 
action s or activi ties. Specified Tasks – told to do. Implied Tasks – something you must  do to 
achieve the specified task . 
2.8. (C) Potential Constraint  – A requirement placed on a commander that dictates an
action,  ie things you must do; eg follow ROE, complete mission by a date/time.  
2.9. (REST) Restraint – A requirement placed on a commander that prohibits an action;

2.10.  (CCIR)  Commander ’s Critical I nformation Requirement: Information concerning areas

process where gaps in knowledge and information have been revealed.  Assumptions are used in place of a fact that is unknown; they must be logical, realistic & necessary. 
Assumptions should not be made that dismiss enemy capabilities or intentions & alter 
challenging aspects of the situation or presume our own success.  Assumptions are treated 
as facts and therefore need to be analysed like a factor.  Once adopted, an assumption will

5.2. What is IPE?   Full Intelligence Preparation o f The Environment  is a tactical level 
planning tool designed to analyse both the physical, information and human terrain as well 
as the enemy and adversary in order to establish what the enemy is most likely to do and 
when. It consists of:  
•Operational Area Evaluation (OAE)
•Threat Evaluation (TE).
•Threat  Integration ( TI).
Figure 5. 2 Illustrating an overview of IPE processes . 
5.3. Operational  Area Evaluation  (OAE) .  OAE is the analysis of the terrain, people and 
the effects of the weather in order to identify how the environment impacts on the movement 
and actions of both friendly forces and actors, audiences, adversaries and  the enemy.  
Includes:  
•Physical Environment Analysis. (Terrain & Weather)
•Information Environment Analysis. (See Serial 4 -02-05)
•Human Network Analysis.
5.4. Threat Evaluation (TE). TE is the doctrinal and strength analysis of the enemy to 
identify the tactics that are most likely to be used.  
5.5. Threat  Integration (TI). TI is the analysis of the enemy overlaid onto the 
environment to identify how the enemy’s tactics will be applied in the environment.  From this, 
the most likely  (ML) and most dangerous (MD) enemy Course of Action (COA) can be 
assessed.

riginal MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 6 – May 2025 5.6. Human Network  Analysis .  Today’s operational environment is complex. The 
operational environment may have conventional forces, irregular fighters or criminal armed 
groups all operating in the same geographic area. The human factor is always present in 
these groups and their networks must be assessed.  Networks vary, including by: location; 
size; shape; membership; demographics; risks and motivations. Successful networks are well integrated into their operating environment, and are commensurately challenging to locate and track, and thus hard to engage. 
5.7. Network Associations . Networks form because of common outcomes or 
allegiances. Examples of these allegiances our shared goals are below: 
•Political motivated network.
•Military network.
•Economically motivated networks.
•Social/Cultural Network.
•Infrastructure (Proximity / Organizational) network.
•Family Network.
•Specialized or Functional network.
5.8. Threat Network Organizational Structures. Networks can be organized in a variety 
of ways. Many will deviate from the hierarchical structures familiar to conventional forces. 
Figure 5. 3 Illustrating Network organisational structures.

level planning. It helps to develop a network profile and identifies the networks that pose the 
greatest threat to success in the operational environment. Networks are created by 
individuals and their nodes and links. Macro analysis concentrates upon a broad overarching understanding of the networks and identifies threat network critical capabilities and 
objectives, operational areas, activities and requirements. Centre of Gravity (C oG) analysis

6.1. Understanding .  This  is one of the cornerstones of our military philosophy and it is 
implicit in applying the tenets of doctrine. Fighting power cannot be applied effectively and 
efficiently without understanding: the competition and its context; the operating environment; our own capabilities; and the capabilities of audiences. Understanding helps commanders to make decisions; it also helps them to manage any associated risks and any second and 
subsequent order effects that could be harmful in influencing the targeted audienc es. 
6.2. What is Analysis?   Analysis is the process of evaluating information about the 
current and past behaviour of a state, system, organisation or individual. Thus, analysis is an 
essential component in the process of converting situational awareness into understanding . 
6.3. Analysis Frameworks .  Selection of a problem  solving framework must focus on 
whether it provides the necessary degree of granularity to meet a specific situation.  Examples include: 
•PEST  – Political, Economic, Social and Technological.
•PESTLEI  – Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Legal, Environmental & Info
•PMESII  -PT– Political, Military, Economic, Social, Infrastructure and Information –
Physical, Time .  This is a widely used and effective U.S. model.
•STEEPLEM  – Social, Technological, Economic, Environmental, Political, Legal, Ethical
and Military.
•ASCOPE – Area, Structure, Capabilities, Organisation, People and Events (used by the
US and the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan).
•Human Terrain .  Understanding the human terrain requires us to understand the local
population’s environment from their perspective .

6.8. Analysis of the Human Terrain . It is important to examine  all aspects of the human terrain, and to avoid only focusing on the obvious 
and different aspects of audiences . Cultural practices are the things that are immediately observable in a society, such as people’s style of 
dress, greetings  and rituals, flags and other symbols. On an individual level, cultural practices  manifest themselves in a person’s behaviour.   
However, to understand the human terrain, we need to look beyond the immediately observable cultural  practices  to examine what drives or 
underlies these practices. These social  structures are the normally invisible concepts and institutions that organise society.  
6.9. The Human Terrain Model .  To help simplify complexity we tend to create defined categories and structures  for analysis .  There is a 
danger that these divisions are artificial and mask  the subtle interconnected nature of human society and social interaction.  
6.10.  Categories of Analysis.   The following categories of analysis are not absolute, the context and operating environment may require 
additional areas to be considered.  
• Social Organisation .  Social organisation is  the basic building block of society. It includes the groups into which people are born, and 
which influence their attitudes and behaviour throughout their life.  On a larger scale, a person shares a language, history and usually 
religion with his ethnic group. Gender is also part of social organisation, as men and women usually have different roles and  
responsibilities in a society.  
• Political Organisation. Power and politics work in different ways in different societies.  Successful engagement with people in power 
relies on understanding why the people around them follow their directions. Understanding the nature of political organisation in the society 
is essential in determining who actually holds the power and their influences  within different audiences . 
• Economic Organisation. Access to resources underpins behaviours and attitudes of all people. How resources are distributed and 
exchanged differs according to the type of audience.  
• Beliefs and Values.  S hared beliefs and values ensure the loyalty  and shapes the behaviour  of members to a n audience group. These 
may include formal  ideologies or religions  or informal or non- codified beliefs about the nature of the world and of society .  Understanding 
these values helps commanders anticipate the likely  behaviour of the  audience group.  
• Interaction . All audience groups have normal ways for their members to interact  with each other, ranging from the language that they 
share, through their  concepts of personal space, hand gestures and clothing. Differences in interaction styles are often the most obvious 
aspect of the human terrain.   Understanding local norms and practices in interacting with others is essential for mission success . 
6.11.  Human Terrain in Military Physical Domains . The aspects of the human terrain described above apply to people wherever they live. 
For. It is therefore essential that intelligence staff  examine the people in the joint operational environment from the perspective of the people, 
rather than from the perspective of the military environment in which they are placed.

10.1.  Understanding  Risk  & Opportunity.   All operations require commanders at all 
levels to identify and seize opportunities.  But they also necessarily involve significant and 
often fatal risks. Understanding risk , and its implications  at the different levels of operations  
is essential  for commanders and staff .   
10.2.  Military Risk (AAP -6 Definition ): “Risk states the extent to which uncertainties and 
potential events  might have an impact on the achievement of objectives.”  
10.3.  Military Risk Management  (AAP -6 Definition) : “The process of Identifying, 
assessing and controlling risk arising from operational factors, and making informed 
decisions that balance risk cost with mission benefits.  
10.4.  Strategic Risk:  Events that impact upon or change the overall strategic context 
may, in extremis, jeopardise the achievement of strategic outcomes. e g:  A change of 
government or its policy . 
10.5.  Operational  Risk: Risks to the mission and 
risks to the force through poor planning or  execution 
and through external influence ie enemy activity.  
10.6.  Operating  Risk :  Relates to the potential 
negative outcomes born out of operating technical 
military capabilities.  ie aircraft operating out of normal 
tolerances for temperature.  
10.7.  Tactical  Risk :  This arises from the effects of both planned or anticipated activity and 
the results of entirely unforeseen or planned activity –  events of chance.  
10.8.  The Implications of R isk.  Risk has different implications at different levels of 
operations with actions and decisions taken at one level potentially incurring risk at another.

10.15.  Reserves.  Some risks will occur which are unforeseen.   Operationally, a 
commander will always keep a reserve, traditionally not less than 1/9th of his force, to 
mitigate risks or exploit opportunities.  They may also warn a reserve to mitigate or exploit 
risks or opportunities using ‘Be Prepared to’ Tasks in the Reserve’s Mission.  
10.16.  Dispensations .  A dispensation is required when it is believed necessary to operate 
an item of equipment outside its endorsed safety case (operating risk). Examples include 
drivers not holding the correct licence, vehicles operating above their gross weight etc.  
10.17.  Waivers .  A waiver is required when a commander wishes to operate outside of 
TTPs  or formal directives  (operational &  tactical risk) . The most common waivers relate to 
ECM and Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) . There are two types of dispensation / 
waiver:  
• Continuous.  Applicable to situations or requirements that the drafting formation or unit identifies as enduring.  
• Operation Specific .  Used to cover an identified requirement within the estimate 
process for a specific operation.  If approved, this type of request will only apply to 
those forces involved in the operation and will expire once the operation has been 
completed

riginal MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 5 – Apr 2024 OPERATIONS PLANNING OVERVIEW (AJP -5 Chapter 1)  
1.1. What is Decision Making and Military Planning (DMMP)?   DMMP is a formal 
process of planning to consider problems and construct Courses of Action (COAs).  
Estimates are planning tools that enable military commanders to make timely and 
appropriate decisions and to generate plans and orders.   Estimates range in complexity from 
the extensive analysis and briefings that take place in large component  or formation 
headquarters , ships  or battalion Command Posts (CPs), where there is a full staff and plenty 
of time, down to the rapid assessment and decisions made in contact by commanders in 
contact or at company  level and below.  
1.2. Planning Characteristics.  Planning is a dynamic process of interrelated activities 
rather than a single linear process.   Planning is command led and continually updated.  HQ 
staff will assist in the planning process, but ultimately it is the commander’s plan,  and he 
drives its development, underlining that planning is an intellectual activity, aided, but not 
driven by an estimate process.  Although each campaign or operation is unique, all planning 
activity shares a common purpose: to translate superior commander’s objectives & intent 
into orders and activity for the subordinate HQs and units.  This process is also known as 
Operational Art and requires the commanders at all levels to make decisions and plan.  
1.3. Operations Planning.  Operations Planning is the planning of military operations at 
the strategic, operational or tactical levels.  The preferred English term to designate the 
planning of military operations at all levels is ”operations planning”. The term ”operational 
planning” is not to be used so as to prevent confusion with operational -level planning. ( AJP-
5)See Figure 1.1 and 1.12 to show how operations planning links to the level of operations .
What is Operational Art?  Operational art is the critical link between strategy and tactics.  
Strategy and policy guide operational art by determining the ultimate objectives to be 
achieved and by allocating the necessary military and non -military resources.  Strategy also

2.1. Combat Estimate (CE) .  The CE, also known as the ‘7 Questions’,  is used in the 
Land environment .  It is derived from the standard estimate but presents the analysis, plan 
creation and decision- making in a sequence of 7 questions.  This is intended to make it easy 
to focus on rapid understanding of the problem and decision- making as part of accelerated 
battle procedure.  The CE is designed to generate plans for single, urgent tactical problems, 
yet can be adapted for more complex, deliberate actions.  It assumes that the operating 
environment and general tactical situation are already well understood.  It is used for 
problems to be executed qui ckly (as a guide, within 72 hours), and because of the nature of 
battlegroup operations it is always the tool used at that level and below .  It may also be used 
at the brigade level  if quick execution is required.  Consequently, the CE can be used by an 
individual commander or with a supporting headquarters staff.

3.1. What is the Tactical Estimate?   The Tactical Estimate (TE)  is used when the 
tactical problem is complex,  and plans may be longer term and involve significant 
sequencing.  There must therefore be sufficient time (over 96 Hrs) to complete a thorough 
assessment of the situation and the resultant plan may well link a number of tactical actions, 
through time and across the Battlespace.  Although it is typically the preserve of the higher 
tactical level (LCC or Division), a Brigade HQ should use the TE when planning a deliberate, 
complex, multinational operation, and the CE for subsequent tactical actions.  
3.2. Process.   TE is taken from  the NATO  APP - 28 – Tactical Planning for Land Forces . 
It consists of analysis in seven linked st eps, very similar  in format, processes  and outputs to 
the 7 step AJP -5 Estimate .  When higher tactical level Land units (LCC or Div) are operating 
within the context of a Joint Operational or Campaign Plan, the TE estimate will typically be used to produce a tactical plan in support of an overarching campaign/  operational -level

(Summary from AJP -3.9(A) Joint Targeting)  
3.1. What is  Joint Targeting?  Joint targeting involves the process of selecting and 
prioritising targets (which are classified as being either facility, individual, virtual entity, 
equipment or organization (FIVE -O) and matching the appropriate response to them .  
3.2. Legal Compliance .  Joint targeting must be conducted in a manner which ensures 
compliance with the applicable legal framework, especially International Humanitarian Law/Law of Armed Conflict (IHL/LOAC) principles. It must also be conducted in order to 
ensure that any risk of  civilian casualties or collateral damage is proportionate compared 
with the expected military advantage to be gained.  
3.3. What is a target?   An area, structure, object, person, or group of people against 
which lethal or non- lethal capability can be employed to create specific psychological or 
physical effects. Notes: The term 'person' also covers their mindset, thought processes, 
attitudes and behaviours. (AJP- 3.9) 
3.4. Full Spectrum  Targeting  Approach:   The full -spectrum approach provides a 
coherent range of options and effects that aims to optimize military action by avoiding 
duplication of effort, effects negating each other and ensures that the right targets are prosecuted in the right order, at the ri ght time by the right capabilities. It recognizes that 
effects will be created by actions in the physical, virtual, or cognitive dimensions in a 
synchronized way, and that both lethal and non -lethal engagement can create physical, 
virtual and cognitive (i.e., psychological/behavioural) effects.  
3.5. Actions & Effects .  Joint  targeting involves taking actions in one or more of the 
operational domains, using all capabilities available, against a target, in order to create an 
effect in one or more of the physical, virtual, or cognitive dimensions. These actions taken 
and the eff ects subsequently created, can range from lethal to non- lethal.  
3.6. Target Engagement Authority ( TEA) .  Target engagement authority is the authority 
granted to a Commander to approve target engagement.   The Commander ’s target 
engagement authority can  subsequently be delegated  further, if permitted, and after 
consideration for the specified target set, the risk level, and/or use of capabilities and/or 
collateral damage level.   During planning and execution, the JTF/CC and their staff must be 
aware of any national caveats, additional restrictions or considerations depending on the 
situation that could affect assigning resources for target engagement. National caveats are reported through appropriate national representatives.  
3.7. The Engagement Continuum.  Engagements and actions can take place across a 
wide spectrum. The engagement continuum and related activities are depicted in Figure 3. 1 
below.   
3.8. Deliberate targeting . Deliberate targeting is conducted against validated targets 
known to exist and intended to be prosecuted on either a scheduled or on -call basis. 
Deliberate targeting results in targets being properly subject to quality control, validated and being placed on the joint target list (JTL) or restricted target list (RTL). Deliberate targeting 
normally supports the JTF’s future operations and future plans efforts.   Deliberate targeting 
also identifies the JFC’s Time- Sensitive Targets (TSTs) .

3.9. Dynamic targeting . Dynamic targeting engages targets that due to the dynamic 
changes in operations, present a threat to force or mission but were not detected, located, or

approved rules of engagement, outside of self -defence, to accomplish missions and tasks 
during operations when it is not feasible to conduct either deliberate or dynamic targeting due to the immediacy of the engagement.

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 2020 OPERATIONS ASSESSMENT  (From AJP -3) 
4.1. Assessment Definitions:   
•  “A considered process of appraisal to support decision making.” (AAP- 06) 
• “the activity that enables the measurement of progress and results of operations in a 
military context, and the subsequent development of conclusions and recommendations 
that support decision making.” (NATO Assessment Handbook )  
4.2. What is the Purpose of Assessment?  The purpose of operations assessment is to 
inform the commander if the operation is being executed as planned and if the operation is 
achieving the desired results. Operations assessment is critical because no planning 
process can guarantee success, and pr ogress must be continually reviewed against 
achievement of objectives so that plans can be adjusted as necessary  
4.3. Levels of Assessment .  The assessment of the campaign encompasses the 
strategic assessment, the operational -level assessment and the tactical assessment. Each 
of these levels supports the assessment of the next level.  It is fundamental to successful 
operations as it provides the means for keeping the operational situation and progress under 
continual review; using a structured mix of subjective and objective measurement . 
4.4. Assessment is Command Led:  The Commander should review (at Assessment 
Board) and adjust initial planning based upon the results of assessment, which has been 
designed to:  
• evaluate the execution of activities by the (joint) force;  
• evaluate the effectiveness of those activities;  
• show  whether the situation is developing favourably.

1.3. Timeliness .  OSW delivered late to subordinate HQs will give them insufficient 
time to conduct their own planning and ultimately may lead to failure as execution 
will be impossible.  An imperfect plan or order, on time, is better than a perfect plan delivered late.  
1.4. Approach .  Where possible, we use template SOP formats to aid 
understanding and promote standardised procedure.  However, creativity to clearly communicate the commander ’s intentions should be encouraged.  
1.5. Composition. Directives; Plans; Orders & Instructions should be:  
•Concise: Only write enough detail that is necessary for a subordinate to achieve his
mission.  Do not prescribe anything to a subordinate commander that he, with a fullerknowledge of the local conditions, should be better to decide himself. Otherwise you willconstrain his initiative.
•Clear .  There should be no scope for ambiguity. Choose your words carefully and us
e
t
he correct staff duties and conventions.
•Accurate.  Check & validate all factual data such as grid references, timings, orbats and
ROE.
1.6. Annexes: The main purpose of annexes is to keep the basic text of OSW short.  
Annexes provide amplifying information that is not appropriate in the main OSW document, 
or information that amplifies a specific aspect.  
1.7. Op Staff Duties: General Points. The main rule is that in operational writing the 
maximum use is to be made of abbreviations and the text is to be written in note form to save time and space, remembering always that the meaning remains clear.  Paragraph 
headings can form part of the opening of a sentence, eg ‘Ammo. Issued 1300 hrs’. Note that the syntax rules of JSP 101 apply, but the remaining conventions will not. 
Minor Rules . 
1.8. Exercise Protective Markings. In exercise protective markings the word 
‘EXERCISE’ is always to be abbreviated to ‘EX’, eg ‘EX SECRET’.  
1.9. Proper Nouns. Proper nouns are written in capital letters, eg ‘SWINDON’, ‘River 
TONE’. 1.10.  Composite Nouns. Any composite noun, or one containing a prefix or suffix is to be 
abbreviated by abbreviating that part of it for which there is an authorised abbreviation, eg 
‘mob’ (mobilisation), ‘demob’ (demobilisation). 
1.11.  Abbreviations. Only those recognised abbreviations included may be used without 
an introduction. Where unofficial abbreviations are to be used they are to be introduced into 
the order correctly. Some abbreviations indicate both the singular and plural. If the addition 
of an ‘s’ is necessary,  it is always placed at the end of the abbreviation eg: ‘CinCs’ 
(Commanders in Chief). An ‘s’ may be added only to the abbreviation of a noun; it is never to 
be added to the abbreviation of a verb, eg ‘follows’ should be abbreviated to ‘fol’.  
1.12.  Times . Times are to be expressed using the 24 -hour clock and the time zone suffix, 
unless an expedient such as ‘Time Zone Used Throughout the Order: BRAVO’ is inserted 
below the references.  
1.13.  Description of Attachments/Detachments . Units which have elements detached 
are to be described using the convention illustrated below. The quantity of units/sub -units is 
always written in full eg: 20 Armd Bde (less two bns) or 1 R IRISH (less one coy).

indented in single inverted commas. For example:  
We captured 3 offrs and 2 NCOs. They revealed en morale to be very poor. One of the 
NCOs said: ‘We have had no food supplied since 3 o’clock on Thursday of last week and we were promised that large stocks would be captured on the objective.’  
Ground Locations, Areas and Boundaries. 
1.15.  Locations and Points on the Ground. Locations and points on the ground may be 
described by Grid Reference or by giving the direction and distance from a simple reference 
point.  
1.16.  Cardinal Points.  The 4 cardinal points of the compass are written in full, eg south. 
For intermediate points the letters N, S, E and W are used, eg NE, SSW. Points of the 
compass should always be considered in clockwise order from north.  
1.17.  Names of Places and Features.  The names of places and features are spelt 
exactly as on the map in use, except that the word ‘River’, written in full, is to precede the names of all rivers regardless of the language in which this word appears on the map. The 
grid reference  is to be given the first time the name of the place or feature occurs. It should 
be shown as a bigram map code followed by the grid reference number, eg: ‘CN 493246’.  
1.18.  Roads, Tracks and Railways.  Roads, tracks and railways are described by the 
names of  places located on them. The word ‘road’, ‘track’ or ‘railway’ is to precede the place 
names,  eg ‘railway Winchester -Basingstoke’. Sufficient place names should be used to 
ensure the correct road / track / railway is identified.  
1.19.  River banks.  Riverbanks  are described as right or left from the point of view of an  
observer facing downstream or, if this cannot be done, by issuing  cardinal points. ‘Near’ and  
‘far’ may be used with reference to friendly forces involved in river crossing operations.  
1.20.  Canals.  The names of a canal, or names of places on it, are used to describe a 
canal. The banks are usually described by means of the cardinal points, eg: ‘the north bank 
of the Kiel  Canal’.  
1.21.  Routes.  When movement is involved, a route is described by a sequence of points 
on the route named, in the direction of movement. When no movement is involved, the 
sequence of points named is to be from left to right or rear to front, assuming that the person 
designating the route is facing the enemy. Cardinal points may be added if required. It is 
common to give a route a nickname for ease of reference.  
1.22.  Areas .  An area is described by taking the northernmost point first and giving the  
remaining points in clockwise order.  
1.23.  Ground/Positions .  Ground and positions are described from left to right and front to 
rear facing the enemy. To avoid confusion, cardinal points may be used to describe flanks, 
rather than ‘left’ or ‘right’.  
1.24.  Boundaries.  Boundaries are designated by easily distinguishable features on the 
ground in the sequence in which they occur. They are to be described from rear to front during an advance and from front to rear in defence and withdrawal. If generally parallel to 
the front, eg rear boundaries, they are to be described from left to right facing the enemy.  
Cardinal points may be added if required. When describing boundaries between units and formations, the words ‘inclusive’ or ‘exclusive’ are used before the place to which they refer. 
The description of a boundary must state specifically to which unit or formation an area or a point is inclusive or exclusive.  
1.25.  Directions. A direction may be indicated in one of 3 ways:  
oBy use of 2 locations or places, eg ‘direction Hannover -Dortmund’.

5.1. What is a Mission Statement ?  “A clear, concise statement of the task(s) to be 
performed and the purpose of the mission. ” (AAP- 6) 
MISSION  
 
  
 
Task (What is to be done)  + Purpose (Why is it to be done)  
  
5.2. Task .  A task is something you have been told to do (specified) or must do (implied) 
to achieve the specified.  Tasks can be objectives, effects and actions.  Multiple tasks can be 
given to subordinates.  
5.3. What is a Concept of Operations (CONOPS)?   “A clear and concise statement of 
the line of action chosen by a commander in order to accomplish his given mission.”  (AAP- 6) 
5.4. Developing Mission Statements .   A mission statement is a clear and direct order 
to a subordinate and consists of Action / Task verbs and a unifying purpose (Effect), traditionally preceded by the words ‘in order to’. There are three  types of mission:  
• A single statement with a unifying purpose.  A superior commander should strive 
to give a minimum of tasks to each subordinate. Therefore the simplest type of mission, and that usually most applicable at lower levels of command, contains only 
one task.  
• A series of tasks with a unifying purpose . It is better to be explicit and list 
specified tasks for subordinates with a unifying purpose.  
• For reserves, a series of ‘be prepared to’ (BPT) tasks, without a unifying purpose.  
At the operational level a mission may be a mixture of all three types.  
5.5. Use of Missions in OSW .  Missions should be listed in a logical order of activity 
rather than in service precedence as this will aid the visualisation of the operation. Tasks 
contained within mission statements should be substantive.  Lesser tasks, such as 
conducting prelim moves or establishing liaison will normally be omitted from the mission, 
but may be included elsewhere in the orders, normally in coordinating instructions.  Missions 
will often be writ ten personally by the commander and  should contains the elements of who, 
what, when, wher e, and why.

3. Where appropriate enhance military forces of SOUTHLAND capacity and capability 
to operate in the JOA without GOLD Alliance support.  
4. Lead with theatre STRATCOM.  
5. Protect security and freedom of movement of GOLD Interests in MAHHAR.

5.11.  Formulating Concepts of Operations (CONOPS) .  The concept of operations 
describes how the commander intends to achieve his mission.  It is drafted in the estimate 
process, steps 3 and 4.  It has three main elements:  
•Intent Statement
•Scheme of Manoeuvre
•Main Effort.

higher (component) tactical level.  
5.12.  Intent Statement :  The commander’s effects schematic produced in step 2 of the 
estimate process  leads to the intent statement.  The intent statement should be written by 
the commander personally to express what  he wants to achieve and why.  The intent must 
be written in language that the reader will understand, noting that they may be from another 
nation or be civilian.  A possible sequence for writing an Intent is: 
•Purpose (Why)  - Describe the overall purpose of what it is you are trying to achiev e
(
the Outcome).
•Method (What)  - Describe the Objectives and the Effects using time , space or
purpose to group them.
•End-state  - Summarise what success looks like and indicate what next.
5.13.  Number of Words .  Intent  statements at the lower tactical level, Land Brigade and 
below may be quite short and brief.  However, operational commander’s or component 
commander’s Intents for campaigns will be considerably longer, as much as a full A4 sized 
page as the complexity and duration is much bigger.   Critically, The intent helps the force 
pursue the mission without further orders, even when actions do not unfold as planned  and it 
enables exploitation when the execution unfolds more favourable than expected. Thus, if an 
unant icipated situation arises, participating commanders understand the purpose of the 
forthcoming action well enough to act decisively and within the bounds of the higher  
commander’s intent.  
5.14.  Example Intent at Land Brigade  level : 
•I intend to enable the destruction of the enemy’s 80 (Sep) MR Bde by 20 Armd Bde.
•We will FIND 80 (Sep) MR Bde axis of advance as early as possible, and DISRUP T
hi
s advance to EA TIGER.  BLOCK his lead echelons from exiting EA TIGER,
thereby FIXING 80 (Sep) MR Bde so that it can be DESTROYED in detail.
•At the end of this operation 80 (Sep) MR Bde will CLEARED from EA TIGER, and 4
Bde will begin its ADVANCE to the International Border.
5.15.  Scheme of Manoeuvre (SoM) :  The SoM expands the Intent; to describe how the 
commander sees his operation unfolding.  SoM  sets out  the method to achieve the change 
identified in the Intent.  It explains the additional detail of how , in relation to each other, the 
force’s  subordinate elements are to achieve the overall  purpose .  It is vital that  subordinates 
can understand their roles in the plan; what actions they need to accomplish and the effects 
that they and others are to realise.  Because it is related to time, a SoM can only be 
completed once the Sync Matrix has been confirmed.  A clear intent should minimise the 
length of the SoM.    
5.16.  Main Effort (ME):   The ME is that activity that the commander considers crucial to 
the success of the mission. He must give it substance by allocating sufficient resources to 
the unit assigned to it. Illuminating the ME ensures that when the situation becomes more 
confusing that activity will be remembered and provide the rallying point of effort. ME may  
change throughout an operation. It should be expressed as an action together, if possible,  
with the  primary force undertaking it.  
5.17.  Example JTF Main Effort : 
•Phase 1:  Successful deterrence of further NORTHLAND aggression. (ACC)
•Phase 2:  Restoration of territorial integrity of SOUTHLAND. (LCC)
•Phase 3:  Successful hand- over for sole security responsibility to an increasingly
confident and capable SOUTHLAND Armed Forces. (LCC)

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 20 20 EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION &  BRIEFINGS OVERVIEW: TYPES & FORMATS  
6.1. Introduction .  This SOHB Serial combines the theory of how to plan a briefing to 
communicate  information along with the agenda and format of a number of common 
briefings.  
Effective Communication  Overview  
6.2. Good commanders and staff officers have the attributes to be able to think and 
decide, organise, and communicate. The most visible skill a staff officer possess is that of 
communication. The best plans and ideas will matter little if poorly communicated. S imilarly, 
the best presenter or writer will be unable to ‘sell’ a poorly thought through plan.    
6.3. If your communication is going to be worth the effort, then it must be effective. What 
do we mean by Effective Communication? Put simply:  
• ‘Effective Communication is defined as the ability to convey information to 
another effectively and efficiently. ’  
If the communication is effective, it will have met its purpose, have been clearly understood 
and can be acted upon. If it is efficient, it will make best use of your time and the time of the 
audience. As the originator, this responsibility lies with you.  It is a process about knowing 
what is required, finding, and gathering the information to meet the requirement and then 
conveying the information clearly and simply. It is much more than just exchanging 
information.  
6.4. Communication comes in many forms: it could be a presentation to an audience to 
inform; it could be a written briefing to senior officer to seek a decision; it may be a briefing 
from a flipchart to explain, and there are many other examples.  
6.5. For any type of communication, we should always apply the POWER principle:  
• Plan. 
• Organise . 
• Write. 
• Edit. 
• Review/Rehearse . 
Plan .  (See Planning Sheet at below  which you should use to aid planning ) 
6.6. Timings .  The first thing we must do is establish how much time we have.  First 
establish by when, date and time, the requirement is due. When you have a total time break 
this time down into thirds:  
• 1/3 of the time to Plan  and Organise ,  
• 1/3 to Write  and  
• 1/3 to Edit and Review/Rehearse . 
• You also need to know for a verbal brief/presentation, how long have you got to 
speak for and is there a questions and answer session too.  
6.7. Planning Questions .  To understand what the requirement is, some important 
questions need to be answered. Use the 5W and H method:  
• When? – see above which you have now answered!  
• Where? - If a presentation or a verbal brief, where do you have to be? If a piece 
of written communication, who does it need to be with?  
• What? – What do they want to know? Have you been asked any questions?  
• Why? - Why do they want to know? What are they going to do with the 
information?  
SERIAL 3-04-06 
3–04–06 - 2 
 
Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 20 20 • Who? Who is the communication for? Who are the audience? What does the 
audience already know?  
• How? What are your initial thoughts on headings/sections/ideas/topics, etc.  
6.8. Organise .  After planning you now need to organise your thoughts and your 
reference material. If you have references or source information read these through and 
identify which parts are helpful to meeting the purpose of the task, which parts provide 
information w ithin the key headings.  Which information provides answers to any questions 
you have been asked. You will have more information that you need. You will not be able to 
cover everything so you must decide what to include and what not! The choice can  be 
helped by categorising information by applying the MOSCOW  principle:  
• Musts : these items must be included, without which the audience cannot 
understand what your communication is about.  (These are the few things you 
would tell them if you had only two minutes to make them understand.)   
• Shoulds : they really ought to know these things if they need to understand the 
subject properly.  
• Coulds : these are nice to know but can be left out and, if your audience is for a 
senior officer, they should always be left out.  
• Will Nots : information that may be relevant to the topic but does not meet the 
purpose of the communication identified in the planning.  
Cross reference the list of Must, Should, Coulds and Will Nots with the available reference 
material to meet your purpose. Identify a logical structure which meets the requirement – the 
questions answered in the plan. This should present the identified Mus t and Should 
information in a way which will make sense to the audience. Present the most important 
information first - if there is more than one Must or Should arrange them by importance. Only 
after you have Planned and Organised  should you start to write . 
6.9. Write .  In Writing  the detail is added to the structure developed during Planning  and 
Organisation . With a piece of written communication start to draft the paragraphs under the 
structure you have developed. With a verbal brief or presentation, always develop the points 
you are going to talk about before you start to consider how you will illustrate th em. Do not  
be tempted to start to design slides or a briefing aid before you have understood the points 
you are going to make. All types of communication should have a Beginning, Middle and 
End. This is a standard convention and the audience you are commun icating will be 
expecting the information to come in these three parts.  
• The beginning .  This  should explain what the communication is about and 
define its purpose. The audience need this made clear to them. The audience 
should understand what will follow and also why they should be listening to you 
or reading your document in the first place.  
• The middle  details the main points you wish to cover – your Musts and Shoulds. 
Make your most important points first. Within each heading or section make your 
most important point first too.  
• The end should convey your key message again. But it may also convey where 
to go from here, what next.  
• Accuracy, Brevity and Clarity . In general,  when you communicate, whether 
written or verbal, it should follow the convention of Accuracy, Brevity and Clarity 
or A B C:  
• Accuracy  - the information given must be reliable, and you must take care to 
distinguish fact from opinion.  
SERIAL 3-04-06 
3–04–06 - 3 
Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 20 20 •Brevity .  Focus on the key points identified from your Musts and Shoulds.
Those who you are providing the communication for, usually senior officers, will
not have time to read long documents or sit through long presentations.
•Clarity .  Use simple language presenting the material as clearly as possible.
Use language and structure to allow for quick understanding. Your audience
should be able to understand the first time they read or hear a presentation.
• Language .  To enhance A B C – choose your language carefully. Choose clear,
everyday words in simple sentence structures within short paragraphs,
appropriate for the audience. Use correct, spoken English or Arabic and avoid
technical language, jargon, acronyms, abbre viations, abstractions and
meaningless corporate -speak. Often one carefully chosen word can do the job of
a phrase, or a phrase can replace a sentence. We communicate clearly because
we think clearly, and we think clearly because we communicate clearly.  C lear,
precise language not only helps us to communicate, but it also ensures that
we’ve got our own thinking properly sorted out.  Vague statements such as
‘issues around’ hide muddled thinking and communicate an imprecise message.
We must think matters t hrough to make sure we’re saying exactly what we
mean. For example, how much more informative are phrases such as will
increase, will damage, will reduce, will complicate than is the widely used ‘will
impact’ upon?
• Question as you Draft . As we write, it’s helpful to imagine a sceptical senior
officer or audience repeatedly asking us two simple questions: Says who?  So
what?  The first reminds us to present some convincing and punchy evidence to
support our arguments.  The second forces u s to pursue the logic of what we’re
saying through to a precise and concrete conclusion, often revealing the solid,
practical advantage of our recommendation.
6.10. Edit.  There is always a temptation to steal some of the last 1/3 of the time available 
–which should be used for Editing , Reviewing and Rehearsing, to assist with writing. Be
disciplined. Protect the last 1/3 of your time, it will improve the quality of your product no end.
A senior officer can always tell if you have not left enough time to first Edit and then
Review/Rehears e your work. Editing is a distinct phase of the process – it focuses on the
content . It provides that opportunity to ensure the poin ts made are as concise and precise as
possible.
• Check MOSCOW .  Stand -back from the detailed process of writing and take a
fresh look at the content. Look at the Must and Should information again. Now
the words are drafted do these bits of information remain Musts and Shoulds? If
not, re -order them accordingly and b e ruthless.
• Review A, B, C .
•Accuracy  – ensure the information is factually accurate. Leave out any
information that you are not sure about, or if it is critical, confirm that information
before including it. It is OK not to know something but to communicate
information that is plain wrong is  inexcusable.
•Brevity  – ensure every word is required to communicate the points made . Go
through each line and check that the words used are necessary. Remove those
words that add no value.
•Clarity  – check the words convey the intended meaning. Keep the language
simple and the sentences short and to the point. Put yourself in the audience’s
position – is it clear?
SERIAL 3-04-06 
3–04–06 - 4 
Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 20 20 At the end of the editing process, you will have improved the quality of your work. You 
will have improved not just the language but the sense and understand. This is time 
well spent and will add value to any communication you are drafting.  
6.11. Review/Rehearse .  The final part of preparation is to Review and Rehearse .
Editing looks specifically at what is said and written. Reviewing is different. 
• Review  looks at whether the intended purpose has been met. To review, go
back to the key questions you asked in the planning phase and check against
these:
•Who?  - Who is the communication for? What do they know already? Have
you made allowances for what the audience knows already – don’t repeat what
they already know.
•Why?  - Why do they want to know – what is the purpose? Does what you
have prepared meet the overall purpose? What is the senior officer intending to
do with the information? Is what you have prepared useful to the senior officer
based on the purpose?
•What?  - What do they want to know? If they have asked you specific
questions – have you answered them ? If they have asked you for an opinion –
have you given it and is it clear it is your opinion and not fact?
By taking time to review, you are confirming you have met the key criteria you have 
been asked to produce. You should have confidence to know that you have met the 
key requirements. Don’t ever overlook reviewing your work.  
• Rehearsal . If delivering a verbal communication,  you will have to rehearse. If a
presentation you should book time and a space to rehearse. If it is a briefing for a
senior officer, as a staff officer, you may not be able to rehearse away from your
desk. That does not matter, if you must, rehearse at yo ur desk. Even if you get to
rehearse just once, it will be worth it. Use the opportunity to align what you are
going to say to any briefing aids you may use, maps, diagrams etc and ensure
you stick to the tim e you have got. Use some of the rehearsal time to run through
your responses to questions you may receive – just two or three of the most
likely will do.
• Answering Questions .  Different types of communication require different ways
to answer questions.
•Presentations . When giving a presentation to an audience a useful way to
answer questions is:
•Stand still – walking around reduces confidence in the answer.
•Actively Listen - look at the person who posed the question.
•Paraphrase the question so all can hear.
•Thank the asker.
•Handle the question – give a concise answer.
•Verify with the asker you have answered their question.
•Verbal Brief . After delivering a verbal briefing a focussed way to provide a
useful answer is:  What – So What – Now What
•What  – answer the question posed.
•So What  – what was the outcome, what happened because of the
answer to the question.
•Now What  – what does this all mean for the future.

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 20 20 6.12.  Key Points : 
• For any type of communication to any type of audience – use P O W E R  to
make your communication more effective.
• After you have determined when the information is due (and where), allow 1/3 of
the time to plan and organise, 1/3 to write and 1/3 to edit and review/rehearse.
• When Planning:
•Apply the 5W an H .
•Ask yourself  some key questions – What information do they want to know?
Who wants it? What are they going to do with it? Who are the audience? And
what do they already know?
• When Organising:
•Prioritise your information using the MOSCOW  principle:
•Retain the Musts and Shoulds – don’t include the Coulds.
•Present your most important  points first.
• When Writing:
oEvery communication needs a Beginning, Middle and End.
oEnsure what you write is Accurate, Brief and Clear.
oSelect the appropriate language  for the audience.
• When Editing:
oFocus on the content:
•Edit for MOSCOW ; are the Musts and Shoulds in the right place still?
•Edit for A B C  – reduce your words down to what is the minimum
required to be effective.
• When Reviewing/Rehearsing:
oReview what you have written against the key questions from your planning –
have you met the purpose?
oIf a verbal brief or presentation – rehearse.
oIf you are expecting questions think about you could be asked and think about
answers.
6.13. Written Brief Format – IRTB.   If writing a written brief as part of the Write

• Receipt of Orders Brief (ROOB) – detailed format below.

commander may approve or reject the CON OPS, or seek further clarification. It
also allows for the opportunity to request additional resources.

HQ or ops room.

Situational Awareness is maintained within the staff cells of a HQ.
• Storyboard . Storyboards are usually a post -incident analysis tool which pictorially
represents an event in time and space. It is prepared by the staff on behalf of the
commander and allows him to rapidly assimilate information of a complex nature.

example during the Targeting Process).

7.1. What is an Orders Group (O GROUP) ?  An Orders Group is the method a 
commander uses to give oral (spoken) orders to his subordinates.  Commanders will usually 
prefer to issue orders in person so that they can impose their will and personality on their 
subordinates, emphasise key points and allow subordinates to ask any questions 
immediately.   It is usual for attendees at verbal O Groups to receive printed OSW and traces 
from the Higher HQ.   
7.2. Rehearsals.  An orders group is a stage managed affair. Therefore a rehearsal is 
desirable if not always practical.  
7.3. Reception Arrangements. The bigger the headquarters , the more important the 
reception arrangements for those attending the O Gp. In particular consider:  
• Arrangements for arrivals from outside the headquarters, including guidance on 
where to  park and how to get to the O Gp.  
• Reception arrangements at the O Gp site. For example:  
o When those attending will be allowed access to the site.  
o Arrangements to meet early arrivals.  
o A location for copying of traces and marking maps, and for subordinates to 
read written  orders prior to receipt of oral orders. Ideally the HQ will already 
have prepared traces and OSW for subordinates.  
7.4. Requirements of Those Attending.  Consider the requirements of those attending 
the O Gp. In particular:  
• Where personal equipment can be stowed during their time at the headquarters.  
• Drinks and meals.  
• Communication facilities.  
7.5. Seating Plan.  Although the commander may have his own views on where specific 
individuals are to sit, the general principle is for the main subordinate commanders to sit 
centrally at the front while other individuals, including the staff, sit at the sides. Considerat ion 
should be given to:  
• The availability, number and marking of seats:  
• Displaying a seating plan.  
7.6. Aids .  The aids used at an O Gp will vary. Consider the requirement for a marked 
map, model or diagram, the need for documents, including confirmatory notes, task organisations and the use of PowerPoint (and the availability of reversionary methods should 
power  fail). 
7.7. Post O Gp.   After the O Gp staff cells may use the opportunity to amplify areas of the

8.1. What is LOG KEEPING ?  The log is a record of all activities, all information received  
and all decisions taken by the HQ.  This detail is recorded either electronically or on a log 
sheet.  All operational messages must be logged and acknowledged by a watchkeeper and the information passed to those concerned, both inside and outside the CP. Watchkeepers themselves must understand the commander’s intent and be able to analyse, interpret and 
act on information received.  
8.2. Accurate Records .  The importance of accurate and comprehensive log -keeping 
cannot be overstressed; logs may be required for after action analysis and could be 
particularly relevant in other operations.  The detail on the operations log should be 
circulated within the CP at formation level and above.  The need for a hard copy of the log to 
be passed around a CP will be reduced as more information is stored digitally. The following items should be included in the log:  
•The gist of all radio and telephone conversations, with exact local time and date
group.
•All written messages and reports (hard copy only), both in and out of the HQ.  A l
ong
m
essage may be paraphrased or referred to by file reference and subject.
•Reports from LOs and visitors and any other relevant information received.
•The time of issue of OSW, and the times of dispersal of conferences and orders
groups.
•The movements of the commander and senior staff officers.
•Own or enemy action. Items to be included in SITREPs and the commander’s diaryto be written up effectively from the log.
•Any other significant action such as those of non- military agencies.
The bare facts of events recorded in the log can be obscure to a reader unless they are in close touch with the situation. Time and mental effort can be saved by recording ‘comment’ in the action column of the log to underline the significance of a particular item and by 
marking up items which are likely to be included in the compilation of OWNSITREPs or 
COMBATREPs.  
8.3. What are Reports & R eturns (R2) ?  Reports and Returns are the routine flow of 
information up and down the chain of command, normally tied to the battle rhythm and 
information requirements that have  been established to support the particular 
operation/campaign.  There is no standard R2 battle rhythm across Defence or NATO.  The format of reports will be set out in the HQ Standard Operating Instructions.

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 2020 LAND OV ERLAY OPERATION ORDER (Over lay OPORD or OpO)  
3.1. Introduction .  Overlay O rders  are the combination of written and graphic instructions 
on one trace containing enough info for a commander to carry out his specified tasks.  
3.2. General .  When producing an overlay OpO the maximum amount of information 
should be represented graphically.  The recipient of an order should be able to place the 
trace onto his map and then ‘fight’ from it.  The temptation to produce too much information 
must b e resisted.  The following are only guidelines as production of an overlay OpO 
ultimately entails subjective judgement by author.  Overlays may be produced electronically  
on command systems , as ‘clears’, with or without a map background (‘taciprint’ ) or on paper.  
3.3. General Rules . 
a. The author must be free to put on overlay what he deems necessary.  The 
overlay should show the situation as commander intends/expects it to be when the 
operation is carried out rather than current situation. The difference between ‘actual’ 
and ‘projected’  dispositions must be made clear.  
b. The order may be issued by any suitable method.  
c. The written part of order must follow the same sequence as formal written orders 
and can be produced in manuscript.  
d. The requirements of speed normally dictate that overlays are handwritten and in 
only one colour.  With increased use of digital networks, a combination of typewritten 
text and handwritten or computer -generated graphics may prove a useful alternative 
provided speed is not sacrificed.  
e. A logical way to proceed is to complete graphical overlay first.  It is then easy to 
see what must be included, in addition to the required sections, in the written portion of 
the order either because it has proved difficult to portray or it will cause too much 
clutter on overlay.  
3.4. The Overlay .  The completed overlay should be a distillation of all information 
available to the commander when carrying out the specific task.  Those points which cannot 
readily be transposed to graphics or which would obscure either map or trace detail should 
be wr itten at the side.  Some particular points to note are:  
a. Task Organisation .  Shown diagrammatically anywhere on the overlay.  The ‘No 
changes except’ method should be used if possible.   
b. Enemy.  Information may be given on the overlay, on a separate overlay or by 
reference to other documents such as INTSUMs.  Information which cannot be 
depicted should be written down.  
c. Friendly Forces .  Information concerning friendly forces other than those 
covered by the order, but which affects action of subordinate commanders, can either 
be drawn on overlay or stated in the written portion.   
d. Mission.  Originator’s mission must always be stated in writing.  
e. Colon.  
(1) A colon (:) indicates that detail relevant to subject is included in the 
graphics.  This could mean additional information or repetition of detail given in 
text. 
(2) The colon should appear at the end of the paragraph or sub paragraph 
heading to indicate detail is included in graphics; a colon would never appear 
here under normal rules.  If a colon appears at end of text it indicates the 
introduction of a list.

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 2020  EXAMPLE FRAGMENTARY ORDER (FRAGO)  
4.1. FRAGOs are an abbreviated form of opO.  They may be used in 3 ways:  
• To issue timely changes to existing orders.  This is the most commonly used form 
of a FRAGO.  
• To issue key sects of an order before the complete order has been produced.  
• To provide specific instructions to command ers who do not require the complete 
order.  
4.2. The standard OpO sequence and paragraph headings are used.  However, after the 
headings, parts of the order which are unchanged or not essential are omitted.  In a FRAGO 
issued to amend existing orders it will be usual for the mission  to remain unchanged but for 
the subordinates’ tasks to be amended to reflect new developments in the situation .  If the 
situation has changed to the extent that the mission  has changed the issue of a FRAGO 
would be inappropriate and a new OpO should be issued.  
4.3. Gen written FRAGOs should fol low the normal conventions of operational  SD and the 
rules governing the production of OpOs/overlay OpOs.  There are 2 exceptions:  
• The superscription of a schematic FRAGO can fol any reasonable format (see 
example at Serial 14.  
• The text of a FRAGO disseminated by sig should be in capitals throughout.  
4.4. FRAGOs can be issued in schematic rather than overlay form to allow the order to be 
produced in A4 size.  This facilitates transmission by fax.  Alternatively, electronic mail (E -
Mail) may be used.  
4.5. In the examples that fol low, distribution lists have been cut short to save space.

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 6 – May 2025 TASK ORGANISATION (TASKORG)   
6.1. Conventions.  The grouping of forces for specific operations or phases within operations is 
described by a Task Organisation (TaskOrg).  
a. The aim of graphical task organisation should be to produce a clear, logical and 
unambiguous picture of formations , units  or task specific groupings and their respective states 
of co mmand for an operation or phase of an operation.  For clarity a separate full or 
abbreviated task organisation may be nec essary for each phase of an operation,  when 
regrouping takes place.  
b. The system is best equated to double entry book -keeping, where entries are made both 
in the credit and debit sect ions, in that changes to units  are shown in the attachments  and 
detachments  columns.  
c. Regardless of the template you use, the following  information  should be displayed in the 
columns:  
(1) Level of command in the title box at the head of each column.  
(2) Manoeuvre units operate under a level of com mand  and state of command  of 
each individual unit in main sect of column.  
(3) Units are detached  from a level of comd in ( -) sect of column.  
6.2. Display.  Task Org is displayed in columns.  Each column is headed by the symbol of a 
formation or unit immediately subordinate to the originator (ie a division  operation order  is in brigade 
columns, a brigade operation order  is in regimental , battalion or battle group columns).  Troo ps 
allocated special tasks ( reserves , rear area security , guard , screen, etc) are usually listed under a 
column headed ‘Special Tasks’.   However,  where such a task is to be carried out by one of the 
manoeuvre units  or formatio ns, it may remain in the main body of the task org rather than move to 
‘Special Tasks’ column. Troops  organic to originator ( division al troops , brigade troops ) are listed 
under separate column, ‘Div Tps’ etc, but only changes to such troops  need be shown.  Blank 
columns may be left for the regrouping of formations  or units.  
6.3. States of Comd.  Op comd takes precedence over admin comd.  Within columns all unit 
symbols are gp in the order:  
FULL COMD   ADCON 
OPCOM    ADCON less.... 
OPCON    LOGCON  
TACOM     
TACON    
  
Although operation order  task orgs usually only need to show operational  states of comd, both 
operational  and admin states should be shown if the admin state changes or if there is a need to 
clarify the sit, i.e.:  
(1) OPCOM and ADCON   
(2) OPCOM and ADCON less...  
(3) OPCON and ADCON less...  
(4) OPCON and ADCON  
(5) TACON and ADCON

different conventions on how to display the sub- units organic to that parent unit which are to remain

a. Option 1 . It is sufficient to repeat the regimen t or b attalio n symbol with the addition of a

the column title symbol will be capped to rep resent  an all arms group ( battle group) . 
b. Option 2 .  List every sub -unit in the column as shown in the example below.  
6.6. Detachments . 
a. Where a symbol shows ( -), the detachment  is to be shown in the ( -) sect at the bottom of 
each column.  This rule applies to troops  organic to originator and to non- organic  troops who 
are then split up within the formation  they have come to support .  Non -organic troops  which 
arrive already depleted to support  the formation should have their previous detachment  shown 
against the symbol in the main column.  
b. When a formation  (eg brigade) is detached  from its parent formation  (eg Division ) only 
the brigade HQ and its own Armour and Infantry  units are detached.  If artillery , engineer  or 
other units are also to be det this must be shown under ‘Div Tps’, unless they are themselves 
organic rather than affiliated.  
c. Battlegrouping .1  The combat element of a combined arms group is described in terms 
of the number of subunits of each type it has under command, as follows and in the order of:

6.7. Special Tasks.  If a special task ( brigade Guard, divisional  reserve ) is based on 2 or more 
subunits  of equal size, the command  must be nominated by name or appt and shown in the column.  
6.8. Half Bars .  Half bars are normally only used in relation to the ‘Special Tasks’ columns to 
identify separate states of command when there is more than one group or task  shown in a single 
column.  They follow the rules of paragraph headings in non- op SD: once started they should 
continue to be used down to the next special task or level of command  which is then to be identified  
with a full bar.

1.1. The first output of the Joint Air Estimate is the Joint Air Operations Plan (JAOP), also 
known as the SUPLAN AIR in NATO doctrine. The JAOP is the air commander’s blueprint 
for integrating and coordinating air activities. It should include;  plans to transition from initial 
to sustainment forces as appropriate; plans for conflict termination and the subsequent redeployment of forces; and procedures to be used to capture lessons.  
1.2. The JAOP provides:

ac
tioned, the desired effects and the weight of effort required.
b. The measures or indicators of success that are to be used to determine whether
joint air operations are meeting assigned objectives; accounting for current andpotential enemy offensive and defensive COA.
c. Guidance on synchronising and phasing with the JFC’s OPLAN.
d. Detail on what joint air assets are required to achieve joint air objectives,
including force availability, deployment timing, basing availability and sustainment
requirements.
e. Specific procedures for allocating, tasking, exercising and transitioning the C2 of
joint air assets.
1.3. From the outset the JTF OPLAN and JAOP must consider how to recognise when 
the campaign is reaching, or has achieved, its end -state.  
1.4. The JAOP is implemented through the JFACC’s daily AOD, which provides a detailed 
‘snap- shot’ of the JAOP to be enacted in a specific period (usually 24 hours).

1.1. Battle space Management  (BM) :  Defined as: “ Battlespace management is the use 
of all necessary adaptive means and measures that enable the planned and dynamic 
coordination, synchronization and prioritization of activities across all dimensions of an 
assigned area of operations within the battlespace,”  (AJP-3) .
1.
2. Battlespace : Defined as:  “The environment, factors and conditions that must be 
understood to apply combat power, protect a force or complete a mission successfully. ” 
(AJP-3)
Note: It includes the land, maritime, air  and space domains ; the enemy and friendly forces 
present therein; facilities; terrestrial and space weather; health hazards; terrain; the 
electromagnetic spectrum; and the information environment in the joint operations area and 
other areas of interest.   
1.3.  Purpose. Battlespace management applies at all levels of operations and enables 
operational level activities in cooperation with relevant non -NATO actors. Effective 
battlespace management will ensure the appropriate allocation of three -dimensional space 
and the electromagnetic spectrum, over time, to various competing users, to maximize coordinated and synchronous operational effectiveness, while avoiding confusion leading to 
a risk to the mission and/or the force.  
1.4. Multi -domain Battlespace Management .  BM must be considered in the physical 
and non- physical battlespace across all domains and time.  Particular issues arise at seams 
and boundaries where the activities of different assets and capabilities within the joint force 
interact with or impact others.  
1.5. What is Battlespace Management ? Battle space management (BM) provides a 
number of tools and processes to help co -ordinate, synchronise and prioritise the military 
activity throughout the Joint Task Force.  All the components involved in an operation will 
have their initial battle- space conditions set by the JTFHQ. This will be promulgated in either 
a discrete Joint Battlespace Management Instruction Document or a BM Annex to an OPLAN or OPORD.  BM is controlled by J3/5.  The purpose of BM is to maximise freedom of 
action / manoeuvre across domain boundaries  and to minimise constraints for all battle-
space users, while managing and reducing the risk of blue- on-blue.

(5) OSG assets (incl ARAs / AMAs)   & Unoccupied AMAs  
c. Bids for Landspace . The G3 Ops terrain / ops trace is the authority for unit 
locations and control measures. Units requiring landspace in an area controlled by 
another formation or component must bid through G3 Ops.  
2.3. Fire Support Coordination Measures  (FSCM ). FSCM provide the means to 
separate, synchronise or integrate land, air and maritime Fires to support the manoeuvre 
commander’s intent and operations plan, and to  allow the maximum exploitation of available 
fire support assets while ensuring the safety  of own troops against blue- on-blue. By their 
nature, FSCM tend to be short term and  immediate. It is critical that FSCM are deactivated 
as soon as practical after a fire mission.  FSCM can either be permissive or restr ictive in 
nature. All boundaries are by default  Restricted Fire Lines (RFL):  
a. Permissive Measures . These facilitate the attack of targets. No further 
coordination is required within permissive areas. These include:  
(1) Fire Support Coordination Line (FSCL).  
(2) Free Fire Area (FFA).  
(3) Coordinated Fire Line (CFL).  
b. Restrictive Measures. These provide safeguards to Friendly Forces or objects. 
Their  establishment requires certain coordination to occur prior to the engagement of 
those targets. Restrictive measures include:  
(1) Airspace Coordination Areas (ACA).  
(2) Restrictive Fire Lines (RFL).  
(3) No Fire Areas (NFA).  
(4) Restricted Fire Areas (RFA).

Original MAJCSC SOHB Edition: 1 2 – May 2020 AIR SPACE MANAGEMENT (ASM)  
3.1. General Points .  The airspace within a JOA is a joint environment and therefore it is 
managed on a joint basis.  Responsibility for managing the airspace - the Airspace Control 
Authority (ACA) -  is usually given to the component best able to discharge that responsibility; 
invariably the JFACC.  All users of the airspace must be aware of the problems and the 
measures taken to facilitate ops, identify users and minimize risks.  These measures are 
collectively known as Airspace Control (ASC) and invariably represent a compromise 
between conflicting demands.  ASC is a service to airspace users.  Many land assets, such 
as BH, MLRS, arty, mors, UAVs and GBAD exploit the 3rd dimension.  All require airspace 
and need the minimum of restrictions to achieve tempo.  The ACA constructs an Air Control 
Plan (ACP) to support the Joint Campaign Plan and endeavours to take account of CCs’ requirements to meet the scheme of manoeuvre.  The ACP is fully compatible with the Joint  
Air Defence Plan (ADP).  
3.2. Control .  In the LCC HQ the AD cell will normally be responsible for Airspace Control 
(ASC) matters in conjunction with the LC representative in the Joint Airspace Coordination 
Centre (JACC).  AD coordinates unit ASC, requests Airspace Control Measures (ACM) and 
disseminates Airspace Control Orders (ACO).  Subject to the JTFC priorities the LCC will 
usually have authority over air operations within the LCC AO short of the FSCL once a 
suitable degree of control of the air has been achieved.  ASC is exercised through either 
positive or procedural control and as the operations situation may require a combination of 
both methods they must be complementary.  
3.3. Positive Control .  Relies on positive identification, tracking and direction of a 
platform within designated airspace, conducted with electronic means by an agency with the appropriate authority and responsibility.  Consequently this type of control is asset intensive 
needing equipment such as radar/surv sensors, ID procedures, 2- way comms/data links and 
other C4I elements to track, identify and direct.   
3.4. Procedural Control .  Relies on a combination of previously agreed and promulgated 
orders and procedures.  Procedural control may segment the airspace by volume and time 
and/or the use of weapon control status.  This form of control relies on ACMs and WCOs 
issued via the ACO  and Special Instructions (SPINS) to identify airspace access within 
agreed parameters.   
3.5. Time Deconfliction.
