1. Scope.  This JCO gives executive direction for the conduct of operations during Phase 1 
SHAPE , of Operation SWORD .  This is the phase of the campaign in which the GA is 
PROTECTED  (DC1)  by the CJTF  IOT REASSURE the people of GA and DETER RED Alliance 
(DC3) against aggression and conflict.   This phase will begin with rapid deployment within the JOA 
of Tier 2 and Tier 3 forces.  To enable  this, the MCC will start to SECURE SLOCs throughout the 
SoH and the AG and SUPPORT the deployment of the Tier 3 forces.  In this phase and ongoing 
through to the end of Phase 3, the AC will commence air operations; Air mobility to support 
deployment, ISR to focus on FIND and UNDERSTAND of the of the RED Alliance Force s 
deployments and DCA within sovereign territory to GUARD and SECURE the Alliance. This phase 
will end when all forces are within the JOA at IOC or FOC and Theatre Conditions Are Established  
(DC2).    This JCO describes the totality of the effects that the Joint Task Force (JTF) is to focus 
upon in this phase.  It also details the required synchronised Joint Actions that will realise these 
effects, as well as supporting and coordinating considerations .  The JCO also describes how the 
CJTF will operate with relevant civilian partners during Phase 1. 
2. Timings.   Phase 1 starts today the 1 Oct 20. It will continue until all forces are in the JOA at 
IOC or FOC and w e achieve  DC2, Theatre Conditions Established , expected to be on or around 5 - 
15 Nov 20.  The phase change will be conditions based and will be authorised by the COM CJTF 
at a Joint Coordination Board (JCB).  The conditions include: the achievement of IOC by the CJTF, 
(LCC 4 x Div at IOC; ACC at FOC, and MCC at FOC) and the achievement of DC2 - Theatre 
Conditions Established .    Early move to Phase 2 could be triggered by a significant failure to deter 
the RED Alliance (DC3) .  This will be  indicated by a significant attack by one or both of the RED  
Alliance States  on the GOLD Alliance.    
SITUATION  
3. Overview.  The political situation remains tense .  The RED Alliance continues to increase 
the read iness of their forces, conducting increased levels of training, deployments from home 
bases and  enhanced  patrolling.   Al BWARH and Al SEEL  have taken little notice of the 
International and GOLD Alliance diplomatic engagement  to stop a shift into unrestrained conflict .  
Both RED Alliance states have continued to reiterate claims to various territorial areas and rights to 
hydrocarbon deposits in GOLD Alliance territory . 
4. International and Regional .  There has been widespread international and regional 
engagement with  the RED Alliance Governments  in an effort to stop escalation of the conflict .    
5. Enemy Assessment .  No change to reference A (OPLAN 01 ). Updates will be issued in a 
routine  INTSUM . 
EXECUTION  
6. Intent .  No Change  to Reference A, summarised as : DETER the RED Alliance from further 
attacks and incursions.  PROTECT the GOLD Alliance’s territory and vital interests, REASSURE 
the people, and SECURE our sovereign territorial integrity.

8. Joint Scheme of Manoeuvre . 
a. DC 1: ‘GOLD Alliance PROTECTED’  (ACC Supported).   Timings - Start of Phase 1 
Achieved by phase  start + 15 Days  and maintained for the whole campaign .  
(1) From the very start we must PROTECT the GOLD Alliance  to stop the RED 
Alliance having a substantive harmful influence  or effect  on our CJTF, people s and 
interests.   The Operational Effects to accomplish PROTECT must be executed  in 
every one of the 5 Domains  (Maritime. Land, Air, Space & Cyber/EM)  and so will 
involve the whole  Combined Joint Task Force and civilian agencies .  Physical 
protection from k inetic attack  will be our natural focus  but we must also consider the 
virtual and cognitive aspects  of PROTECT  using information activities  that will be 
especially  important during Phase 1 for both the population and critical infrastructure .  
(2) All physical  & virtual  borders  with the RED Alliance  must be GUARDED  (OE 1.1, 
1.2 & 1.3) . While we expect activity to be focused on N AL SALAAM , the RED Alliance 
have the capability to strike anywhere in the JOA.   Integrated Air Defence (OE 1.4) will 
be essential to Critical National Infrastructure (OE 1.5) but also to we need to 
communicate all our activities to reassure the population  (OE1.6), maintain t heir 
morale  and reduce the effect of conflict on the daily life of our citizens . 
(3) In Phase 1 , all DC 1 related  operational effects and actions will build 
incrementally as force levels increase.   Initially, we will need to rely on the Air 
Component as Land Component force deploy and Maritime Component forces 
redeploy. Our activity  should be mostly  unchallenged b y RED forces  in the physical 
dimension but contested in the virtual and cognitive dimension .  This will change  
significantly in Phase 2  or if major  kinetic offensive conflict starts  early .  Achieving the 
DC 1 PROTECT will then be harder and require a Prioritised Defended Asset List 
(PDAL) and risk/benefit analysis as part of  our b attle rhythm as the GOLD units and 
capabilities are expended or neutralised by enemy actions.

Annex 3D - 1 ANNEX 3 D - SITUATION UPDATE ON 17 OCT 20 
1. Situation as at 17 Oct 20.  At 0530 hrs on 17 Oct 20 Al Bwarh  launched an unprovoked 
limited offensive operation to seize terrain in the north of Al Salaam .   
a. The initial land force offensive consisted of 80 Sep MRR supported by elements of 
Army Troops and limited air operations to achieve control of the air over their own forces .  
The forces penetrated approximately 5 km in the area of the A l Abdali  Border Post (QU 
6030).   
b. Intelligence reports indicate that 2 further regimen ts of 40 MRD are in the final 
stages of deploying and it is assessed that they will cross the border region by 
271200 COCT20 in order to complete the securing of the northern oilfields.  The remainder 
of 1 CAA is continuing to mobili se and is expected to be ready at the beginning of Dec 20. 
2. International condemnation of these actions has been unanimous except for the initial 
response from Al Seel  which ha s stated its support for the actions of Al Bwarh .  Al Seel  is prepared 
to support Al Bwarh  if Al Salaam  or the Gold Alliance  takes any military action against the incursion 
forces.  Al Seel  has raised the readiness levels of its armed forces.  
3. Response .  The following Gold Alliance  response has been planned:  
a. Tier 1 .  The C hief of Staff (C OS) of the Al Salaam  armed forces has been tasked  by 
the GA CJTF  to CONTAIN and BLOCK the border incursion, develop plans for the eviction 
of Al Bwarh  forces (80 Sep MRR ) using Tier 1 forces  and deter further  Red Alliance  
aggression until Tier 2  and Tier 3 regional and international forces arrive . 
b. Tier 2 .  The Gold Alliance  has agreed to the immediate deployment of Force 
Elements of the Peninsular Shield Force (PSF) to support Al Salaam  if required.  
c. Tier 3 .  The Gold Alliance  has conducted initial planning and has stated that it 
considers itself capable of achieving its initial military objectives against Al Bwarh  armed 
forces  by deploying the PSF .  However , the Gold Alliance  has requested international 
assistance in the event that Al Bwarh  expands its limited attack or is reinforced by Al Seel  
forces . Additionally, there is a possibility  that Al Seel  forces may act independently 
elsewhere in the GA territory to take advantage of the current unstable situation.  The UK 
and US have commenced the deployment of Force Elements to the region in anticipation of 
a broader Red Alliance  action and to demonstrate political support of the Gold Alliance . 
4. Command and Control .  The command structure for Tier 1 operations is shown in the 
Gold Alliance Handbook (Section 1, Para 8).  The command structure for Tier 2 and Tier 3 
operations is explained in Para 9 of Section 1 of the G old Alliance  Handbook .

1. Scope.  This JCO gives executive direction for the conduct of operations during Phase 2  
ENGAGE , of Operation SWORD .  This is the phase of the campaign in which the CJTF establishes 
control of the air (DC4), completes the securing of the sea LOCs (DC5), clears RED forces from 
GOLD territory (DC6) and re -secures territorial integrity (DC7).   This JCO describes the totality of 
the effects that the Joint Task Force (JTF) is to focus upon in this phase.  It also details the 
required synchronised Joint Actions that will realise these effects, as well as suppo rting and 
coordinating considerations.  The JCO also describes how the CJTF will operate with relevant 
civilian partners during Phase 2.  
2. Timings.   The CJTF move to Phase 2  ENGAGE  is conditions based  and controlled by DP1 .  
These conditions are: 
a. The success of t heatre conditions established  (DC2) . 
b. The failure to achieve  RED Alliance DETERED (DC3).   
SITUATION  
3. Overview.  The political situation has not improved and there is no indication that the RED 
Alliance is seeking a diplomatic settlement to the situation .  Isolated and geographically limited 
military conflict has commenced.  
4. International and Regional .  There has been widespread international and regional 
condemnation of Red Alliance offensive military activity in the North of AL SALAAM.  The Supreme 
Council of the GOLD Alliance has issued a statement condemning the RED Alliance actions and 
urging them to withdraw quickly from AL SALAAM territory before the clashes escalate out of 
control.  
5. Enemy Assessment .   
a. The initial RED land force offensive consisted of 80 Sep MRR supported by elements 
of Army Troops and limited air operations to achieve control of the air where and when 
required.  The forces penetrated approximately 5 km in the area of the AL ABDALI Border 
Post (QU 6030).  Before being blocked by 1(SA) Div.    
b. The 40 MRD is expected to cross the border region by 271200 COCT 20 in order to 
complete the securing of the northern oilfields.   
c. The remainder of 1 CAA  (50 MR Div, 60 Tk Div, 70 Tk Div, 31 Tk Regt and 35 Sep MR 
Regt)  is continuing to mobilise and is expected to be ready at the beginning of Dec 20.

escalation of the conflict.  If RED do not withdraw  but tries to  reinforce , we will DEFEAT and 
CLEAR the enemy from GOLD Alliance Territory.  This may also require attacks on RED Alliance

i RED ALLIANCE HANDBOOK EDITION  4 –2025 
INTRODUCTION  
1. The Red Alliance Handbook  provides a Generic Enemy Force  reference document  for 
Mubarak Al Abdullah Joint Command and Staff College (MAJCSC)  exercises .  The concept of a 
GENFORCE (or a Generic Enemy Force) was developed in the UK to provide details of an enemy 
force against which the British Armed Forces  could plan and train.  The MAJCSC version 
consider s both Operational Art and Tactical Doctrine, and the Organisation and Equipment of a 
generic enemy force based loosely on post -Soviet Russian doctrine and equipment.  Whilst this 
handbook still extracts  some of the information from this post-soviet  period , it has been 
significantly updated and its  scope extended  to include global maritime and air forces  equipment . 
2. During exercises, students will fight against elements of Red Alliance forces.  The land 
forces of the Red Alliance are focused on a Combined Arms Army (CAA) and provide detail down 
to battalion level.  The maritime and air forces are based on a wide range of equipment and 
systems sourced from around the world.  They are not representative of the forces of any real 
nation and contain combinations of weapons and platforms that may not exist in the real world.  
3. This handbook is designed to support all the exercises conducted at the MAJCSC that 
involve the nations of the Red Alliance from the conduct of the initial Intelligence Preparation of the 
(Land) Environment (IPE) exercise in Term 2 through to Exercise AMEL  AL MUSHTARAK, the 
capstone exercise at the end of the course.  
4. Chapter 1 provides an insight into how Red Alliance forces fight at the operational and 
tactical levels, with some useful planning yardsticks.  Chapter 2 shows how the Red Alliance forces 
are organised  with equipment numbers, characteristics and photographs.  
5. Any comments on the content and layout of this handbook should be passed to the 
sponsor; the Course Development Team.

CONCEPTS AND DOCTRINE  
SECTION 1 : RED ALLIANCE  PRINCIPLES OF WAR  
1. The Red Alliance  principles of war apply across all domains;  however, their application will 
not always be equal.  Whilst the principle of ‘concentration of force’ will always apply to some 
degree, the requirements for concentration will differ significantly across the domains.  It is 
recognised that these ‘principles of war’ are somewhat land -centric,  but this is no different from 
their application in the West and Red Alliance  commanders in the other domains are expected to 
apply them appropriately.  
2. Selection and Maintenance of the Aim .  In selecting the aim,  Red Alliance  commanders 
are taught to emphasise the destruction of the enemy.  
a. Operational Art .  The ultimate aim of any operation involving the Red Alliance  is 
the utter defeat of the  enemy.   In future war  they will seek to fix  the enemy’s main striking 
power which will reside  in his fixed  and rotary wing aviation, missiles, long -range artillery 
and electronic warfare ( EW) capabilities,  and in  the Command, Control, Communications 
and Information ( C3I) systems  that direct them.  The primary task will thus always be the 
destruction  of these means through the conduct of deep operations  on land and from the 
sea.  Red Alliance  doctrine is increasingly manoeuvrist which, along with an aggressive 
procurement strategy, has significantly impro ved their effectiveness.  
b. Tactics .  Red Alliance  commanders at division  / regiment  and regiment  / battalion 
will be  expected to demonstrate much greater initiative in decision -making than in the  past 
and to rely much less on passing responsibility back up the chain of  command.   Though a 
new concept for many of them, ‘mission command’ as understood in the west in 
increasingly practised at all levels, significantly increasing their effectiveness.  
3. Surprise .  Surprise is considered an increasingly important component of victory.   As the 
range, accuracy and  destructiveness of weaponry increases, surprise also becomes essential not 
merely  to victory but to survival in the face of modern weaponry.  It prevents the enemy  from 
optim ising the use of his forces and shortens drastically his available reaction  times, thereby 
helping to preserve combat effectiveness.  
4. Offensive Action .  In early versions of Red Alliance  doctrine this was known, somewhat 
clumsily, as ‘Activeness and Speed ’.  ‘Success in an operation or battle is achieved by that  side 
which, all else being equal, acts more actively and resolutely, takes the initiative  and holds it firmly.  
A side which only defends is inevitably doomed to defeat. ’  Thus , a prominent Red Alliance  
commander demonstrates  the obsession with  seizing  and holding the initiative , whether in attack 
or defence.  
a. Significance of the Initiative .  The advantages which accrue to the defence  from 
ground, concealment and modern firepower are all outweighed, in  Red Alliance  eyes, by 
the advantage which poss ession of the initiative impart s to the attacker.   At all times, the 
Red Alliance  endeavours to maintain  an offensive state of mind in its commanders.  
b. Constant Pressure .  There must be no let -up in the attack or counterattack  and 
every effort must be made to tur n offensive action into pursuit.  Where  necessary, 
momentum will be maintained through the acceptance of casualties,  loss of men and 
equipment being more acceptable than loss of time.   Time is  seen to be the most precious 
commodity in modern war .  Plainly,  this principle is more difficult to li ve up to when on the 
defensive.  
c. Tempo .  Pressure on the enemy is not enough in and of itself.  A merely attritional  
approach will grind down both sides .  The enemy must be unbalanced,  his command and 
control must be disrupted,  and the will of his commanders  paralysed, and his forces must 
be split up into isolated and demoral ised fragments which can be destroyed in detail.   In the 
offensive, this is  accomplished by achieving as early as possible a high tempo of 
operations .  The greatest possible  stress is laid on manoeuvre.  Bypassing will  usually be 
Edition  4 
1-1-2 preferred to direct assault.  In the defence, emphasis is now placed on rapid regrouping 
and reaction by reserves.   Transition to the  counter -attack  / strike and counter -offensive is 
always the goal.  In both offense and defence , the greatest possible stress is placed on the 
speedy reactions of air, missile  and artillery strike systems , and the use of maritime and air 
mobil ity to carry the battle into the enemy’s depth.  
5. Concentration  of Force .  Success stems from the concentration of superior force at the  
decisive time and place.  A defender, overstretched by being given an excessive sector  to defend, 
can be defeated by an attacker with litt le or no overall superiority but possessing the initiative and 
with the freedom to concentrate his efforts at the chosen  point of attack.  
a. Approach to Concentration .  The Red Alliance  follows 5 complementary  
approaches to the problems of concentration to achieve the requisite correlation  of forces in 
the offensive.   This is particularly evident in the land domain.  
(1) Manoeuvre .  A superior enemy cannot be defeated in an attritional struggle.  
Only manoeuvre to create counter -concentrations and surprise will bring success.  
(2) Deception .  The enemy must be persuaded through deception and feints to 
concentrate  his forces on false axes, thus lowering the density of his offensive or 
defence  on the chosen axes.  
(3) Concentration of Fire .  Rather than massing forces to overwhelm the  
enemy, fire s and electronic attack should be concentrated  on the selected sector 
from widely dispersed long -range systems, ships , submarines  and aircraft . 
(4) March Separately, Fight Together .  In the land domain, f ormations and 
manoeuvre units will  advance rapidly from dispersed locations in depth, moving in 
more or less  parallel columns and converging only at the last minute on the chosen  
sector.  The most sudden and dramatic method of altering the  correlation of forces 
on the chosen sector will be provided by air -mobility  or by amphibious operations 
from the sea . 
(5) Dispersal .  Concealed dispersion of units over a wide area, with regular re -
location, aims to minim ise the effect of enemy strikes .  The use of amphibious 
forces which allow the sea -basing of troops, vehicles, equipment and logistic 
support are becoming increasingly important to Red Alliance  commanders.  
b. Maintaining a Favourable Correlation of Forces .  Having broken through, 
advancing forces will disperse to advance on multiple axes, but always with several 
columns within supporting distance.  Such a pattern of advance will fragment the enemy 
and complicate his use of reserves, maintaining the initially favourable correlation of forces.  
6. Action Throughout the Enemy’s Depth .  The need to attack the enemy simultaneously 
throughout  the entire depth of his deployment is a long-established  Red Alliance  principle.   In the 
offensive it is necessary to destabil ise the defence at the earliest  possible moment.  Keys to 
accomplishing this are the disruption of enemy C3I and  logistic support, the destruction, disruption 
or fixing of tactical and immediate  operational reserves , and the early seizure of vital ground in the 
depth on which  the enemy could re-establish his defence if given the opportunity ( eg obstacle  
crossings, defiles, crossroads  etc).  Raiding detachments and deep strikes have become the 
cutting edge of contemporary formations, whether in attack or defence.  A regiment  may be tasked 
as an exploitation echelon by higher formations .  A combined arms battalion will often be sent out 
as a raiding or forward detachment.   Even in defence, observation of this principle is critical.  The 
considerable increase in air -mobility  and the fragmented, non -linear nature of the battlefield will 
combine to make  the insertion of raiding forces and forward detachments much easier than it  was 
previously, whether in attack or in defence.   Deep strike by air assets can also achieve the same 
effect.  
7. Realism .  The successful commander is the one who best  balances the risks he faces so 
that he can achieve his aim whatever counter -move  the enemy may undertake.  Essential to this 
outcome is continuous and effective  intelligence gathering, surveillance and reconnaissance at all 
levels.

1-1-38. Cooperation .  As all arms are integrated into the battalion structure  and work  and train
together, commanders can fully understand their individual  strengths and weaknesses and staffs
become accustomed to coordinating their  actions.  In recent years, the Red Alliance  has become
increasingly manoeuvrist and concurrently has developed a more sophisticated Joint doctrine.
Integration of air power into the overall campaign plus increasing use of Close Air Support (CAS)
on the battlefields have become hallmarks of Red Alliance  ground operations which will be
supported, where appropriate,  with maritime power from the sea .  Specifically , these include the
use of amphibious forces for maritime power projection along with maritime fires, predominantly
Naval Gunfire Support (NGS) to land operations.  The use of aircraft in the Counter Sea role where
air power is used to support and protect maritime operations is increasingly evident.
9. Preservation of Combat Effectiveness of Own Troops .  Routing the enemy is not
enough if one’s own combat  effectiveness does not remain high enough to preserve the fruits of
victory.   The Red Alliance  currently sees 4 solutions to this problem :
a. Maximum use of offensive action.
b. Concealment, deception and disinformation are now considered crucial.
c. The Restoration of Combat Effectiveness after devastating strikes is a great
concern.
d. The Red Alliance  has devised a logistics system which is designed to cope with fast
moving, manoeuvre -dominated operations where there are no clearly defined front lines or
safe rear areas.
10. Pre-emption .  Combining elements of manoeuvrism with the traditional Soviet approach of
using shock armies to overrun an ill -prepared enemy, pre -emption has recently been adopted by
the Red Alliance  as a principle of war.  They may therefore be expected to act offensively before
other means might be considered to be exhausted thereby surprising the enemy, inducing shock
and confusion through the use of the unexpected
.

1-2-1 SECTION 2: JOINT INTELLIGENCE, SURVEILLANCE AND RECONNAISSANCE  (ISR)  
11. Joint Assets .  In the air and maritime domain , commanders will have a significant number 
of their own dedicated Intelligence, Surveillance, Target Acquisition and Reconnaissance (ISTAR) 
assets though they will still rely on Joint assets for completion of the Recognised Air and Maritime 
Pictures (RAP and RMP).  Most of a tactical land formation’s intelligence on the situation in its 
zone of general reconnaissance will come from higher formations.  At divisional and regiment level, 
formations will be direct recipients of the relevant product  of operatio nal reconnaissance.  
a. Satellites .  The Red Alliance  deploys  operational strategic surveillance satellites.  
Using electro -optical, infra -red line scan (IRLS), synthetic aperture radar (SAR) , and radar 
and radio intercept sensors, these have an all -weather, day and night capability and, 
combined with relay satellites, report in near -real time.  The deep coverage  of satellites 
enables the Red Alliance  to make full use of the reach of long -range  Surface to Surface 
Missiles (S SM) and cruise missiles.  Mobile ground stations for receiving and  processing 
data are now deployed down to divisional level . 
b. Unmanned Aerial Systems .  Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS)  are used to 
penetrate into areas where air defences are known to be  dense: not only is a pilot thus not 
put at risk, but the small size of the platform  reduces its detectability and vulnerability.  Air 
Forces operate the Shahed 129A  UAS with a n endurance of 24 hrs  and a range of 540 km.  
With their  real-time reporting capability, these multi -sensor UAS can be used not only  for 
operational reconnaissance but as  the eyes of Reconnaissance Strike Complexe s (RSC)1 
at army  level using SS -21 Scarab -B (Tochka ) tactical ballistic missiles , and at the joint level 
using cruise m issiles and operational SSMs as the strike component.  Such UAS also 
provide post -strike reconnaissance to  aid the Battle Damage Assessment ( BDA) process.  
c. Manned Aircraft .  Aircraft are more  responsive than satellites.  They have a longer 
range and faster transit time  to the target than UAS and are not, like the latter, vulnerable to 
jamming of  the link with the ground controller.   The Red Alliance  Air Commander will have 
access to the SU -24MR Fencer reconnaissance aircraft  and reconnaissance pods may 
attached to other aircraft.  
d. SIGINT .  Although satellites and aircraft are now the main tactical Signals  
Intelligence (SIGINT) collectors at the operational level, the Joint Force Commander  (JFC) 
has substantial numbers of ground -based D irection Finding (DF)  and intercept troops.  
e. Special Purpose Forces (SPF) .  The Red Alliance  JFC has a formation  of SPF  
which operate in a similar manner to western Special Forces .  Ideally at least some of the 
deep reconnaissance patrols  formed from these troops will be inserted covertly before 
hostilities begin.   Otherwise,  they may be deployed by parachute (often using a high -
altitude,  low-opening technique), by helicopter, by microlight  (a favoured method) or  by 
ground infiltration.

1-3-8 LAND FORCES – OFFENSIVE OPERATION S 
23. Army Offensive Operations .  Generally speaking , Combined Arms Armies are used t o 
conduct penetrations, to act on secondary sectors, to operate in difficult terrain or to form second 
echelons or reserves.  Tank armies usually act in the second echelon when attacking a strong 
enemy, or as the operational exploitation echelon.  There are basically 4 forms of offensive 
operation, though elements of them may be combined : 
a. The Single Thrust .  This is most common when the enemy defence is strong, well 
prepared and deeply echeloned.  In these circumstances most of the army’s strength has to 
be concentrated on a narrow sector to achieve a breakthrough, widen the penetration 
sector to permit the insertion of operational manoeuvre forces.  
b. Encirclement .  An army is too small to execute an encirclement of operational 
scale by itself.  There may, however, be opportunities, particularly when launching a 
counter -attack , to eliminate a badly balanced enemy grouping.  
c. An Attack  from One Flank .  A variation on the theme of encirclement is the 
crushing of the enemy against an obstacle.  In coastal  operations, where the obstacle is the 
sea, annihilation will be complete , particularly when maritime fires are employed to project 
force from the sea against the enemy formation .  The concentrated attack  from one flank is 
also used to encircle a much larger enemy grouping in cooperation with the forces of 
another army formation, or to turn the position of the main enemy grouping so that it can be 
destroyed in flank and rear attacks.  
d. Offensive on Several Axes .  Two or more rupturing attack s may be delivered to 
achieve the disintegration of the enemy grouping, splitting it up into isolated pockets.  This 
sort of operation can be undertaken when the enemy’s defence is hasty, over -extended, 
lacking in depth and without  a strong reserve.  It is also the most appropriate model when 
the enemy is quite strong but has chosen to adopt manoeuvre defence rather than try and 
hold forward.  
24. Differing Requirements for Concentration .  In the offensive a numerical superiority of 
between 3:1 and 4:1 is considered acceptable on operationally decisive axes.  At the tactical level 
in the land domain, much will depend on the circumstances of the battle.  Attacking a strong 
enemy in prepared defences on an axis of main effort requires a superiority of between  5:1 and 6:1 
to ensure success.  In a meeting battle, an advantage of 1.5:1 is considered adequate and even 
parity may be accepted.  
25. Attack Echelons .  The Red Alliance  will echelon forces at the operational level (with CAAs 
forming 1st and 2nd operational echelons) and at the tactical level (with divisions forming 1st and 2nd 
tactical echelons).  Against a world class enemy heavy division deployed on a 30 km front with a 
depth of 50 km, the Red Alliance  sees the need to deploy a deeply echeloned attack .  Attack 
echelons are formed to break through the enemy’s tactical zone of defence and defeat the 
enemy’s immediate operational reserves.  Thereafter, they continue the advance into the enemy’s 
depth.  
a. The First Operational Echelon .  The first operational echelon conducts the first 
mission of the operation: the penetration of the defence.  The bulk of the formation will be 
located in the first echelon.  Its task is to defeat the enemy’s corresponding first echelon 
(the immediate mis sion) and develop the offensive into his depth (subsequent mission).  If 
the senior commander’s calculations have been done properly, the first echelon should be 
capable of penetrating to the entire tactical depth of the defenc e before additional forces 
have to be committed to maintain momentum.  
b. The Second Operational Echelon .  The second operational echelon, if formed, is 
tasked with augmenting the efforts of the first.  Its role is to develop the success achieved 
by the first echelon on the main axis.  Thus, it may: conduct pursuit; breach defence zones 
in the depth; defeat counter -attack groupings (ideally d estroying them in meeting battles 
through flank and rear attacks); destroy by -passed ‘islands of resistance’ which threaten 
the development of the operation or unduly restrict deployment and limit the operational 
Edition 4 
1-3-9 flexibility of the higher formation.  Only when resistance is unexpectedly effective will the 
second echelon replace the first.  That implies fighting the first echelon to a standstill and 
then suffering an operational pause: 2 cardinal crimes in the Red Alliance  military lexicon.  
Note that the Red Alliance  will reinforce success, applying second echelon pressure to the 
most successful first echelon attack.  
c. The Exploitation Echelon .  The exploitation echelon may have to complete the 
penetration of the tactical zone of defence if time would otherwise be lost.  Ideally, 
however, it is committed through a clear breach or gap in the enemy’s deployment or, 
perhaps, infiltrated through in  small packets and reunited in the enemy’s rear.  Its role is the 
conversion of tactical into operational success.  The exploitation echelon, working in close 
cooperation with air -delivered forces, collapses the defence from within.   By attacking the 
command and control, long -range weapons and logistical support of the enemy’s first 
echelon, and by engaging the operational reserves and seizing depth defence lines before 
they can be occupied, they help to precipitate the collapse of t he defence.   
d. Echelon Changes . In line with the RA Principle of War; Offensive Action – maintain 
constant pressure and tempo.  It is assessed that  when a 1st Tac Echelon reaches 50% 
combat effectiveness the 2nd Tac Echelon will be committed to carry on the attack and 
become the exploitation echelon.  The 1st Tac Echelon will then regenerate or rehabilitate.  
26. Main Effort .  A formation on the commander’s main effort can expect to be reinforced by 
additional strike assets, for example elements of the R egimental Artillery Group (RA G), DAG or 
AAG, by combat aviation, and by additional engineer effort and extra air defence  assets . 
 
Note: All Red Alliance  units and formations can be split into echelons.  An echelon is a name given 
to the organisation of formations at each level of command from lower tactical level to operational 
formations.

1-3-10 26. Developing the Deep Battle .  For strategic goals to be achieved in good time, it is 
necessary from the earliest moment to develop deep battle, using forward, raiding and heliborne  
detachments, and then, as a result of successful tactical manoeuvre , to conduct deep operations 
with OMGs working in concert with air and airborne assault forces  (when air defences are weak) . 
a. Missiles .  Army Surface to Surface Missile regiment s will always remain under 
army  or JFC  control for the conduct of the deep fire battle.  Formations on key operational 
axes will be reinforced with SSM formations from the JFC.  The missiles will be the basis of 
the main Reconnaissance  Strike Complexes.   Land Attack Missiles could be fired from 
ships and submarines but no vessels are believed currently to fitted with this capability.  
b. Artillery .  Strong army artillery groups  will be formed, with organic long -range  
assets being augmented from the JFC’s  resources.  Usually there will also be an  army  
group of rocket artillery  and maritime fires (naval gunfire support) may be available close to 
the c oast.  These groups deploy  over considerable areas but their central ised control 
ensures the  concentration of fire on the main sector .  This and the rapid manoeuvre of 
massed  fire in support of the penetration and committal of second or exploitation  echelons , 
as well as the effective waging of the deep fire struggle , is critical to the winning of fire 
superiorit y.  The importance of the role of artillery can be gauged from the fact  that the Red 
Alliance  expects up to 40  to 45 % of the destruction visited on the  enemy in the tactical 
zone to be inflicted by it.  
c. Aviation .  Attack helicopter s and ground attack aircraft  are normally held under the 
central ised control  of the Air Commander reflecting the increasing preference for joint 
operations within a single, unified command .  They are likely to be employed together in 
large mixed raids against the enemy’s operational -tactical depth, supported  by the 
suppression of enemy air defence s by missiles, artillery, aviation and ECM.  Elements may 
also be placed under command of forward or raiding detachments, forming land -air 
groupings.  Their other r ole is to provide flexible, rapid reacting fire support for the contact 
battle.  The Red Alliance  expects aviation to account for up to 40  to 45 % of the destruction 
visited upon the enemy in the tactical zone.  Support  helicopter s are used to deliver 
heliborne assault but can also be used in the attack helicopter role.  
d. Special Purpose Forces .  SPF are used for reconnaissance , target designation 
and sabotage.  Each a rmy has a n SPF  battalion and each division has a n SPF  company 
within the organic reconnaissance  battalion.  
e. Heliborne and Airborne Operations .  The organic separate light motor rifle 
battalions are well trained in heliborne assault  to secure deep tactical objectives or conduct 
raids.  At army level, the air assault  battalion , mounted in BMD  airborne infantry fighting 
vehicles , might expect to seize  and hold ground in the operational depth for between 18 
and 24 hours if well supported by attack helicopters and ground attack aircraft.  Airborne 
(parachute) insertion is usually a strategic operation at regimental strength 150  to 300 km 
deep.  These forces are often held as a strategic reserve.  
27. Dimensions of an Army Offensive .  The following generali sations are the broadest of 
guidelines only:   
a. Width .  The sector of responsibility of a main axis formation of 4  or 5 divisions is 
likely to be 100  to 120 km  in ‘normal ’ conditions.  On secondary sectors, or sectors where 
the enemy’s force density is inadequate to create any effective defence, the frontage may 
grow to 120 to150 km  or even more.  Penetration sectors are as little as 10  to16 km for 2 
divisions.  
b. Depth .  The depth of a first echelon army’s immediate mission will normally be 
about 100  to 120 km  (ie, the depth of a defending corps).  Against a strong, well prepared 
defence, however, it could shrink to 80  to100 km .   
28. Rates of Advance and Duration .  On the main axis, the Red Alliance  usually plans on 
achieving an average rate of advance of 15 to 20 km per day in ‘normal ’ (unrestricted) terrain and 
10 to 15 in low mountainous or other difficult going  (restricted) .  These calculations assume that

30. RED  Land Forces  - Forms of Tactical Manoeuvre . 
 
31. Types of Attack .  The Red Alliance  defines types of attack in terms of the enemy’s tactical 
posture.  
a. Attack from a Position of Close Contact .  This attack is conducted by a force 
already in close contact with the enemy  in a strongly defended position .  It is characterised 
by detailed reconnaissance  and heavy artillery  preparation followed by an assault on a 
narrow front.  The Red Alliance  believes it will be less frequent than attacks from the march 
in future war.  

Edition 4 
1-3-12 b. Meeting Battle .  A meeting engagement is conducted when 2 attacking forces 
move towards each other.  This form of attack is characterised by surprise, little knowledge 
of the enemy situation and the need for quick decision making.  It is normally conducted 
during a tactical march or following a breakthrough against enemy reserves moving 
forward.   The Red Alliance  believes that this will be the most common form of combat on 
the manoeuvre -dominated, ever -changing battlefield of the next war.  As the Red Allia nce 
unit advances in tactical march formation, the action in a meeting battle usually follows the 
sequence below.  
(1) Location and Identification of an Approaching Enemy .  One of the first 
reactions of the Red Alliance  commander will be to direct his own reconnaissance 
assets to provide more detail of the enemy’s location, strength, movements and  
intentions.  
(2) Selection of the Point of Contact .  The Red Alliance  commander will 
assess the locations of the opposing forces and their speed of advance and  will plot 
the likely line of contact on his map.  From a map assessment he determines the 
location of the key terrain in that area.  It is vital to seize  this ground before the 
enemy and this task may be allocated to a forward detachment or to leading march 
security elements.  It may be necessary to slow the enemy down .  Remote mining 
and / or air attack may be used to accomplish this, as may the actions of a forward 
detachment.  
(3) Engagement of the Enemy .  Precision air, long -range artillery and remote 
mining attacks will be delivered against the approaching enemy .  Speed and shock 
action are paramount.  The forward march security elements will occupy a blocking 
position and begin engaging the approaching forces.  Attached artillery will also 
deploy as rapidly as possible and open fire.  Anti-tank elements should be well 
forward in the march formation so that they may join in the task of pinning the 
enemy force.  The main body should deploy to the selected assault position without 
delay and strike the enemy’s main body as it advances to support its forward 
elements.   Ideally the enemy is then distracted and assaulted while on the move or 
deployin g, preferably from a flank or even both flanks.  
c. Pursuit .  A pursuit is mounted against withdrawing enemy forces.  The Red Alliance  
will attempt to maintain pressure on the enemy to slow the withdrawal.  Attempts will be 
made to encircle and destroy the enemy.  The Red Alliance  may use air assault troops to 
establish blocking positions along the withdrawal route and use fast moving units on 
parallel routes to overtake withdrawing enemy.  
d. Attack from  the Line of March .  An attack from the line of march may be  
conducted from the tactical march and when not in contact with the enemy prior to the 
attack.   It is normally conducted against enemy in a hasty defence position.  The Red 
Alliance  frontage will narrow on approach to the enemy position to maximise chances of a 
breakthrough.

(2) Direct fire support will be given by the troops already in contact, probably 
augmented by elements temporarily detached from the A nti-Tank Reserves (ATR) .  
Both first echelon regiments will form RAGs with artillery decentral ised from

32. Objectives .  An objective is more akin to a NATO Phase Line rather than a point target and 
hence will normally follow a linear terrain feature whenever possible.  An en emy commander’s 
intention is focused primarily on destroying an enemy who may stop him from reaching his 
objective.  Once an objective is achieved an attacking force is expected to continue for as long as 
it is combat effective (CE).  At the tactical level commanders give their subordinates an 
IMMEDIATE and SUBSEQUENT objective.   If the subsequent objective is achieved a CE unit is 
given a direction in which to advance . 
33. Echelons .  Red Alliance  land forces will attack in 2 echelons at each level: tactical and 
operational, ie 1st tactical echelon and the  2nd tactical echelon of the 1st operational echelon.  The 
1st echelon contains 1/2 to 2/3 of the echelon combat power, with the remainder in the 2nd 
echelon.  The first echelon mission is to achieve the immediate objective.  If achieved, the 2nd may 
be tasked with the subsequent objective with the 1st reverting to a reserve.  The Red Alliance  uses 
single  echelon formations w hen the enemy is not defending in depth or when attacking along a 
secondary axis.  It will commit the 2nd echelon only to reinforce success, not to replace  the 1st 
echelon.  If committed , the 2nd echelon will move through gaps between the 1st echelon or around 
a flank; forward passage of lines is rarely used and will be avoided whenever possible.  When 
committed the 2nd echelon is supported by artillery , air and smoke.  The 2nd echelon is also used 
as a counter attack force, to destroy by passed enemy or to  conduct a pursuit.

35. Criteria for Success  in Attack .  Three indicators are used to assess the success of an  
operation:  
• the degree of destruction inflicted on the enemy  
• the depth of  penetration achieved  
• and the degree to which the fighting power of the formation  is preserved, at least on the 
main axis.  
The degree of destruction to be imposed  on the enemy is said to be at least 50% of his initial 
strength and at least 75% of  his high value systems and the ruination of his command -and-control  
system,  for these together will render the enemy combat ineffective. The degree of  penetration 
demanded will vary according to relative strengths, terrain and other  factors. The third indicator is 
relative. The ability of the attacker to maintain the  offensive is a function of the loss rates of both 
sides. If the defen der has lost not less than 50% and the attacker not more than 40%, momentum 
can be maintained: (losses even greater than 40% can be accepted if a slight superiority in 
numbers remains and the enemy’s morale has been broken.) . The operation is considered a 
success if all three criteria are  met, partially if only the second is achieved and not at all if the 
depth of penetration  is inadequate.

36. Types of Defence .  The following types of defence can be hasty or deliberate:  
a. Positional Defence .  Positional defence is the norm when adequate forces are 
available to achieve an efficient density of  weapons (especially anti -tank) or key  areas must 
be held .  See Page 1 -3-20 which shows a Motor Rifle  Division  in defence.  A positional 
defence is designed to be penetrated but only to create the conditions for a decisive 
counter attack.   The ground will offer relatively few opportunities for the conduct of 
positional defence at the operational level, though some favourable sectors may be held 
positionally in manoeuvre defence to provide a pivot for the manoeuvre of counter -attack 
forces.  
b. Positional Defence in the Desert .  Defensive positions are based on terrain which 
constrains flanking moves and channels frontal attacks, ie mountainous areas, 
escarpments, soft sand or salt flats.  Ideally, defences are sited in broken country which 
aids concealment and slows the enemy.  Wadis and depressions are exploited to hide and 
protect both defences and second echelons / reserves, and a good network of roads / 
tracks is desirable for the rapid manoeuvre of the latter.  As in manoeuvre defence, except 
on the rare occasion when there  are no flanks to turn, positional defence requires that a 
good half of a defending formation is deployed in the second echelon / reserve.  The 
counter -attack, particularly against an enveloping attack, is the critical element in desert 
defence, on which the stability of the defence rests.

37. Terminology and Concepts used in Operational and Tactical Defence . 
a. Covering Forces .  A Covering Force is organised at Joint Force or army level.  It 
will comprise 1  to 2 lower formations, deployed up to 50 to 60 km in front of the Main 
Defensive Area.  On conclusion of its delaying task, the covering force will fall back into the 
second echelon or reserve and carry out refurbishment.  Its roles are : 
(1) To determine the composition and strength of the attacker, his chosen axes 
and intentions.  
(2) To force the enemy into premature deployment on successive delay lines 
thus winning time for the organization of the main defences and counter moves.  
(3) To force the enemy to concentrate and thus offer a rich target array for 
deep -strike weapons (including aviation).  
(4) To channel the enemy into the strongest part of the main defences 
(especially fire pockets); wear down and disrupt the attacker; conceal the true 
location of the forward edge.  
b. Types of Covering Forces .  The types of c overing forces found at the tactical level 
are: 
(1) Forward Detachment .  A Forward Detachment is an all arms grouping 
organ ised at army or divisional level and only when there is no covering force out in 
front.  The forward detachment is pushed up to 20  km in front of the forward edge , 
into a Security Zone , and will delay on 2  to 3 lines before reverting to formation 
reserve or second echelon for refurbishment.   Page 1 -3-22 shows a typical layout.  
(2) Forward Positions .  Forward Positions are composed of a reinforced 
company in strength, deployed 3  to 6 km beyond the forward edge on the most 
threatened axis for their parent unit.  
(3) Combat Security Outposts .  A unit commander may well order that a 
second echelon company temporarily detach es a platoon to form a combat security 
outpost up to 2  km in front of the forward edge on an approach not cover ed by a 
forward position.  
c. Combat Support in the Security Zone .  Each battalion acting in the first  echelon 
of a covering force will have at least one , and usually 2, artillery  battalions in direct support , 
and is likely to receive C lose Air Support  at critical moments .  There will be other long -
range artillery , Multi Barrelled Rocket Launchers  and target acquisition means deployed in 
the zone.   Together with air attack, the artillery battalion’s role is to wear down and disrupt 
the enemy long before he  reaches the forward edge  of the Main Defensive Area .  Strong air 
defence groups will be formed to protect deep fire groups, HQs and logistic support against 
air, missile and heliborne  / airborne attacks.  
Edition 4 
1-3-19 d. Counter A ttacks .  Counter attacks are considered to be the decisive moment in 
defence and all available resources will be committed to them. This is the main function of 
the second echelon, which will be armour heavy. Fire support will come from the Divisional 
Artillery Groups (DAG) of both first and second echelon divisions and the Army Artillery 
Group (AAG). Air and MBRL strikes, with EW, will neutral ise the enemy fire support and 
HQs. Remote mining will impose delay on armoured reserves.  
DEFENDED AREAS  
38. The Main Defensive Area (MDA) .  The MDA is an area in which every effort will be made 
to halt and destroy the enemy.  It consists of defensive belts to canalise the enemy into the 
strongest positions and killing areas.  Only the front positions will be occupied initially, with units 
falling back to depth positions later.  Forces are usually deployed in 2 echelons, with second 
echelon divisions 20 to 30 km behind the first.  The first echelon will fight a stubborn defence and 
will rarely mount counter attack s on its own, but his is not a passive defensive battle.  The Red 
Alliance  place great emphasis on the use of reserves in defence. Penetrations will be met by anti -
tank reserves and MODs which are engineer units equipped to create rapid obstacles.  Anti -
landing reserves will respond rapidly to deep air mobile or airborne attacks .  The scale of the 
defence is shown in the table on Page 1 -3-23. 
39. Defended Areas in the Desert .  Given extensive fields of fire, defended areas are usually 
wider and deeper than on normal terrain.  They are prepared for all -round defence and must be 
able to maintain themselves for long periods without resupply.  Due to the difficulty in achieving 
concealment, more dummy positions than usual need to be prepared.  Inevitably, there will often 
be substantial gaps between areas and often between strongpoints within them.  These are 
covered by surveillance and patrols and may be plugged by remote mining an d artillery fire / attack 
helicopters and / or by the actions of Anti -Tank Reserves (ATRs) and MODs.  
40. Position Preparation  in the Desert .  This generally poses considerable problems in 
deserts.  Digging -in on soft sand is not possible without revetments (fortification); explosive means 
are usually necessary in rocky areas.   There are rarely any locally available materials to be used 
and concealment is also difficult. Positions must be more or less level with the ground and high 
winds will disturb or ruin camouflage and shift sands to reveal defences and minefields.  
41. Obstacle Creation  in the Desert .  With few natural obstacles, there is increased emphasis 
on anti -tank ditching (on suitable soils) and mining (including the extensive use of dummy 
obstacles for deception and controlled minefields to avoid inhibiting friendly forces’ manoeuvre).  
Tactical  and, especially, protective minefields are important to shape the battle but, given the 
unpredictability of a battle’s development and logistic constraint even more emphasis will be 
placed on mining during the course of combat by MODs, artillery and aircr aft. Increased resources 
will be allocated.

1-4-1 SECTION 4 – AIR FORCE OPERATIONS  
40. The Importance of Air Power .  Red Alliance  theorists do not maintain that air power can 
achieve war winning results independently.  The air force has, however, progressed far from its 
previous status as an auxiliary service, albeit an important one.  The significance of air power has 
increased dra matically since World War II and it goes on rising.  In future war, victory will be 
impossible without control of the air, for all combat has become air -land in nature.  Up to 70% of 
the destruction of ground targets will be inflicted by air -delivered weapons, including up to 45% of 
those in the tactical zone.  Moreover, the air element has progressed beyond being merely an 
essential component in the combined arms team at both lower and higher formation levels.  It has 
become the principal compo nent of some deep operations, accomplishing operational missions 
with the aid of missile troops and raiding forces.  
41. Electronic -Fire Superiority .  The first operation in future war, ideally (or rather 
necessarily) pre -emptive in nature, will consist of an electronic -fire engagement.  This will be an 
air, land and sea launched missile, aviation , electronic and increasingly cyber -attack  throughout 
the enemy’s operational and even strategic depth to seize the initiative, establish dominance in the 
information struggle and the battle for air and fire superiority, thus creating the necessary 
preconditions for the actions of th e ground forces.  The electronic -fire engagement may last for 
several weeks and during it there may be only limited offensive activity by major ground 
formations.  
42. The Struggle for Electronic -Fire Superiority .  The Red Alliance  sees the likelihood of a 
future war beginning with an air operation which may assume the dimensions of a campaign.  This 
will determine which side wins the struggle for electronic -fire superiority at the critical operational 
level and therefore, in all pr obability, the outcome of initial operations or even the war as a whole.  
The aims of this operation / campaign will be as follows:  
a. The neutral isation of enemy air defences . 
b. The destruction of enemy High Value Air Assets (HVAA) , especially long -range 
offensive aircraft,  and of operational and operational -tactical missile systems and the other  
components of R econnaissance Strike Complexes.  
c. The disruption of enemy C3I.  
d. Having thus secured electronic -fire dominance, hamper the operations  of ground  
forces by disrupting the enemy’s mobil isation, concentration  and deployment and inflicting 
heavy losses on his ground troops, logistic  support and infrastructure.  
43. The Characteristics of Air Power .  Air Forces possess certain attributes  which impart to 
them the principal role in the struggle for electronic -fire superiority and which make them a major 
player in all operations.  These are  their tremendous reach, ability to deliver large payloads with 
considerable  (often precise) accuracy and their speed of reaction at the operational and  even 
tactical levels.  These qualities give air power the following  characteristics : 
a. Flexibility .  Air power can effectively engage many target sets anywhere in the 
operational or tactical zones, and it can rapidly switch its emphasis from area to area or 
target set to target set.  
b. Responsiveness .  Firepower may be manoeuvred very rapidly across the front and 
into the enemy’s depth.  
c. Concentration .  Modern aircraft can bring formidable weights of firepower to bear 
as long as they are employed with precision weapons.  
d. Surprise .  By virtue of its other characteristics, air power is capable of producing a 
sudden, mass concentration of firepower anywhere of interest to the operational 
commander.  The existence of this capability is known to the enemy, but the where and 
when may be surprising, particularly in the sense that it may be difficult to defend against in 
all sectors of importance simultaneously.

1-4-2 PRINCIPLES IN THE USE OF AIR POWER  
44. General .  In order fully to exploit the characteristics of air power to achieve the greatest 
possible impact on the course of operations and battles, the Red Alliance  has identified certain 
principles. These apply equally at its operational and tactical levels, ie to the employment of both 
the Air Force and Army Aviation.  They are outlined below.  
45. Concentration and Continuity of Effort .  As far as possible, Air Force resources must be 
concentrated to achieve the main operational goal.  Initially, this will always be the achievement of 
air (and fire) superiority.  Thereafter, while maintaining control of the air  with whatever assets are 
necessary, it is likely to be deep interdiction with occasional (but en masse ) diversions into counter 
land operations in support of ground activity  on the main axis or support for air landings.  It is 
considered essential to avoid spreading forces too thi nly by pursuing several operational goals 
simultaneously and thus failing to achieve any of them fully.  It is equally important to avoid 
switching from one operational objective to another before the first is fully achieved.  Continuity of 
effort is thus stressed.  The same injunction to avoid ‘penny packeting’ applies to the employment 
of Army Aviation in the tactical sphere.  
46. Centralised Command and Control .  To achieve concentration of effort, it is necessary to 
centralise command and control.  This also makes it possible rapidly to refocus air effort as the 
operational situation develops.  Exercise of control at the highest possible level is a corollary of 
centralised command and control.  It ensures that effort will indeed be concentrated on the main 
operational or tactical goal and, at the same time, it guarantees the full exploitation of the flexibility 
that is characteristic of air  power.  The highest l evel will be determined by the operational 
objectives and by the range and capabilities of the assets available .  Operational Command 
(OPCOM) of bomber, fighter -bomber, fighter , ground attack  and transport a ircraft will normally be 
delegated to the Red Alliance  Joint Force  Commande r who, in turn, will delegate OPCOM to his 
Air Commander.  Tactical Command (TACOM) of some battlefield support helicopters may be 
delegated to the Land Commander whilst TACOM of embarked helicopters will normally be 
delegated to the Maritime Commander.  
47. Coordination .  The coordination of force packages and of air actions with those of the 
ground forces, air defence and EW is seen to be a complex and  difficult task.  It must be organised 
at the highest practical level.  
48. Economy of Force .  If concentration and continuity of effort are to be  achieved, air assets 
must not be used to perform missions which could be  executed by other means.   Thus, for 
instance, some air defences are better  suppressed by cruise missiles and SSMs, artillery and 
raiding detachments  or SPF than by manned aircraft; reconnaissance and attacks on heavily  
defended point targets may better be left to UAS; ground attack aircraft or  attack helicopters are 
not used to strike targets that can be neutralised  by artillery.  In order to economise on very 
expensive aircraft and crews and to  free them for offensive action, the Red Alliance  has put much 
effort into increasing  the si ze and effectiveness of the ground forces’ air defence.  The Red 
Alliance  does, however, recognise that a combination of losses amongst  air defenders and rapid 
and frequent moves will create holes in the air  defence umbrella, especially amongst forces 
conducting deep battle and  deep operations.  This may impel the Red Alliance  to provide  top cover 
in some  situations.  When conducting offensive action, economy must be achieved  by ensuring 
that strikes are coordinated in terms of time and geographical  area to minimi se the effort required 
to suppress enemy air defences and  defeat enemy fighter aviation.  
49. Surprise .  To reduce attrition rates to acceptable levels, surprise is an  important part of air 
action.  It can be achieved by: choosing unexpected  axes; attacking at an unlikely time; attacking 
in unanticipated strength; using  new weapons and  / or tactics  utilising the entire electronic domain ; 
degrading enemy early warning capabilities , and deceptive actions (especially by UAS). 
50. Preservation of Combat Effectiveness .  The major contribution made by air power to the 
struggle for electronic -fire superiority and the immense cost of modern aircraft combine to make 
this a very important principle.  
a. Defensive Measures .  The Red Alliance  is paying particular attention to the  
survivability of airfields, air defences, EW and reconnaissance assets in  order that aviation 
Edition 4 
1-4-3 can be preserved long enough to achieve its potential  and gain a decisive superiority over 
the enemy.  This requires large  numbers of dispersal airfields with hardened aircraft 
shelters (HAS) and  other hardened facilities for vital installations: redundancy in both  
operating surfaces and air bases themselves is considered vital to  maintaining maximum 
sortie levels.  Rapid runway and taxiway repair are also important and repair parties are 
maintained at a high state of  readiness and training.  
b. Deception .  Deception measures to tempt the enemy into expending his  expensive 
and therefore scarce precision weaponry will assume a  particularly important role.  
c. Offensive Action .  The Red Alliance  believes that offensive action is critical  to 
preserve its ability to conduct deep strikes.  Enemy aviation, both  offensive and defensive, 
must be attacked on its bases.  In the air, the  effectiveness of enemy command and control 
aircraft, including their  associated communications, will be neutrali sed by a combination of 
air and ground jammers working in support of air defence aviation resources  employing 
anti-radiation as well as air to air missiles.  Enemy AWACS,  JSTARs and tanker type 
targets are very high in priority for destruction,  as are stealth aircraft.  Attempts will also be 
made to destroy the  communications and navigation satellites on which so much of an  
enemy’s air effort will depend.  
MISSIONS  
51. General .  Red Alliance  long range aviation, missiles and SPF may well be  used to strike 
key political and military command targets, strategic missiles  and critical economic and 
infrastructure facilities to achieve strategic impact.   Such missions will be controlled and planned at 
the highest level.  Details  will be campaign dependent and are not discussed further in an 
operational  and tactical  manual.  The Joint Military Commander will concentrate his air campaign  
on achieving  operational goals, though its intervention in tactical land battles through the provision 
of counter land support to l and actions and counter sea activity at sea will also have a high 
significance for air tasking, particularly when the Air Commander is the supporting commander . 
52. Achievement of Electronic -Fire Superiority .  For the Red Alliance , the most  important 
task is to prevent the enemy from exploiting to the full the  characteristics of his Reconnaissance 
Strike Complexes and air power while allowing his own to be  utilised to the full.   This means that 
most fixed wing aviation, save for dedicated  ground -attack aircraft, will be devoted for the most 
part to offensive or  defensive counter -air operations until the required degree of control of the air is 
achieved.  A significant part of this struggle for electronic -fire superiority will be the destruction and 
degradation of the enemy’s C3I,  particularly of the reconnaissance and control elements of RSCs 
and RFCs.   Considerable effort will be devoted to the destruction of enemy  reconnaissance, 
navigation, communications and meteorological satellites,  AWACS and those aircraft associated 
with RSCs.  
53. Deep Interdiction .  The Red Alliance  holds that deep interdiction has the greatest  impact 
on the conduct of ground operations in manoeuvre warfare provided,  of course, that the enemy is 
under heavy pressure from the ground forces.   Thus , the second priority after the achievement of 
air and fire superiority goes  to the destruction, disruption and delay of the movement of enemy 
reserves  and logistic support.  The more fluid and mobile operations become, the more  important 
interdiction becomes.  The Red Allian ce realises, however, that the  efforts of a deep interdiction 
operation will only be significant if that operation  is conducted continuously over an extended 
period and with adequate  resources.  
54. Counter Land .  Counter land operations are  seen to have a more immediate, but inevitably  
also a more locali sed influence on the conduct of ground operations.  It is therefore the main form 
of support for the ground forces only when either an  insufficiently favourable air situation or a lack 
of resources preclude a deep  interdiction operation, or during certain crucial phases of the ground 
operation .  These might be the committal of an OMG or operational second echelon to defeat an  
enemy counter attack, the forcing of a major obstacle in the enemy’s depth,  to break up an enemy 
attack or to damage and delay a penetration or  exploitation force .  Such interventions in the land 
battle must, of course, be  closely coordinated with the actions of the ground forces.  The 
preference is  to employ fixed wing aviation against targets outside artillery range, ie for  Air 
Interdiction (AI) missions, and attacks on enemy reserve  concentrations, deep fire systems and

attack  helicopters.  
55. Reconnaissance .  Reconnaissance  is considered a vital mission of the Air Force despite 
the proliferation of satellites and UAS.  The issue has been addressed in detail  in Chapter 1 
Section 2 . 
56. Air Assault .  The actions of airborne and air assault troops are key  components of deep 
operation s and battles.  Their employment is utterly  dependent on the achievement of the required 
degree of control of the air .  The delivery of  these important assets is always preceded and 
accompanied by a major air  effort to eliminate threatening enemy air and air defence elements and 
to neutrali se ground forces which could intervene against the landing.  
57. Aerial Resupply .  Aerial resupply is routinely practised for the delivery of key items needed  
in a hurry.  It is also envisaged occasionally on a large scale, when the air  situation allows, to 
support forces operating in the enemy depth or encircled  groupings.

1-5-1 SECTION 5 – MARITIME FORCE OPERATIONS  
INTRODUCTION  
58. The Red Alliance  maritime forces comprise a mix of Western and former -Soviet platforms, 
some of which date back some years or were procured through friendly third -party nations as a 
way of overcoming sanctions .  In recent years the Red Alliance  has invested considerably in its 
expeditionary capabilities with the acquisition of both new and second -hand amphibious and 
support shipping .  Along with the acquisition of a number of conventional submarines and major 
surface combatants, the Red Alliance  maritime forces can now claim to having developed into a 
true ‘green water’ force.  In addition, the maritime forces include a very large number of Fast Attack 
Craft (FAC) and Fast Inshore Attack Craft (FIAC) suited for more the more traditional c oastal  
operations of a ‘brown water’ navy.   Within the Red Alliance  as a whole, maritime forces are seen 
as the junior partner and are likely to be employed primarily in support of land forces as part of a 
Joint Force.  
ROLES OF RED ALLIANCE  MARITIME FORCES  
59. The 4 roles of the Red Alliance  maritime forces are Warfighting, Maritime Security, Peace 
Support and Defence Engagement.  Primacy lies in warfighting with all units optimised for the 
warfighting role.   The maritime contribution to security, peace support and defence engagement is 
limited to that which is seen to promote the interests of the countries of the Red Alliance.  
60. The Warfighting Role .  The Red Alliance  identifies  2 distinct  and largely separate 
warfighting functions for its maritime forces.  It recognises firstly that success in the maritime 
domain  will be delivered through control of the sea, largely delivered by denying its use to its 
enemies.  Secondly, it recognises the importance of maritime power projection through use of its 
amphibious capabilities in support of the land campaign.   
61. Sea Control .  Sea Control is underpinned by maritime manoeuvre and delivered through a 
number of operational approaches  which are listed below.  Aircraft in the counter sea role may be 
expected to support maritime forces in achieving and maintaining sea control.  
a. Sea Denial .  The Red Alliance  will first and foremost seek to deny its enemies the 
freedom of manoeuvre to operate at sea.  Close to shore it will lay sea mines of which it 
has vast numbers albeit of antiquated design with most being the traditional type of 
moored, contact mine.  FAC and FIAC will be deployed in large numbers using ‘swarm’ 
tactics to deny straits and landing grounds , and missile shore batteries will be integrated 
into the joint plan.  Further out to sea, a Surface Action Group (SAG) compris ing a mix of 
frigates and destroyers supported by a suitable logistics ship may be deployed as an overt 
show of force , whilst submarines may be despatched if covert activity is required.  
b. Fleet in Being .  The simple possession of submarines delivers a real threat to 
enemy maritime forces .  They must expend considerable time and effort to ascertain their 
location  and to monitor them even when they are well away from the enemy forces’ 
operating areas.  
c. Blockade .  Owing to the requirement for enemy forces to reinforce their allies from 
the sea, and as a result of the economies of most nations likely to threaten Red Alliance  
interests being largely dependent on seaborne trade, blockade may be employed to restrict 
enemy forces access to their own ports and to international straits.  A mixture of mines and 
FAC / FIAC swarm tactics are likely to be used to support this approach along with other 
sea denial tactics further out to sea.  
Sea Control is unlikely to be an end in itself but a set of conditions to be achieved in order to  
achieve  a desired condition that will be limited in time, space and to the extent it is required.  
62. Maritime Power Projection .  Amphibious forces , supplemented by merchant ships taken 
up from trade (STUFT) under contract , provide the principal means by which the Red Alliance  
delivers maritime power projection.  Additionally, the Russian / Soviet built destroyers and frigates 
are fitted with guns of sufficiently large calibre to deliver effective naval gunfire support (NGS) to 
forces ashore .

1-5-2 63. Maritime Manoeuvre .  The Red Alliance  does not consider maritime manoeuvre as a 
principle of maritime power in its own right, rather as the su m of the attributes of maritime forces.  
These attributes are universal and enduring and thus do not differ from those identified in Western 
doctrine.  In sum, these are:  
a. Access .  Access guarantees freedom of navigation for maritime forces up to 12 
nautical miles from a c oastline to allow options for intervention at a time and place of 
national choosing.  
b. Poise .  Poise is the ability of maritime forces to loiter in international waters , 
demonstrating a forward military presence at readiness without the political and military 
complications and risks of deploying forces ashore or projecting from a third -party location.  
c. Mobility .  Exploiting the access and freedom of navigation afforded by the sea, 
provides maritime forces  with a high degree of mobility.  This facilitates maritime 
manoeuvre and proves a deployable force that can reposition rapidly and cover significant 
distances to respond to situations.  The capability of ‘lift capacity’  exploits the attribute of 
mobility to move large quantities of materiel by sea.  
d. Persistence .  The endurance provided by on -board stocks, the ability to replenish 
at sea and operate at range from host -nation support provides a sustained presence unlike 
that provided by any other military force.  The attribute of ‘persistence’ enables the 
capability of ‘sustained reach’  which enables maritime forces to operate away from their 
home base.  Persistence is enabled, in part, through the ‘resilience’  of maritime forces.  
e. Versatility .  Maritime forces are uniquely versatile, easily changing their military 
posture, while undertaking several tasks concurrently and remaining available for rapid re -
tasking.  Deploying with inherently high levels of readiness, a warship can transition from a 
peacetime state to a combat ready one in a matter of hours.  
Collectively and individually these attributes deliver influence or the ability of Red Alliance  maritime 
forces  to have an effect on the behaviour of enemy forces at and in the vicinity of the sea.  
64. Cover .  Cover is the provision of protection to units with less combat power or elements 
that are operating in isolation, away from the main force .  The Red Alliance  maritime forces lack 
some of the means to project power from the sea that are available to major ‘blue water’ navies but 
they are capable of fighting in both the underwater and above water battlespaces.  They therefore 
have the capability to provide limited force protection to vulnerable amphibious vessels and STUFT 
as well as to Mine Counter M easures Vessels (MCMVs) and to those involved in the laying of 
mines.   Maritime forces will expect the Red Alliance  air forces to provide defen ce against air attack 
through the provision of Combat Air Patrols (CAP) over maritime formations . 
65. The Maritime Security Role .  The Red Alliance  maritime forces principally contribute to 
maritime security in the fields of Maritime Counter Terrorism (MCT), and through Maritime 
Interdiction Operations (MIO).  Tasks may include stopping, inspecting, seizing, and diverting 
suspect ships and aircraft, and establishing and enforcing a maritime exclusion zone for the 
maritime vessels of one or more parties to a conflict.  Maritime forces may also protect merchant 
shipping with flag -state consent that could otherwise be threatened.   The Red Alliance  mariti me 
forces may operate as part of a multi -national alliance but are more likely to operate unilaterally to 
protect Red Alliance interests.  Other maritime security operations that  the Red Alliance  maritime 
forces may conduct include:  
a. Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief (HADR) .  Red Alliance  maritime 
forces have the reach and capabilities to provide HADR to countries in the vicinity of the 
Arabian Gulf, Red Sea and potentially further afield to South Asia and West Africa.  This 
capability has been developed both to assist friendly states and the home nations of the 
Red Alliance and to bolster the Alliance’s credibility on the world stage.  
b. Freedom of Navigation Operations .  Red Alliance  maritime forces may be 
expected to conduct freedom of navigation operations to uphold their perceived authority in 
the Straits of Hormuz and to assert their right of innocent passage in the waters of other

1-5-3 nations.  This may be conducted partly to reassure friendly states but also to coerce those 
less well disposed.  
66. Peace Support Operations  (PSO) .  The Red Alliance  contribution to PSO is likely to be 
limited to activities in countries where the Red Alliance states wish to reinforce or establish a 
degree of influence.  In these situations, the maritime contribution is likely to be both limited and 
solely in support of operations on land.  
67. Defence Engagement .  As with PSO, Red Alliance  Defence Engagement is likely to be 
carefully targeted at nations which the Red Alliance wishes to influence or where they wish to 
reinforce their presence.  Whilst vessels may well visit friendly ports to conduct defence diplomacy, 
the Red Alliance ’s primary in volvement is likely to be in delivering training as an aspect of capacity 
building in friendly nations and in defence sales to boost the economies of Red Alliance nations.

2-2-1 SECTION 2 : LAND FORCE EQUIPMENT CHARACTERISTICS  
12. Origins .  The Red Alliance  land forces are largely equipped with material of former -Soviet 
or Russian origin.  Historically the Soviet Union supported friendly and non -aligned states with 
military hardware and expertise in order to counter Western influence in the Arabian Gulf and 
elsewhere.  This has continued largely unchanged since the demise of the Soviet Unio n with 
Russia being generally willing to provide military hardware to client states regardless of sanctions 
imposed by the United Nations.  More recently , the nations of the Red Alliance have started to look 
elsewhere for equipment and training,  but the la nd forces largely continue to use Russian 
equipment, albeit within a more manoeuvrist doctrine than previously.  
13. Capabilities .  The characteristics of the equipment and weapons given in the following 
section are drawn  from a variety of Russian and Western open sources.  Whilst all this equipment 
is available in the real world, it may not always be organised or employed in precisely t he 
combinations or manner described in this document.   
14. Nomenclature .  In general, the most commonly u nderstood  name for a piece of equipment 
is used throughout this and subsequent sections.  This will normally be the NATO reporting name , 
for example the 9K35 Strela -10 short -range air defence system is described throughout as the SA -
