2-3-1SECTION 3: ORGANISATION OF AIR AND AIR DEFENCE FORCES  
FUNCTIONAL COMMAND  OF AIR FORCES  
15. To meet the many demands made of air power , the Red Alliance  has divided their
resources into 3 functional commands.  There is, however,  a degree of interchangeability between
the first two and multi -role aircraft  may be switched from one to the other as the situation requires.
In time of war this is particularly important as the campaign moves from Counter Air to Counter
Land .
16. Offensive Air Command (OAC) .  OAC  comprises all those Air Force assets  employed to
reconnoitre and strike targets on the ground, together with  the ESM, escort and stand -off jamming
(EJ and SOJ) aircraft which help them to reach their targets.   OAC includes a number of Army
Cooperation Squadrons dedicated to the support of the Land Commander but which remain under
the OPCOM of the Air Commander.
a.Army Cooperation Squadrons (AC Sqns) .  AC Sqns exist to provide the air
dimension for the tactical battle.  Of course, OAC assets will also be used in this role for
specific phases of combat, but the Red Alliance  perceives the need for a dedicated
component to guarantee intimate air support at all times.  AC Sqns consist primarily of
attack and transport helicopters but also includes day -only ground attack aircraft.
b.Counter Sea .  Counter sea  operations may include strike missions in which the aircraft
involved will be drawn from the OAC.
17. Defensive Air Command (DAC) .  DAC  controls the air defence, air superiority  and
Airborne Early Warning (AEW) and Control  aircraft which combat the air enemy in the air.   The
latter also control offensive aircraft and deconflict their actions with  those of defensive aviation.
Ground Based Air Defence (GBAD) missiles and Anti -Aircraft Artillery (AAA) come under DAC .
a.GBAD .  The Red Alliance ’s Integrated Air Defence System (IADS) falls within the
DAC’s area of responsibility
b.Counter Sea .  Counter sea  operations may include the provision of Combat Air Patrols
over maritime formations in which the aircraft involved will be drawn from the DAC.
18. Transport Command .  The Red Alliance ’s Transport Command comprises fixed wing
aircraft used for logistics  purposes , and the delivery of airborne forces and those rotary wing
transports required to support air operations.  Also coming under  Transport Command are the air-
to-air refuelling (AAR) aircraft , though  operationally these support both OAC and DAC as required.
(AAR is  seen to be an important force multiplier, extending the loiter time of aircraft  on CAPs or on
airborne alert.  They also extend the range  of deep strike aircraft and their fighter protection,
ensuring that they will  not be inhibited from co nducting aerial manoeuvre through shortage of  fuel,
and they enable a ircraft to operate at longer range.
OPERATIONAL COMMAND  OF AIR FORCES  
19. In wartime, a Red Alliance  Joint Military Commander will be appointed to command all
forces allocated to the conflict.  He, in turn, will appoint an Air Commander who will be delegated
OPCOM of the majority of air assets except those retained by the Maritime Commander .
Generally , this will be limited to as small number of ship -based aircraft.
AIRCRAFT, WEAPONS AND FORCE STRUCTURING  
20. Stand Off Weapons .  The problem of destroying targets in the enemy’s depth  in the face
of sophisticated fighter and SAM opposition is approached in a  number of different ways.   One w ay
of reducing risk and therefore attrition  is seen to lie in long -range weapons including the ground
launched cruise missiles (GLCM) and theatre ballistic missiles (TBM)  operated by the land forces .
With a low radar cross  section and a terrain hugging capability, GLCM a re difficult to intercept and
destroy with either air or ground based defences.  Other stand -off weapons in the form of radiation
homing missiles (ARM)  are used against the fire control radars  of threat SAMs themselves to
suppress  air defences on the approaches to targets and to destroy AWACS.   The delivery platform
can engage its target without entering the engagement zone of the enemy’s fighters or dense SAM
defences.  In some cases, it will not even be necessary to leave friendly airspace to launch such
Edition 4 
2-3-2 ‘fire and forget’ weapons.  The cost  of precision weaponry being very high, it can only be provided 
in relatively  limited quantities to deal with the most problematical targets.  Therefore, most  
missions, at least in the tactical zone, will still have to be accomplished  using free fall (including 
retard) bombs and cluster munitions which require  aircraft to overfly the target.  
21. Offensive Aircraft .  The Red Alliance  recogni ses that, while SAM  defences can be 
avoided, or at least exposure to them limited, by careful  routing and low flying, enemy fighters 
cannot easily be evaded if controlled  by AWACS .  AWACS has effectively closed the gap beneath 
ground -based  radars which in the past was exploited by attack aircraft, thus forcing the  latter to 
fight their way to and from the target rather than try to avoid the  defence. Fighter -bomber design 
therefore stresses high speed and  manoeuvrability,  and such aircraft now carry short range air to 
air missi les (AAM ) for self -protection  as well as offensive stores.  There is, in fact, less and less 
difference  in performance between advanced fighter -bombers and fighters, with either  being 
usable (albeit with some limitations) in the other role . 
22. Support Aircraft .  Given that little will escape the AWACS eye in the sky,  offensive aircraft 
are likely to have to fight their way to their target (and back  again).  They will often need fighter 
escorts and will always require EW  support.  The Red Alliance  does not rely solely on self -
protection ECM pods and  decoys carried by attack aircraft.  They are supplemented by large SOJ  
platforms which operate from the safety of their own airspace and are escorted  by EJ aircraft 
(which may not only jam ground and airborne intercept radars  and engage them with ARMs but 
also lay very long, slow -fall chaff trails to  conceal the size of raids and the location of individual 
aircraft within them).  
23. Fighters .  The trend in the Red Alliance  is to purchase fighters with long-range  / loiter 
times and t hat can carry a large inventory of AAMs for different types of engagement.  It also  
reflects a growing stress on BVR engagements, including those using long  range  and look -down, 
shoot -down radars and missiles, in preference to dog  fighting.  Nonetheless , the latter is not 
neglected,  and fighters always carry both  short range, all aspect AAMs and a 30  mm cannon for 
close -in fights.  
24. AWACS .  Both airspace management and air defence are crucially  dependent on the Red 
Alliance ’s small number of AWACS platforms.  
25. Army Cooperation .  The Red Alliance  continues to emphasi se the importance of a  sturdy, 
survivable ground attack aircraft capable of delivering a heavy weight  of ordnance in the tactical 
depth.  Advanced inertial navigation systems  enable such aircraft to deliver attacks accurately from 
very low level against  targets whose location is known in advance and optronic target acquisition  / 
aiming systems aid surprise attacks by eliminating active systems.   In attack  helicopter design, 
three trends are discernible .  One is to provide a fire  support helicopter thought of and described 
as ‘flying artillery ’.  The second  takes the shape of a well-armed  vehicle that can carry an infantry 
section,  known as a ‘flying BMP ’.  Such aircraft are to be seen in growing numbers in  association 
with air assault units.  The third is a rotary wing ‘fighter ’ with the  ability to engage both ground and 
air targets, and with the agility to engage  in dog fights with enemy helicopters.  As attack 
helicopters are now required  to operate throughout the enemy’s tactical depth (by night as well as 
day) and not just along the line of contact, they now carry the same protective  features as ground 
attack aircraft (eg armour against 20  mm cannon fire,  RWRs and radar and IR decoys) .  They too 
have inertial navigation and  optronic targeting and sighting systems (using mast -mounted sights) 
and laser target acquisition and marking systems.  
AIRCREW  
26. Manning .  Expensive and thus scarce assets must be fully utili sed.  The Red Alliance  
seeks to  establish an aircrew to aircraft ratio of 2:1 for all weather,  day and night aircraft and 1.5:1 
for day only aircraft in order to achieve  sustainability.  
27. Training .  Whilst t he Red Alliance  has greatly improved the selection procedures for  
aircrew and the quality of flight instruction and training , training is still limited to an average of 75 
hours per annum for combat aircrew.  Fighter  and fighter -bomber crews are cross trained so that 
they can perform  adequately in their secondary role.

2-5-1SECTION 5: ORGANISATION OF MARITIME FORCES  
PEACETIME COMMAND OF MARITIME FORCES  
28. In peacetime the maritime forces of the nations of the Red Alliance operate to meet the
priorities of their national governments .  There is a standing Red Alliance  maritime headquarters,
the principal role of which is to plan for war.   Subsidiary maritime headquarters are established in
Al Bwarh and Al Seel to exercise peacetime command of national forces, and for warfighting .
29. Al Seel .  Al Seel has invested heavily in its maritime forces though the Navy remains very
much the junior service.  Its equipment is sourced from a wide range of nations, sometimes in
defiance of sanctions through the use of third parties, and contains a mix of Western  and former -
Soviet platforms and technologies though the majority comes from the former Soviet Union and its
successor states.  In recent times, they have become adept at seamlessly integrating these
different technologies and their ships and submar ines now differ significantly from their original
state as delivered from their suppliers.  The peacetime Order of Battle (ORBAT) of A l Seel’s
maritime forces is shown on Page 2 -5-4.
30. Al Bwarh .  Al Bwarh maritime forces have been developed with the assistance of Al Seel
and contain a mix of platforms and technologies from east and west though.  As with Al Seel, the
majority is from the former Soviet Union and its successor states .  Personnel are largely trained in
Al Seel facilities and most operational sea training of maritime units is conducted in Al Seel naval
facilities under the auspices of Al Seel personnel.  As a result, all Al Bwarh maritime forces are
completely interoper able wi th their Al Seel allies.   The peacetime ORBAT of A l Bwarh ’s maritime
forces is shown on Page 2 -5-3.
OPERATIONS DURING CONFLICT  
31. The Red Alliance  maritime forces are conf igured to deliver the warfighting role through
control of the sea limited in time, space and to the degree required to deny its use to the enemy.
To that end , in wartime they are force packaged into a single Maritime Component as shown on
Page 2 -5-4.  The Maritime Component is commanded from the standing Red Alliance  Maritime
Headquarters.
32. Red Alliance  Maritime Component .  The Red Alliance  Maritime Component is organised
in a manner that will be recognisable to Gold Alliance maritime planners and profession als though
the terminology may be different  (See Page 2 -5-5).  The Maritime Component operates as a single
unified maritime Task Force which is sub -divided in to 4 Task Groups:
a.The Amphibious Force .  The Amphibious Force contains 2 sub -formations: 1 Al Seel
Marine Regiment  which would normally make up the majority of the Landing Force, and the
Amphibious Shipping.  The Amphibious Shipping comprises a mix of specialist amphibious
transports: one LPD, one LPH and 4 LSLs , plus 4 STUFT which are Government Owned
and Contractor Operated (GOCO ) and  have civilian crews.   The majority of the amphibious
capability belongs to Al Seel but Al Bwarh’s single LSL plus its 3 Ro Ro / Ro Pax vesse ls
gives it a limited capability to operate independently.
b.The Mine Counter Measures (MCM) Force .  The MCM Force contains 2 MCM
Squadrons, one from Al Bwarh with 3 minesweepers, and one from Al Seel with 6
minesweepers.  All the minesweepers are single role vessels equipped with both
mechanical and influence sweeps .  As such, they are capable of dealing with the types of
mines laid during recent conflicts in the Arabian Gulf but would struggle against a more
sophisticated mine threat.
c.The Strike Force .  The Strike Force is organised into 2 sub -formations: the major units
comprising destroyers, frigates and the replenishment ship, and the extensive FAC / FIAC
force.
(1) Major Units .  The roles of the major units include the provision of ‘cover’ to
the amphibious force, and to form Surface Action Groups (SAGs) to take the fight to
the enemy, most probably in the open waters of the Sea of Oman and the Arabian
Sea.  Al Bwarh operates one destroyer and 2 frigates; Al Seel possesses 2
destroyers and 3 frigates.  The capabilities of the Al Bwarh and the Al Seel vessels
Edition 4 
2-5-2are very similar with no obvious differences in either equipment fit or readiness 
posture.  Only Al Seel possess a replenishment ship, a former British Rover class 
light fleet tanker which has the ability to resupply fuel oils and a limited quantity of 
other stores.  
(2) FAC / FIAC .  The Fast Attack Craft are relatively heavily armed high-speed
vessels and are designed to operate in numbers to overwhelm enemy defences and
launch missiles and torpedoes against enemy surface units close to shore.  The
Fast Inshore Attack Craft operate in a similar manner but are both more numerous
and much more lightly arm ed.  The FIAC deploy in swarms with the aim of denying
the enemy access to choke points such as the Straits of Hormuz close to where
they are based.  Al Bwarh operate s 2 squ adrons of FAC armed with missiles whilst
Al Seel operates one, and both nations have a single squadron  of torpedo -armed
FAC.  Al Seel only operates 2 squadrons of FIAC.
d.Submarines .  Al Seel operates 3 former -Soviet Kilo class conventional submarines
(SSK).  Whilst highly effective sea denial weapons, the principal effect delivered by the
SSKs is to act as a ‘fleet -in-being’  tying up large numbers of enemy surface, sub -surface
and air resources in trying to detect and prosecute attacks against them.  Al Seel Naval
Officers are known to have studies extensively the role of Argentinian SSKs during the
Falklands  Conflict  of 1982  and are expected to seek to achieve the same eff ect in any
future conflict.
33. Readiness and Training .  Red Alliance  maritime forces are kept at a high degree of
readiness.  Al Seel in particular has an extensive maritime support infrastructure to maintain its
vessels, the use of which it extends to the maritime forces of Al Bwarh.  Units of both forces train
regularly together and independently; in recent times, more trust appears to be being placed in
more junior commanders who are permitted to exercise a limited degree of mission command,
reflecting a more manoeuvrist approach by t he high commands of both nations.  It is not known
how effective this will prove in reality; the armed forces of both nations were built up along the
Soviet model.
